title: Works great in my apartment
text:
I live in an apartment with a shared laundry room with one washer & one dryer. Cost is $1.75 to wash and $1.75 to dry.

Buying this portable washing machine has made it EASY for me to do small loads of laundry in the comfort of my own home, without have to lug a laundry basket up & down the stairs to the shared laundry room.

Since the portable washer is only about 17 lbs, it is easy to lift it into my tub to easily add water for the washing, and to easily drain the water in the tub afterwards. The spin cycle removes a lot of the water from the clothing so they will dry faster when you hang dry.

This portable washer is great for smaller items like shirts, pants, socks, and under garments. It can handle smaller loads. Glad I bought this because it is really easy to use and serves its purpose.

title: Game Changer
text: I bought this thing after looking at a bunch of options. Warning the tube that feeds in the water doesn't connect well to a faucet. Solution? I just bought a twenty dollar rinseroo. This perfectly connected to the tube they gave, and it gave me an extra 5 feet. With the rinseroo, I didn't even need to connect take out my shower head up top; it was like meant to be. You just put it on a sturdy stand next to your tub, and drain the water. The spin wash made my clothes 90% dry. The next solution was to buy a panda portable ventless dryer. For 200 total, I created a perfect system of washing and drying with a literal 15 minute set up time. This is insane and a must have. It came like a week earlier than expected.

title: Five Stars
text: Great purchase I did with this machine.

title: Fast but loud
text: This thing is great. It can wash well and dry well enough to reduce drying time on clothes line or dryers. It is not the quietest thing so use it during the day when no one is sleeping. But it is fast and can get your laundry done quick

title: Nice
text: Nice

title: Great Machine w/ Minor Flaws
text:
I live in a small apartment in Midtown, Manhattan and do not have a coin laundromat close. I found that I was spending anywhere between $15-$25 a week on drop-off laundry services and it was quickly becoming my largest expense. As I was looking for different laundry solutions, I came across this machine and ordered it immediately based on other customer reviews. I waited exactly 1 week till I found this sitting on the ground floor of my apartment building. The box was pretty damaged and also placed upside down.

Some comments on the actual machine: 1) Pretty lightweight, around 20/25 pounds. 2) The instructions are useless, you'll understand how to use the product better by watching YouTube tutorials. 3) The cord for water is extremely short and kind of useless as it's only about 3 feet long.

When I first tried it out, I made the mistake of using it in my kitchen and I hated it. Though it was working fine, it was leaking A LOT from the bottom and pretty much got my entire apartment wet. For the next use, I moved it into the tub and it's been working great. I throw in my clothes, leave it to run for 10-15 mins, come back and put the clothes into the spinner for about 3-5 mins. When you drain the washer, you can actually see all of the dirt leaving your clothes. The spinner gets your clothes very dry and if you hang all of your clothes up at night, they should all be completely dry by the morning. I load around 5-10 pieces of clothing. It fits a decent amount, about half of a "normal" load. I would say that a single person should only have to do laundry twice a week.

Overall, I am very pleased with my purchase. However, I wish it didn't leak because then I can put it in a more convenient location other than in the tub (since I have to move it in there every time I want to use it).

4/5 stars.

title: Love it!
text:
I love this little washer. It is much more powerful than I expected! As other mentioned I can confirm the following,
**The hose does not attach to my faucet. But I still fill it with the faucet, just run the water a bit slower and carefully hold the hose beneath it. Works for me, not a big deal other than taking a few minutes. I have the time.
**Gravity drain is what I dislike about this washer. I have the ability to carry it out of my kitchen and drain it outside. If you can't do that, then perhaps drain it in a bathtub? I haven't tried using it in my bathroom but I may do that in the future.
** Spin dryer will only hold about half of your wash load... but it works really well!! Gets clothes close to dry!

Also, it doesn't seem to use a lot of water which is great.
Overall, I'm very happy with this washer, it does what I need it to do. I don't have a lot of laundry to do in general but I was so tired of hand washing and I refuse to waste money at the laundry mat!

title: This portable washer/spinner is AMAZING!!
text: This portable washer/spinner is AMAZING!!!! I love it.  I actually do my wash in this to zen out. Some people meditate.  I wash clothes in this.  I've got my system down to a science that I can wash bed sheets.  It's so light.  Yes, I drain the water into my bathtub, and I have my unit higher than my bathtub.  You just have to figure it out.  I did.  And I no longer have to walk 3 flights of stairs to do my wash.  This thing will wash anything up to 15 minutes.  At 15 minutes, it's clearly washed.  You can use your hands and move clothing around in it while it washes which I do if it looks too tangled.  Meaning, the washer washes right then left then right then left, etc.  It might get tangled.  So untangle as it washes.  My favorite part of this is the spinner.  It nearly spins my clothes dry.  I'm sold.  I've already shown my coworkers this unit.  Make sure it's STABLE when you run it.  Make sure the WATER DRAINS properly.  I have a private terrace so I get to dry my clothes out there.  I leave the tops open when I place this out on the terrace.  This unit is very light.  The price is also amazing.  I will pull this out whenever I know I have 4 loads to wash.  Loads are up to 11 lbs. each.  Now you have some manual labor to do.  If you're not up for that, then don't buy this.

title: Small washer
text: If I wash only two or three small items it will work. Time consuming no water inlets poor instructions on how to use. At least for the average person spinner works well washer clothes get tangled terribly

title: A good buy with a few flaws
text:
I have had this for about a week now amd have done a ton of loads- I really let the laundry pile up while looking for a laundry solution for our apartment. Over all it works really great. It took some trial and error to figure out how much I coukd fit in it without over-taxing the machine. I can fit two bath towels in a load, or a queen fitted sheet with two pillowcases. I haven't tried to wash adult jeans yet, but I can't imagine trying more than two pairs.
As many people have mentied the water intake hose is useless. I fill it up with my shower head.
I put it in the bathtub to was and drain. It is quite loud and has scuffed my tub somewhat, but I think it would be quieter sitting on an even floor. It is easy to lift while empty, but mot so much when it's full of water, so I just keep it in the tub until I'm completely done with it.
The spind dryer is awesome. It gets most of the water out and most things will dry in a couole of hours. Even my jeans are usually dry after hanging overnight.
I'm pretty happy with this overall. It definitely beats hand washing!

title: Five Stars
text: So far so good wash the clothes so clean

title: This machine works great. I have found that it's going to be ...
text:
This machine works great. I have found that it's going to be saving me a lot of money. I set mine up in my bedroom to keep it out of the way of management. It's sitting on milk crates side by side. A waste basket is perfect for catching the water. I had it in the tub but felt my neighbors could hear it below me. This will be perfect for a Christmas gift.

The part I can't use is that hose. It's no big deal as a bucket is perfect to fill my washer. The spin cycle is better than the washer in the laundry mat.

Edit....8/29/17 I dropped the washer and got scared. So,I put the washer in my tub. I fill it with two buckets of water. But what I was using was the hand held hose for the shower. It drains right in the tub. I then remove it to the closet as not to let my neigbors now I have it. This is the only one I see with the built in lint catcher which is great.

title: Get Ready to Wash for Hours & Get Your Hands Wet!
text: I bought one of these for my apartment and now I'm stuck with it, so I thought I reveiw it. I've used it about 4 times, but finally got frustrated and just go to the coin laundry now because I'm in and out in 45-50 min vs the 3-4 hours it takes to do laundry with this thing and an in-home clothes dryer thing (you've seen those too I'm sure!). First off, you need to put this thing in your shower or bathtub to use it, so you have to lug it around the apartment in order to use it (a hassle). Second, you have to get a special hose to get it to connect to the shower or bathtub spout, so get ready to have to buy a "Washing Machine Drain Hose Extension" in addition to this unit in order to even be able to use it properly (the flimsy thin tube they provide with the packaging is totally useless, believe me!!!). Third, when using it, you have "babysit" the entire procedure. You can't just throw a bunch of clothes in it and expect it to work on it's own like a normal washing machine. TO WIT: By "babysit" I mean you have to continually lift the top of the washer reservoir to move the clothes around in the hot water (yep, actually get your hands down in that hot laundry soapy water!) so that the clothes don't get tangled into an impossible spiders web, something you can't untangle (which they WILL if you leave it alone). Then, after you drain the hot soapy water, you have to re-fill it with cold water, and get your hands down in there AGAIN during the rinse. It's a total pain!  Then, for the Spin Dry side, you have to go 3-5 articles of clothing per spin, which is a huge time waster. All in all, 1 single load of a weeks worth of shorts and t-shirst would take me about 2 hours to totally complete and have ready to dry in the dryer machine (another waste of money item that I bought! Hahaha!). Anyways, hope this helps. I'd only buy this thing if I had no other way to wash clothes. At the coin laundry my clothes come out cleaner, softer, and everything gets done faster.  Thanks for reading!

title: Convenience and Price
text:
I’ve had this for 3 months now.

As many other reviews say, it does its job, but the washer is more useful than the dryer side. Still more convenient than not having a Washer/dryer at all, and the dryer side being the weaker side isn’t enough of a detriment to give it 4 stars. The dryer is the weaker side because it doesn’t produce heat, but, rather, spins the clothes around, pretty much “air-ing” the clothes dry, which takes a while to do since it only spins in 5 minute intervals. I just wanted to get my clothes clean in a convenient manner, and it does that.

I put it in my bathroom, where it is easier to fill and drain than other places in my apartment. I use a small bucket to fill it with water and put it in the tub to drain it and use the detachable shower head to rinse the inside of the washer side out, but you can just fill the bucket with water and do it that way too.

Over all, I recommend it for the convenience and price.

title: Perfect for small spaces/apartments
text:
Pros: compact size, washes clothes thoroughly, amazing spinner - leave clothes 75 -80% dry, quick wash and spin cycles, work well with powder/liquid or laundry detergent pods, good for shirts, bottoms, workout/lounge-wear, sheets, small towels, delicate and children's clothes,
Cons: tiny water inlet hose that is not compatible with most faucets, gravity draining means that you have to have the machine elevated to properly drain, you may need to tilt the machine to ensure all water is properly drained, small loads at a time

Overall impressions: very convenient and super easy to use (despite poorly written instructions), reasonably price solution for small spaces

title: This machine was good until the spinner stop working the third time I ...
text: This machine was good until the spinner stop working the third time I used it in a small period of a month

title: Glad to know such items exsist!
text: I bought this for a friend of mine who lives in studio under a shared house. Unfortunately, she was having problems with the dryer and the man of the house refused to fix it due to favoring a lower monthly bill instead. We both went searching for a portable washer and dryer that would help resolve this issue and came across this item. After I bought and had this delivered at her place she instantly fell in love and found washing her laundry much easier without having to use any electricity. This is a really good buy if you live in a small place and want to save up on bills.

title: Wish I would of bought sooner!
text:
Saving alot and stopped visiting my dry cleaners. This washer fits more than what they advertise. You can wash and spin at the same time too. Clothes wash in 5 to 15 minutes and can be spun dried for 2 minutes and then hung to dry the rest of the way. I even wash a few of my size 8 running shoes and spin dry 2 pairs a time. Fits a queen size quilt but can't spin dry it because the spin size is smaller, unless you try and squeeze it in there. Can also wash about 4 to 5 sets of medium to large scrub sets or about 8-10 xl men's shirts. Fits in your shower or tub and you don't have to buy extra things. I use my hand held shower head to fill it and drains pretty fast. Can store in any closet when done. No difference in electric bill but it does use quite a bit of water if you do full loads.
Hope this helps you.

title: It's pretty good for the right situation....
text:
This is good if you are in a pinch and have no alternative to do laundry. That's about it really.
It works and will get things clean, but washing delicate or expensive things is RISKY. It looks like it ruined a sweater of mine, although I knew putting it in was risky.
It's not really a hassle to use or anything, I just think most people are actually better off buying their own washer and dryer due to how much better they clean and treat clothes.

Obviously this thing will have you spending more time doing laundry since it takes small loads. Drying is the biggest pain.

title: Good product
text: I am happy with this mini washer. I purchased it as replacement until I can afford a bigger one. My clothes come cleaner, thanks to the15 minute wash cycle! My only gripe is draining this washer. I cannot set mine in my tub due to the drain being on the right, and drain hose on washer is on left. The washer drain would be facing uphill, causing drain issues. I have to use a 5 gal. bucket to catch the water as it drains. My issue is more of a housing flaw than product flaw. I wish there was a way to hook this machine up to regular washer hose, and drain pipe. I'm thinking that a water hose (with spray nozzle) might be the better solution, so I don't have to constantly turn my water lines on and off, which could break the lines if not handled carefully. But the washer is great! And the spin dryer is probably the best I have ever seen!

title: Amazing!
text:
I bought this in response to COVID-19, since I'm from Queens and I didn't want to risk it at a laundromat. It washes so well! The spinning compartment leaves clothes almost dry, so it's fantastic. Couple of things to keep in mind: there's no pump to get the water out. There is a hose that gets the water out by gravity alone, which means the machine has to be off the floor. I am using an Ikea tv stand. It being from Ikea, and not being solid wood, it hobbles with the movement of the machine. So I also ordered some corner brackets and plates to reinforce the stand and make it sturdier. Success!
Another thing to keep in mind, is that the hose to put water in, is too little to work. So this is what I do. I keep my machine/stand in the kitchen. When I have a load, I bring them to the bathroom and use the shower head to fill there washer up and to drain, I just put the hose in the bathtub. It is super fast and leaves clothes clean.
It is noisy. More so the washer than the spinner. But hey, small price to pay to wash your clothes at home.
Absolutely recommend it!!!

title: Godsend!
text: I got tired of lugging heavy laundry baskets up and down stairs from a second story apartment, in and out of car, in and out of laundromat, being with weird people. What a godsend! When I first used the machine I was surprised at the black water. Apparently the expensive laundromat machines don’t clean as well as I thought they did. Excellent cleaning power with this machine! The sheer convenience of doing your own laundry any time you want is so worth it. Don’t waste your money on a dryer machine or heating rack. We use a folding wooden clothes drying rack and a regular fan (like for summer cooling) if we are in a tearing hurry. It only takes about an hour to dry. The spinner is so good that I only need to run it for a minute or two and the clothes are almost dry.

title: I LOVE this little washer!
text:
So far so good! I did a lot of research before purchasing this model. Per the suggestion of other reviewers, I also purchased 2 of the "Generic Flower-type Washing Machine Floating Lint Mesh Bag Hair Filter Net Pouch Blue " to toss into each load to help catch lint/hair, and they do a great job! They're only a few bucks, so definitely worth the expense, folks. So, I'm including a bunch of pics on how I've set mine up.

As you all know, the gravity-feed for the drain is an issue to solve in your own way. I solved it by situating my washer right on top of our guest bathroom sink (it also is a laundry room with a water spigot, which I purchased a 10 ft washer hose with a little brass clamp/off-switch (see pics) so I don't have to run back and forth to turn on/off water while trying to fill the washer.

In the pics, you'll notice that the sink doesn't look very deep. It's not, but guess what? There's only like...what, 4-6 gallons of water in the washer? There's an overflow hole in the back of the sink, and although the water does come out rather quickly, between the drain in the bottom of the sink and the overflow hole, it has never flowed out over the top of the sink (knock on wood).

I have to agree with other reviewers that the spin cycle is GREAT. The clothes come out very well wrung out so that they dry much quicker. I dry as much as I can outside, and when I can't I dry inside on racks. If it's too rainy/humid and my clothes don't dry in a timely manner, I finish them off in my panda stand-up blue fabric dryer...which works pretty well.

I know each person needs to sort out their work-around for 1) where/how to drain and 2) how to get water into the washer. This is my solution, and I'm VERY happy with it! My clothes come out very clean. I do pre-treat major stains with a bit of laundry soap (or dish soap in a pinch) and let them sit overnight with the soap on the stain before I wash the item. The washer does as good a job of getting stains out and cleaning the clothes as any big washer I've ever used (if not better).

I also love that I can more easily choose how long I want each cycle. I may need only 10 mins to wash, 8 mins to rinse, and then 3.5 mins to spin out (which is what I normally do)...or, I might choose to wash for a full 12 (or more) mins for very dirty loads. It's not as easy as all that with regular washers to adjust each cycle and save on electricity! On regular washers, you basically are a slave to a super long cycle using up more electricity than perhaps is needed. Cheers!

title: This machine is absolutely wonderful. The piece of mind alone of being able ...
text: Rarely write reviews but greatly appreciate the time others take to do it so felt compelled and necessary here.  We have been traveling full time in a 31ft motor home since December 2016.  We occasionally stay in RV parks w laundry facilities but many times we dry camp... no facilities... sometimes for a week or more at a time. This machine is absolutely wonderful.  The piece of mind alone of being able to wash when we need to is worth it alone.  We have been able to reduce our spare clothes we take from a one month supply down to 10 days or so which saves us space.  So nice being able to stay in our RV and not have to sit in a laundry mat.  Individual loads will easily handle our jeans, queen sheet set, bath towels, a big beach towel.  Simply amazing.  We can keep up every 4-5 days and never get behind!  Powerful yet small enough to keep out of the way in our shower/tub or bedside.  Great place to store our dirty clothes in the washer which also saves space elsewhere.  People that have these seem to have. I reliability issues and we haven't either... so reasonably priced that if it breaks we will likely just order another one but should last a few years.  Weight only 28 lbs so super easy to move around.., even to do laundry outside.  Our favorite purchase for our motor home!!

title: Five Stars
text: Best hundred bucks you could spend if your living tiny

title: Good by if you need it
text:
I’ve had this for a while now and waited to review to see the longer results. This is great if you don’t have room for a washer and hate the laundry mat. It’s a little time consuming changing from wash to spin but works. Get the clothes cleaner than I expected and holds quite a bit. The spin cycle really spins the clothes almost dry which although the reviews said so I was skeptical. My only issues with it is the cord and hose length. The fill hose that came with it it small and short so we got a hose and connector which works better for us and is much faster filling. The drain hose could definitely be longer and it actually started leaking a little bit but we wrapped it in cellophane to stop that. We also had to sit out on a wooden crate so it would drain properly.
This is not a perfect washer but it does work for what it’s needed for and am happy with my purchase considering I loath the laundry mat.

title: Worth it for small spaces
text:
I was hesitant to buy this after reading reviews, however, I didn’t want to go to a laundromat. I decided to give it a try. It arrived very quickly.

I did an overall inspection before I used the machine. I noticed staining in the drain tube that was similar to another reviewer. I believe this is from the manufacturing process and it doesn’t affect washing your clothes. Odds are, you will have to buy an attachment for the water inlet because the tube they provide is way too small to fit anything. I bought tubing that was for a dishwasher drain and it works alright for the job at hand. The instructions provided are garbage. Throw them out and use other reviews as a guide.

I place a small table in my bathtub and run the machine in the tub.

The machine runs well. Do not wash more than 2-3 loads a day. Do not overfill the spin dryer as it will make a lot of noise and causes more vibration. I’ve had to catch it before it fell off the table. I’ve been using liquid detergent, but it’s a gamble as to how much to use.

My final advice would be to only use the machine every couple of days so you’re not wearing out the machine. This is a good machine for people living alone or in a tiny apartment.

title: un poco pequeña pero trabaja muy bien

title: Snowbirding Savior
text:
We are snowbirds and I was looking for something to use in our travel trailer. I have been using this for a couple of weeks and it meets my needs.

It is a bit larger than I expected, but we have it on folding stools in our shower. The set up allows me to fill the washer side with the shower head (although I also fill a pail from the kitchen sink to fill faster). I drop in a Tide pod and agitate it for a couple minutes before adding my clothes.

I tried to run water in the spin side as the rinse, but I didn’t feel the soap was getting out of the clothes very well. So, I do a few wash loads with the same water and then empty and do a rinse cycle in the wash side. Then I spin them 3-5 minutes without adding any water. The clothes come out much drier than I thought they would and line drying is fast.

Because we are in a small space, it isn’t convenient to have to move it out of the shower when we want to use. It’s a bit clumsy getting it in and out of the shower, but we are still able to manage.

There is just 2 of us, but I still wash a load every couple of days as it does take me a good hour with adding the rinse that I do. Still better than $2 a wash and another $2 to dry in a laundromat.

text: This thing works great! My only complaint is the terrible water intake hose. I bought a bucket to help me fill it by hand in the tub but otherwise it's so useful.

title: Good Product, Badly Translated Instructions!
text:
Great product, terrible directions!

1. Unless you have an open three-prong outlet very close to your sink or tub, you'll need an extension cord. The power cord is very short and requires a three-prong outlet.

2. The machine uses gravity to drain. I used a heavy duty steralite bin to raise it a foot or so off ground level. I put a non-slip mat under the bin and a towel under the washer. Once you can point the drain tube straight down, you know it's going to drain properly.

3. This thing makes a lot of noise on hard floors! I don't suggest setting up on carpet in case of leaks, but I put a bath mat under mine to muffle noise.

4. The wash cycle is very quick. I suggest using non-HE soaps. Run the wash with soap once, drain, then run again with plain water.

5. Always drain IMMEDIATELY after washing. The stagnant water smells bad very quickly and can build up residue.

title: Great potential.
text: I'm very mixed up about writing this review... right out of the box, the machine didn't work properly. The wash side did not operate at all, we could hear the gear/motor going in and out but it wouldn't spin. If you stick your hand in and spin the blade (not sharp) part it would spin (VERY strongly, by the way) for about four seconds than stop. It was frustrating how much potential this thing had, how powerful it was. I contacted the seller (not Amazon) and although it took some (very little) back and forth, they refunded the cost of the machine. I was bummed they wouldn't just replace the item, but they did right by me either way.

title: 7 month update
text: I haven’t used this machine that much, but it’s handy in a pinch. The inlet hose is completely worthless, so people have used their imagination to come up with work-arounds. Something you should not have to do for this price of an item. I just use the kitchen sprayer which takes forever to fill up, and the electric cord that came with it is not long enough to work in my bathroom to use shower. It needs to be plugged directly into a wall, not an extension cord, but I’m going to find a heavy duty one & try that. Anyway, the one thing that bugs me the most is the tiny spin basket. Why on earth would they not make it the same size as the washer tub???  I washed a small fleece blanket. The washer handled it just fine, but the tiny spin basket was too small, so it’s hanging out on my deck railing to drip dry. If the spin basket was same size it would have been fine. Instead I still had to wring it out by hand. Do not expect to use this for anything other than a few pieces of light clothing only. I also noticed it is starting to leak from under the upper seal (not the lid or crack where lid opens, but the seal that glues the top to the bottom. It was not due to overfilling. Small light loads - great. Nothing else.

title: Seriously impressed
text: 8 pairs of underwear, 3 tshirts, 3 sleeveless tank tops, a pair of shorts, 2 dresses (all women's XL) and a bulky sweater, and I could've fit more! title: Works, But is Hassle

Had a bit of a time trying to figure out how and where to drain it in the apartment. Also - the spin unit is separate, so for each spin cycle (drain soap, rinse) have to move stuff into the spin bin, then back to the washer bin for a rinse. It does work, but frankly if I had to do it over, I'd try the bucket and plunger method instead!

title: Unresponsive Customer Service; Machine works great, until it doesn't. Good luck!
text: Purchased in January, washing machine stopped spinning in March. Requested a return/replacement and received no response, over a week later. Sent second request. The initial purchase was easy, item arrived quickly and as ordered. Setup was easy, worked great. Until it didn't. But for only getting three month's of use, it is giving me buyer's remorse. These compact washers from all manufacturer's don't seem to have much of a life cycle. I've used many and they're all cheap crap. Lasting the longest was the Panda and it only worked for about a year. Thinking next I will just purchase the spin dryer separately and expect to replace the washer piece every 6 mos to a year.

title: Not for US traditional laundry room/not free return/ need adapter to connect to water supply
text:
After received the washer, we found out that it isn't compatible with US traditional laundry room, it needs a drain on the floor to dump the water. We tried to install in the bathroom, but the water intake tube is too short to reach the faucet, also it needs an adapter to connect. More, you will need to buy a power extension cord since the power cable is short too.
We started return process, but the seller gave us two options, one is get a refund of $15 and keep the product, selling it or gifting it whichever you want. Two is returning the product but they charge $40 shipping and returning fee.

title: Surprisingly Great!
text:
I must say I was skeptical when I bought this little portable washing machine. But so far this little machine proved to be a great buy and investment.

I have washed so far: clothes, pet bedding, sheets, and small blankets in this little machine. Note that for obvious reasons due to size, you will not be able to wash comforters in this machine. Not unless they are for a twin size bed and don't have much thickness to them. Kids blankets and maybe throws will fit just.

I would say the worst feature for this machine is that the drain. It uses gravity to drain the water. If the machine it is not set up higher than the drain, then it can cause a big mess. Luckily I have a stand alone shower in my bathroom (separate from my tub) that I can just drop the drain hose on the floor of the shower to the drain.

The best feature is the spin basket. I does a good job getting the excess water out of the clothes. All you have to do is get it to balance correctly. Which is not hard and most of the time it balances on its own.

I am glad I took the chance on this machine and I hope it continues to work for some time.

title: Great Investment!
text: This works so well and it's made apartment living so much easier! When I use this, I put two short/small folding tables in the bathtub and place this on top of the tables so that the gravity effect of the drain works easily. As others pointed out, the water intake tube doesn't fit on any normal faucet. I solved this problem by buying a large funnel. I stuck the intake tube onto the small end of the funnel. I hole the funnel up to the shower head and let the water flow straight from there into the intake area of the washer and it's perfect. This washer works REALLY well. The only downside is getting used to allowing things to drip dry, but it's worth it considering the fact that I no longer need to run down to my apartment building's laundry room in order to do laundry, sit and wait, transfer stuff from washer to dryer, etc. This machine was a terrific purchase.

title: Professional Pumpers
text:
Its too soon for Me to give My final review I may up date later

Up date September 06 2019 I bought a 3 gallon Shop Vac wet/dry vacuum cleaner do Not buy It, It has a major design flaw You heard the saying IF ITS NOT BROKE DON'T FIX IT! and boy did Shop Vac fixed It, It No more has a place to connect to the hose to the exhaust and on top of that It sprays liquid out the back all over the electrical switch.
The good news I thought I clogged the drain up and with the problem with the Shop Vac I decided to take this washing machine apart drill some holes take a big hammer to It and all that stuff, but It was easy to repair I remove the back cover with a Phillips screw driver No security screws and there Is a plastic strap It looks like that goes on big cardboard boxes, the strap has a hook on It that connects to the drainage valve and the strap was Not connected and once I connected It, It now drains just fine. also I washed a Polyester light twin size blanket In that was laying on the ground for years had grass growing on It, It was very dirty the washing side did Not get It very clean I think would have to take It to a car wash and use a pressure washer or use a old fashion washboard to get It very clean but this washing machine had No problem with It at all It Is powerful but unfortunately the blanket was too big for the spin cycle side, It has the power to spin It just will Not fit.

one thing Is for sure just as on many other products Whoever designed the drainage was Influenced by professional plumbers that always use too small of drain lines so some (*&^*%*%$ can harass Us for clogging up the drain, because the drain got clogged up and I could Not get It unclogged. so a ordered a 40 dollar wet/dry vacuum cleaner.
I had a fulls size washing machine but I could Not stop the mice from getting Into the tub and decaying there, these manufactures can build computerised washing machines that know more about clothes than I want to know but they can Not make them pest proof.
I Am using a bucket and a thing that looks like a toilet plunger to wash My clothes but Its Inside of a Thermal Ice Shelter and when turning on the hot Water Its gets hotter than Oklahoma/Arizona and If add some beach there Is the ASPCA for cruelty to Animals but what about cruelty to Humans?
This washing machine would be good for warmer climates but Not for cold climates washing heavy coats and blankets which I was hoping for some miracle that It would.
I had 2 Polyester sheets laying outside for a few years hoping some day to be able to afford a washing machine and the sheets were very dirty covered with mud so I scraped them off the best I could and put them In the washing machine and by mistake I filled It up all the way with hot Water It seems seems to have plenty of power swishing the the sheets back and forth but only gets the outer of the sheets clean, You would have to set the sheets In another way to get It all clean,
Therefore this washing machine even though It Is plenty powerful enough to wash heavier loads but It still does better with smaller clothing Items.
I wanted to get a washing machine that Is a little bit larger but all the ones that I seen all are digital models to Me If appliances did Not have It In the 1960's then It does Not need It now to Me simpler Is better I did Not want that digital circuitry getting wet and quit working.
The spin cycle Is perfect though I wish It was larger, It makes a little bit of noise starting up but then Is very quiet and smooth and fast.

title: Great machine.
text:
Read full review as i have two parts.
I will preface this by saying that mine did spring a leak on the wash tub side, i'm sure i can open it up and caulk it, i'll update if i ever do with the result. For now i just have a cloth under the leg where the slow trickle is coming out.
I contacted the company about this and they resolved it with a partial refund that could go towards me fixing it or a new machine.

Yes, the tubes are short, i have mine on a table and i cut down my house drain pipe. (This was a temp machine until we can afford a "real" one, but i'm not sure i even want a real one) i had to macgyver the inlet tube, i brought the tube and my sink connector to ACE (Yes, go to them, mine is family owned and amazing) and they hooked me up. (Literaly? Haha)

You have to manually fill and drain, but i like that. I can choose specific temps and amounts and times.
It has a gravity drain vs pump, which i also like, one less thing to break.
Spin dryer gets the clothes damp, we hang them outside in the summer and inside near a heat vent in the winter, theyre dry withen 1-3hrs on a good day, and most days are good.
Lint is an issue, wash like colors.

This thing gets the clothes SUPER clean. My water was quite dirty the first load, but after that the water wasnt as dirty with the same clothes, so, i conclude that my "real" machine (which was a big brand efficiant whatever) wasnt cleaning that great.

I am choosing not to take a star away for the leak, this is a fantastic machine and the company also resolved it promptly.

title: Broke after 15 uses
text:
After 15 uses, the spin dryer broke. It spins, but the entire machine moves, meaning that the thing travels across the floor, and the water isn't extracted. I am about to move and will not be needing this anymore, so I'm not fussing with trying to fix it. From other reviews, it sounds like this is a common problem.

I also had problems with fuzz collecting on my clothes. And, even on the "soft" cycle for 12 minutes instead of 15, I had two handknit socks that had tears after washing.

That said, it did very well with t-shirts and underwear. I found it works much better if you process a light load. Put clothes in the spin extractor to the point where it is full. Then fill the tub to the top of the lint trap, then put those clothes in the tub. That amount gives your clothes plenty of room to move about and really get clean. I did like the ability to have the machine in my apartment and just do 1-2 small loads a week. The laundryroom in my current building is filthy so this was a much better experience. That said, it did break...and it came with a broken spot in the back that luckily didn't affect use.

title: but it's really easy once you get the system down
text: I live on a boat and our only option is 110v washers, but they never seem to work that well. When you live on a boat you know, adding any additional source of water intake (washers, dishwashers and so on) is a bit nerve wracking. We keep this washer outside on the dock and fill it up with the hose. Grey water dumping is allowed, so we use a biodegradable soap and it drains directly into the water. It's a bit of an adjustment if you're used to regular washers, but it's really easy once you get the system down. The spinner gets things pretty close to dry, the same if not better than a regular washer. It gets them dry enough that my 110v dryer can handle the load in about 45 minutes. Our marina has a laundry room but I prefer this setup over having to pay and compete for laundry time.

title: A Great Way to Do Laundry InHouse (at least as of the first 30 days of purchase)
text:
It's taken me awhile to figure out how best to make this work without buying additional "stuff," and I finally think I have it. Despite the fact that a piece has already broken (more on that later), I'm really glad I bought this, and I did based on reviews; hence my taking the time to write about my experience. For inquiring minds, it does come in a box that DOESN'T identify what's inside, which is good when your homeowners' docs say "no washer." Second, unboxing is a breeeze and it's not too difficult to lift and carry around. While I wish I had bought a pump washer (and I recommend you consider it) the gravity drain works fine as long as you have it raised. Despite what several reviewers said, just putting it in the bathtub doesn't work well because it's an insufficient drop. I had 4 glass blocks which right now are being used to support this. While it's a tad wobbly, particularly on spin cycle, I've run one load this way and it was fine. Secondly, the spinner side is INCREDIBLE. It really, really gets the liquid out and clothes dry much quicker than when you take them out of a "regular" washer and hang them to dry.

Despite what many people wrote, I had no problem going to Home Depot and buying some plastic tubing that fits over the water intake valves. I simply stick the tube in the washer side and put it on the intake valve on the spinner side.

As far as washing is concerned, PLEASE be careful when the detergent! I put mine in a pump soap dispenser and slowly came to the realization that ONE pump of soap is more than enough! Rinsing the soap out is the biggest issue and ultimately what I do is similar to what someone else posted -- I spin the laundry after washing for 1 minute or so, then put it back in the washer side and re-fill with water and "wash" for a few minutes (generally adding vinegar), then use the spin cycle with water flowing in for 1 minute or so, and spin without water for 2 to 3 minutes.

What has broken is the lid to the spinner side. The little plastic insert your supposed to put on top of the clothes popped up and actually "shaved" plastic off from the inside and also somehow damaged the top lid so now I have to scotch tape it down. I don't know what got shaved off, whether it was an inside catch or what, but I had to wipe out alot of plastic, so be sore that insert plastic disc is really pushed down on top of your clothes before you spin.

Overall, for the price and quality, I highly recommend this and have now ordered the Panda 3.75 dryer so I can have the full laundry experience in house. I'll review that after I use it for a while. I'll also revise this posting as time goes on. I hope this lasts longer than a year but it being lightweight plastic, we'll see.

title: excellent small machine so far
text: Ive been using it as my regular washing machine.  In fact it sits on top of my regular broken washer and drains right into the washing machine drain in the wall.  I'm doing a load as I type.  it's a little noisy and i like to keep an eye on things.  You can throw in a load and then leave the house.  But I'm very pleased.  It gets things clean and I like using natural products, vinegar, Dr. Bronners, etc.  I do find that I prefer to rinse in the washer side instead of the spin side.  I just find it easier.  I drain and then refill and then wash again for a few minutes, then i drain and place load into the spin side.  sometimes it takes two spin loads ;to equal one load of wash.  So i spin half the wash load and then throw it in the dryer.  and then do the rest.  Its a great little machine.  I didnt have $500 or $1000 to spend on getting my machine repaired or buying another, so this is an awesome solution until I have the money.  and as previous posts state, ignore the skinny plastic tube and the instructions.  I put water into the washer via the old washing machine hoses.  I place the hose inside and turn on the water and fill it that way.  I've read that some people use a bucket.  It works great.  make sure dial is on normal and not drain, turn the other dial to the time you need for agitation and voila!  you are washing.  When you are ready, turn dial to drain and then place wet clothes into the spinner.  and then turn dial to the time you need for spinning.  and then you are done.  Again rinsing is your choice whether you rinse in the washer side or the spinner side.

title: Love it tons
text:
How have I not reviewed this yet? Love it tons. I've had it for about 3 months now and wash about once to twice a week.
I use it as my dirty clothes hamper, so I just wash when it approaches full. If I'm not washing pants, I can usually wash 15+ articles of clothing between t-shirts, shorts, and underwear. And plenty socks. It'll take 15 minutes of washing, though I usually do 15 more minutes. Then I spray lots of water in the washing compartment to rinse them out. Afterwards, most batches take 2 sets of drying to dry. Get it dry enough that I can put the clothes on a hanger and blow a fan at them and they be dry in a few hours. When cold in the house, does take until morning. (assuming I put it on the wash at 9PM and hang them at 10PM and not check on them until I wake up at 6:30 AM).

Love it though. I've always been terrible about washing clothes, especially when I had to go to a laundromat. Now I just cart the washer into the shower, fill with hot water, throw detergent in and turn it on. It's great for lazy people like me as the cycles are so short. If you forget to take something out, the second cycle still has enough time since it doesn't take long to do its thing.

title: A dream! Just put it in the tub
text:
ETA October 2020: Still using the machine regularly. No complicated setup is necessary. Just put it in the tub when you want to use it. If you have a handheld showerhead, fill the washer up that way (I usually unscrew the actual showerhead to get a full flow from the hose). Couldn't be simpler. Haven't been to a laundromat in years.

ETA July 2019: Well it's been 8 months, and I wouldn't take off a single star. I now have a removable showerhead with a hose, so filling it up's a breeze. I sit the machine right in the tub for use, no alterations or props needed. It's not perfect -- towels end up *really* fuzzy, and after drying any wash I have to run a lint brush over everything. But it's worth it.

I've had this for just 2 days so far -- wow. I've had to use laundromats my whole adult life, always in walk-up 4th or 5th floor apartments. This is a life-changer. I've done three loads already, and it's really simple and straightforward to use.

Pros:
- It works! In my most recent load I washed 6 shirts, pajama pants, and several pairs of undies and socks. That's practically 1 week's clothing for me. (adult woman, size 6) That's about 1/3 a typical laundromat load (half of a home-sized washer)
- Very easy to use
- Lightweight when empty so I can easily move in and out of tub
- It's about as loud as your typical washing machine; when I close the bathroom door the noise is mostly muffled. The spinner starts off loud but gets very quiet after a few seconds.
- A complete load takes about 30 min including hanging to dry -- compared to 2 hours at the laundromat!!

Cons:
- The hose, obviously, but see the easy adaptation I came up with below
- The spin-dryer is overblown by other reviewers -- it gets clothes about as dry as they'd come straight out of a regular washing machine. Takes several hours to dry.
- Lint is an issue. I've been using a lint roller when folding my clothes -- usually there's 1-2 pieces that catch the bulk of it. Also, I suggest washing your clothes inside out. The lint catcher needs cleaning after 2 loads, but it's still not catching a lot.

My setup:
- I converted a rubber glove to adapt the hose -- see picture. I slip the rubber glove over my showerhead with a rubber band, and I snipped the tip off of one finger, which allows it to fit neatly over the hose. I tied the other fingers into knots to focus flow. I taped the glove to the hose for a little added security. I might get a fancier hookup, but for now, this works great.
- Prop the machine on 4 bed risers, and use in the tub. With an extension cord it plugs directly into my sink-side outlet. My building has shoddy electrical work, which is why I prop it out of the water.
- When not in use, it sits next to my tub. It's very light to move in and out. I store the hoses and bed risers inside of it.
- I use warm water and powdered detergent. Use *very* little detergent! The clothes do tend to clump in the washer, sadly; I've

So far, so great! I'll try to come back in 6 months or so to update how well it's served me over time.

ETA: One week later, I've found that washing towels leaves them covered in fuzz afterwards, that comes off all over my body. Not sure what to do about this!

title: It does what it is supposed to do
text:
Great little washer. I HIGHLY recommend using the tips and pointers that other reviewers have given in their reviews and videos. I definitely also recommend buying the attachments to hook it up directly to a water source as using a bucket is very tedious and time consuming. The first time I used it I spent hours doing 2 small loads with the bucket method. All of that dumping and refilling using my kitchen sink was sooooo slow. The absolute easiest method is to use it in your bathroom so you can attach it to the shower and drain it directly into the bathtub. You also want to set it up on something higher so it drains easily... otherwise it is a pain to drain. I can wash maybe a third of a regular washers load at once so if you're like me and have children you definitely want to wash clothes every day to avoid that weekend pileup where you will spend the whole day washing clothes in this tiny washer.
That said - I live in a townhome and there is not a washer/dryer hookup so this is perfect for me to avoid the laundromat. I am planning on purchasing an electric portable dryer as the clothes still take several hours to dry and they can be quite stiff - especially jeans - when air drying.

title: The hose they give you does not fit common house hold faucet.
text:
After living in my apartment for years and getting frustrated with either spending $40+ on dry cleaning or washing my loads with the washer and drier that literally was broken all the time with my landlord refusing to replace them, I looked for an alternative answer. I found this bad boy and I was pumped.
I have a very small bathroom and only a stand up shower so I can't really keep it in there but it is small enough where I just keep it in the kitchen next to my apartment size drier (also a brilliant idea)

I must say this machine REALLY does a great job cleaning out the clothes. My husband's clothes are always filled with dirt because he works in fencing and I only really have to wash it once and it gets out A LOOOTTT if not all of the dirt out. For the size of the machine, it fits maybe a few outfits per load. I don't usually put too much in there so it doesn't all bundle together but I can fit 2 pairs of jeans and a couple shirts or like 5 to 6 shirts and some underthings.

The only problems I really have is the hose that they give you is too small to fit on my faucets which is very inconvenient. I do have one of those removable shower hoses which makes it easy to fill the tub but when it comes to rinsing the clothes I have to drain the tub, spin the clothes, fill the tub with clean water and then put the clothes back in to wash the soap off, ( I reuse the water as to not be wasteful) It's a bit of a workout to have to go through all the steps but it does what it needs to over all.

I even tried to get a different hose that was recommended but that was too big. I did see a picture on here that I found to be a brilliant idea, cutting an X at the top of a turkey baster then running the hose, I haven't tried it yet but it looks promising.

Overall I do recommend this if you're looking to save money, (Not so much time because of the reasons above)

title: Great!
text: I needed a washer badly. This was fun and easy to use.

title: LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE IT!
text:
[[VIDEOID:c0fe15609048108f02d0d81a6ae7bdce]] Feb 10, 2022 edit
Still a great washer. It's still going strong and I just got done doing several loads in the washer and it still brings a smile to my face when I do laundry. I have since discovered that the "Normal" wash is normal cycle but "Soft" would be considered the "gentle" cycle. This washer doesn't agitate like normal washers with the quick back and forth agitation but rather a long spin in one direction and then a long one in the other. The gentle "Soft" cycle does the same it just limits the time in the agitation motion to short spin one way and then a short spin in the other. The reason why I mention this is because several of my polyblend shirts will stretch out in the water and get tangled up and I end up with a ball of clothes in my washer. So I wash those separately with other clothes but it's not perfect. I wash, drain, rinse, spin, rinse with softner and then spin again. It takes just a small amount of detergent but I ran out and started using my leftover detergent gel packs. They work just fine and once they are gone then I'll go back to liquid. Overall, still the best darn thing I've purchased next to my countertop dishwasher.

**************************************************
I am a live-in caregiver to my elderly mother in a senior citizen apartment complex. We live in a one bedroom apartment in which we have no washer/dryer hookups, but we do have a laundry room on the first floor all the way in the front of the complex opposite of us. Because of covid I have stopped using the laundry room (or laundromat) especially since a lot of seniors here don't wear masks and we have indoor hallways.

I was washing our clothes by hand in big muck buckets with a laundry plunger but that was an ALL DAY JOB just for a few things and it took forever for our clothes to dry on the rack because I couldn't wring all the water out of the clothes. I decided I had enough and when we got our stimulus money I bought this washer. OMG this thing is a complete game changer!

I cannot stress how much easier this machine is making my life as we have clean clothes all the time and I can do several loads a day with ease. The spinner, some call it a spin dryer but it's actually there to wring or spin all the water from the clothes just like a regular washer, spins the clothes so well that there are actually dry spots on the clothes when it's done. I'm not saying it's completely dry because it isn't, but what I am saying is the 9 hours it took me to dry our clothes before when I was handwashing them now only take about 30 minutes.

I set the washer in my bathtub, I use a rubber mat under it to ease the vibrations and slippage if any as well as I have to use a sponge on one corner of the machine to make it more stable, then I set my dryer rack in the living room where I have ceiling and regular fans to circulate air around the clothes.

Oh there's a lint trap built in that by golly does a great job of catching lint, hair, pet fur and whatnot. I clean it out each time I wash. I love this machine...I'm so happy I got it.

title: Good, but sometimes temperamental.
text:
I've been using this A LOT for about 2 months now... It does pretty well. After reading the reviews and then using it, I think I see where some people are going wrong.

1.) Burning smell from washer or spinner when using? You've probably overloaded it. The only time I had that issue was when I accidently overloaded it.

2.) Spinner won't work? Possibly too heavy of clothing. Some clothes hold way more water than others, such as Micro-fleece. Try slightly wringing them out then try again. Sometimes you may need to reach inside and pull GENTLY up while rotating counterclockwise if a heavy load has pushed it down too far and it won't spin.

3.) Spinner still won't work? The safety shutoff mechanism in the lid has... "issues". Sometimes it won't catch right and the spinner won't start. Try shutting the lid a few times (GENTLY) while holding on to it and pushing VERY LIGHTLY towards the back as you do so. Sometimes and slight alignment adjustment may need to be made by pushing slightly right or left as you're lowering. We're talking millimeters here. I will try to post a video of the lid adjustments and issues.

It helps to have a little bit of mechanical knowledge and understanding when using this washer because issues will arise.
But, overall, it's a good purchase and worth the money.

title: Works Well
text: You are able to wash and rise items well. Machine is easy to clean inside and out. Spin water out of items nicely. Inlet hose doesn't fix standard faucet. My Baby, told me about this washer and spinner an I thank her! Videos on Amazon and YouTube are helpful, if you're in need of additional information or want to see how it works. Oh, don't over load machine.

title: Probably the most life-changing $100 I've ever spent
text:
I bought this because I moved to a third-floor apartment with no elevator and didn't want to deal with hauling laundry up the stairs. It seemed crazy to think you could get a suitable washine machine for $100 - and I thought the delivery would be a hassle. It arrived in just a few days, and it's a fairly light machine, so it wasn't too hard for me to haul it up to my apartment.

As so many others have mentioned, the big hassle is figuring out how to hook it up. I have space in my kitchen, but that didn't seem like it would work for draining. I didn't want to put it on a counter. I put it in a bathroom, and while the room is fairly small, there's just enough space to keep the machine stored in there. I put it in the tub to use it. Initially I was using a bucket to fill it, but that was kind of a hassle. Today I found a funnel that fits perfectly on the input end of the hose. It's the large funnel in the OXO 3-piece set. I bought it at Target, but they have it on Amazon too. You can attach it tightly enough that the funnel will stay attached to the hose even with high water pressure. This wouldn't work with my bathtub faucet because the hose goes up to the top of the machine. I used it with my shower and it worked well. I don't take showers in this bathroom, so the next step is to find a way to attach the funnel to the shower head so that I don't have to hold it up there. EDIT: I used a zip tie to attach the funnel to the shower head. This works well as long as I'm careful about not using too much water pressure. I don't use this shower, so I can leave it in place all the time, but it also would be easy to just turn the funnel out of the way to take a shower.

I was surprised by the frequent starting and stopping of the wash cycle, but apparently this is normal. I haven't yet figured out the exact right amount of clothing to put in. I think I put in too much one time, and the clothes came out with some detergent streaks on them. I washed them again in smaller loads and it all came out. So this seems to wash clothes pretty well. I bought an Amazon-branded drying rack, and it accommodates about the same amount of clothing that I can fit in the machine.

An important thing to think about if you're switching to this machine from a laundromat is how to deal with drying your clothes and handling wrinkling. I hate ironing and don't want to deal with that. I bought some kind of Downy spray that's supposed to take out wrinkles, but so far I haven't needed to use it. I've been putting fabric softener in and my clothes have been been wearable after drying on the rack. I've only washed one towel so far and it was too stiff. I'm not sure yet whether I'll buy a dryer. So far stiffness and wrinkles aren't as big a problem as I anticipated.

title: Great for any kind of stain

title: No more back breaking hand washing clothes.
text: I live in a small apartment with my two children.  My health, as well as my income, is not very good.  Having to go the laundromat is task that I would put off as long as possible.  I have been washing clothes in the kitchen sink, but the detergent often makes my hands burn and it takes 3-4 days for the clothes to dry.  I stumbled upon this item one day on Amazon.com and read the reviews and watched a few videos.  I figured, at a 100 bucks, it would pay for itself in 1 month.  As stated by other reviewers, it can be difficult to find a good place to put it and hook it up to a water source.  I was going to build a platform, but I found a better solution for the time being.  I place it on the kitchen counter and use a step stool to put the clothes in.  I purchased a SharkBite 1/2"x1/2"FNPT straight connector (swivel) from HomeDepot.  After removing the rubber piece from the end of the washer fill tube, I popped the brass fitting in it's place.  Next, I unscrewed the plastic head/handle from the sprayer next to my kitchen sink, with that removed I popped the other end of the brass fitting into the sprayer line.  Voila!  Now I can place the other end of the fill tube as needed on the washing/spinning tub inlets.  Yes, the washer is way off the floor and I have to stick by it, but I don't have to fill it up with a bucket anymore, AND I am able to rinse the clothes as needed during the spinning cycle.  GRANTED - for large items like blankets, etc. I will still have to make a trip to the laundromat- but these types of items never fit very well in my old washing machine anyway.

Cord is nice and long. Cons: the owners manuel is terrible. Extremely small print and misspelled words and sentences that don't make sense. Basically, figure it out on your own without it. The drain hose is VERY short and VERY flimsy. It's pretty much junk. The fill hose isen't much better. I looked the company up for customer service and it seems their suggestion for replacement parts is to go to your hardware store. I wished I would have looked them up besides on here before I bought this item. They are not accredited with the bbb and have terrible reviews for customer service. I guess if you need a longer hose or a replacement part you are on your own.

title: *UPDATED AGAIN!
text:
UPDATED 12-18-19!
still abusing this washer. Hot water for almost everything depending on the fabric.

***Update***

I've been using the hottest water possible from the sink. I use powder HE powder mostly because I pay 40 bucks for 80lbs of detergent (yes really! Brand is called Boardwalk, 18 lbs lasted over year for this washer if you measure detergent accurately for this machine.) no problems for me, just manually loading and draining the washer manually is a daunting task. but it's worth it in a smaller appartment. if mine broke tomorrow I'm buying another one, unless I find a bigger washer.

title: Received defective product. Dryer is too loud
This little workhorse outshines my HE machine
text:
I love this little beast! I have a laundry room in our finished basement, but wanted something small for the first floor to wash small loads that I have been doing by hand. I rarely use my big machine or dryer any longer because even with our household if 6, this takes care of everything better than our full sized machine. I have even taught our 4 young boys to use it and we will be purchasing a second for the second floor bathroom. They each have their own drying racks in their bedrooms that are folded away when not in use. My laundry days have become so much easier. Everyone gets their own day of the week to do their laundry and can have it done in an hour. We are saving so much money with this machine.
It doesn't wear out the clothes like our HE machine does. We reuse our wash water for 2 to 3 loads, so that saves on water. We hardly ever use the dryer anymore, huge electric savings there. And it saves tons of time. We put shirts right on the hangers to dry and don't have to mess with them again.
The spin dryer gets rid of so much water that most things are dry in an hour. I'm so very impressed. I'm just hoping it lasts. Even if it only lasts 6 months, it will more than paid for itself in savings of both time and money.
The biggest reason that I love our portable washing machine is because it actually gets things clean, I mean totally clean.
Update: I've purchased 2 of these 5 years ago for just under $107 each. I'm here to replace 1 because the spin dryer motor seized up. I absolutely love them. They cut down on bills; water, sewer, and electric. I still have my super-sized washer, but rarely use it. Highly recommend, even at the new price. Still totally worth it.

title: It’s good
text:
My girlfriend and I really like this washer. Washing clothes is easy. We don’t use a hose to fill it up. We just use a 3.5 gallon bucket from Target.

Can even wash our queen sheets in here (but not the comforter).

This machine is oddly satisfying it washes well, and the spin dryer works surprisingly well too. We hang up the clothes, and they’re dry pretty quick.

All in all, we like and recommend this washer dryer combo.

title: Workhorse
text: I've owned this since December 2016. One of my best purchases ever. You do have to elevate it to drain it. We keep ours in the bathroom elevated next to the tub wall so the hose can easily drain there. We fill it using the extended shower head. The hose that this washing machine comes with for filling it with water must have been made with another country/location in mind because no one out here seems to have a tap that fits to it. At first I was filling it using that rubber attachment you can buy that's advertised for washing pets or your hair. I was attaching that to my kitchen sink to fill the washing machine. That was great. The only problem was I didn't want to keep draining into the large bucket and then lifting and emptying the bucket. That's when I moved the machine to the bathroom. It's simpler cause I don't have to be so eyes on. Washing laundry has become much easier since it's right in our home. The machine is a work horse. I take care of it, keep it clean and check the wires once in a while. I also have to keep the drain hose from getting mildewy. To top it all off, it wasn't even an expensive investment.

title: LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this washer!!!
text: This washer I was very skeptical about.  Well it is great! It is very powerful and gets clothes so clean.  It washes one large sheet, about five shirts, mabe two pair of jeans.  The spinner doesn't hold as much but it's no problem spinning a few at a time.  It spins so good the clothes take no time to dry.  You have to elevate it to get it to drain, so I put it on top of a plastic storage tub and it worked great.  It drains really fast.  I highly recommend this washer it's fantastic.

title: Best apt size washing machine
text:
I don’t know where to begin .... this washer is the best thing I’ve purchased in a very long time. It pays for its self over and over.
I brought this over three months ago and is still working perfectly ... some advice is not to stuff it .. I’ve put about three pairs of jeans depending on the size and four shirts and clothes came out clean every time . This is a great machine for an apt . I just place in my tub and wash then it drain right in the tub. I would just recommend a drainer to catch any dirt or lent so your pipes don’t get clogged . The spinner part works so well that it only takes about two hours for the clothes to dry Three hours for jeans . title: I really HATE this little piece of junk
text: I really HATE this little piece of junk...but it does have a couple of attributes, so I gave it a bonus star. Before you order this...know that it is TOTALLY MANUAL. I put it on my back porch so I could MANUALLY lie the drain hose down to drain.  You have to MANUALLY add wash and rinse water.  I use a hose connected to the kitchen sink. No cycle...you must MANUALLY turn on wash, and turn on wash again to rinse...then spin. To drain, you must unhook the drain hose and lie it down...no pump. The bonus star is for the strong agitator and the strong spinner. It gets clothes clean, and clothes dry quickly due to good spinner....but you must dedicate your time to the entire process. If you have the time and patience...go for it.

text:
Perfect for small spaces. Does require a little bit more work than a fully automatic washer, but wasn’t a deal breaker for me. It uses very little water and soap to do a load and the spin dryer is AMAZING. I live in a very humid place and hang drying clothes usually takes a few days. The spin dryer gets so much water out my jeans dry over night!
My only complaints are: it needs a longer inlet hose, a backup filter(or a way to order one, and better instruction booklet(I wanted to clean the inside of the washer and spin dryer).

title: A washer your Mom or Grandma would love!
text: I bought this six months ago and I recommend it wholeheartedly! Can'take beat it for the price. Cleans great. Not for lazy people! Save on soap and you control how well it does or doesn't do. I think my Grandma would have loved this as well as my Mom! It still washes great but the spin dryer does not run now and that is a big ding for me to give it. People who buy this expect a year's worth of service life out of all it's operating feature so I can no longer reccomend it wholeheartedly. If I buy another one I will have that concern. Hmmmm!

title: Washing is great, rinsing is terrible.
text: This little machine washes clothes really well, but it takes a lot of extra work to get the detergent rinsed out of the clothes. Towels are even more difficult. I would recommend this for an emergency type use, but not the machine to do all the laundry. I'd rather take my laundry to a laundry mat and get it all done in 2-3 hours with minimal work vs 3-5 hours of constantly changing out, rinsing, and basically hand rinsing the entire load over & over until there is minimal soap suds. The functionality of the machine works great, the multiple rinse cycles and hand switching the load in & out is where I don't have that kind of time.

title: If you keep up with your laundry, and don't have tons of clothes or large items, it's pretty great
text:
We attached it, put it on top of, and secured it with screws to an old entertainment center thing that has wheels which is about a foot and a half high. The hose for filling it doesn't attach to any of our faucets and it's really short and flimsy, so we have to fill it by hand with a bucket and it takes several bucket fulls. Technically half bucket fulls, because a full bucket is too heavy and spills everywhere.
Had to stand it next to the toilet and attach a rock to the end of the drain hose for weight so it doesn't flail around and it drains into the toilet. I was told it has to be high enough to be able to drain. And this was the only way to have that work and still be able to reach it, I'm 5'1". It washed really well, have to run one wash cycle with detergent and fabric softener for the longest setting, then drain, then fill with water completely again and then do a short cycle, like 6 minutes, With clean water. You can see how dirty your clothes actually are! And how clean they're going to be because of all the dirt coming off and draining away.
So you definitely want to do a whole nother cycle with just water to rinse everything off. The spin cycle gets clothes almost dry. But basically one wash load takes 3 spin dry cycles so you have to find a place to leave the wet washed clothes while you're spinning them in batches. If you're doing multiple loads that is, and want to keep it going. Doesn't take too long to dry after they have been spun 2x. I wish it was a little easier. But it is great and will take some getting used to. I'm sure we will figure it out and get better at it. We are both disabled. And going to the laundromat is just a pain. Hopefully this will get easier. I had thought we could put it into the bathtub but my friend who set it up for us said it's a gravity drain. And it won't drain properly if it's not high up enough. It is also pretty heavy for us. But so is lifting several buckets of water. So I'm mixed on how I feel about it. I still have to go to the laundromat for stuff. Like blankets, and similar items. Stuff gets spun pretty dry, but then it's sort of wrinkled. Because remember, it's not a clothes dryer. Then I have to hang everything up for a while, then take it all down, and iron what needs ironing, and get it out of the bathroom. A lot of steps.

title: Better than expected
text: I just got the washer, so I've only used it once, but it really blew me away with how efficient and quiet it is. The washer part is really powerful and got the clothes clean, the spinner really gets the job done and is barely audible. At first it wobbled a lot during spinning, but I figured out it's either my bathroom floor or the feet on the washer that are uneven. It was an easy fix. The water inlet hose is useless, I'm guessing it's designed for faucets in its origin country (China). I used a bucket to fill the washer, I'm gonna have to get some sort of adapter. I had it sitting on the floor, but almost all the water drained just fine into a bucket next to the washer. The power cord is suprisingly long, from what other reviews said I expected a super short cord, but it reaches all the way across my small bathroom. As for the spinner, I let it run for five minutes and the clothes are almost dry. Very impressed!  Be sure to only use a tiny bit of detergent, and I mean tiny, as the washer produces lots of suds. Bottom line, so far I love this washer, it's much better than expected. It loses points for the completely useless manual that is impossible to read, whoever wrote the manual clearly does not speak any English, and also for the water inlet hose. There is also some flexible disc thingie the washer came with, but it doesn't tell me where to put it or how to use it or really what it's for. Everything else on the machine is pretty self explanatory.

title: Great so far with the exception of...
text:
Positives: This little machine is a wonder. It gets clothes cleaner in less time than a standard machine. A couple of things to be careful of: (1) Make sure when filling the machine on both wash and rinse that the center knob is turned to "Normal" and the hose is engaged on the hook on the side of the machine (up) when filling; (2) after rinsing and draining, leave the drain knob on when spinning; and (3) do NOT overload the spinner. It will only take about half of the load and does a great job. May require rebalancing the clothes. Clothes are spun well and just damp. I found that a 1" (outside diameter) PVC pipe will fit into the drain hose to lengthen it. I added another length of pipe to that with a PVC connector to lengthen it more until I can figure out exactly how I want it to drain. I've done about six loads in this machine in the last few days, and really am very pleased. Expect a bit of a learning curve. Be careful about how full it is filled. I have just used it about halfway. The agitator is pretty strong. Also, very, very little detergent is needed.

Negatives: (1) The sink end of the fill hose fits nothing; (2) the power cord is too short; and (3) the drain hose is much, much too short. This needs to come with an adapter for sink attachment for filling and either a longer attached drain hose and/or an extension to the existing hose; thus, the four stars instead of five. I found that for me it really was too heavy to be lifting in and out of a tub. However, it slides easily so if it is able to be slid to somewhere where it can drain, that would work.

title: Great little machine!!

I'm a big guy so I can't do very big loads, but it saves me time and money. I like the fact that I can wash clothes whenever I want. Only thing that I have to agree with, with everyone else is the cheap hose the give you to connect to your sink. It's ridiculous. Whoever thought this was okay should be fired! Lol! I just used a empty water jug to fill it up and placed the machine up on a old shoe rack that I wasn't using so I can make sure I can drain out all the water. Anyway, so far so good. I also bought the three year warranty. Hopefully won't need it, but good to have. I'll update this in a couple weeks and let you know.

title: Great little machine
text: I live in an area that gets a lot of rain; we have a septic system that is easily overloaded when the ground is saturated. I can't wash clothes for days. I got this machine as a gift bc I needed a way to stay ahead of the dirty laundry and this machine does the trick. It can handle small to medium loads of laundry.  I can easily transport it myself to our porch, fill the washer using a hose, get the wash done and drain it off my porch.  It spins everything dry enough for my dryer in under 2 minutes. That spin cycle is something.  I was able to do jeans and towels as long as I didn't overload it.  It doesn't, of course, have the capacity of my large washer but for emergency situations, this is quite adequate.  It's really not for heavily soiled items but if you live in an apartment, have a small family, or just need something in a fix, this is the machine for you.

title: Amazing product!!!
text:
Being a single parent and on a budget, going to the local laundromat to wash clothes was not cost efficient at all. Spending over ten dollars to wash and dry, a few loads of colthes and blankets was quickly adding up! Not to mention finding the time to get to there.

I bought this unit not looking for a miracle, but a solution to my problem... washing the clothing that my family of four had and trying to save money. This product thus far is doing just that!

I wash at least three loads of clothes ( jeans, shirts, socks, delicates, shorts and dresses) and small basic house goods ( towels, sheets, pillow cases, small throw blankets) twice a week. Using a bucket I fill my washer; always making sure to check my load size and the appropriate fill line in the machine. I use less liquid detergent than in a full sized washer and am sure not to use hot water. Depending on the load, I set it to wash for a minimum of 9 minutes to the full 15 minutes. I drain all the water out at the end of the cycle, and then fill the unit with fresh water to rinse for at least 5 minutes. * Always be sure to set the unit back to 'Normal ' or 'Soft' after you finish drain and before you start refilling with fresh water!!! If not the unit will spray water out from the drain hose when you start the machine!

One of the best aspects of the unit is the spinner! I usually only place a few items in at a time and spin for 2 minutes. The full 5 minutes is great for heavy items such as jeans or towels. Be sure they are leveled correctly, so that the unit does not start becoming off balance ( you will hear the sound difference when this occurs). When the items come out of the spinner they are almost completely dry. This makes hang drying easier or in my case placing them into my small Panda dryer a quick dry!!!

I love my portable washer! It hopefully will last for some time to come, with proper use and care.

text:
Works great! Can be a hassle to deal with sometimes but I suppose it would be easier if I had a little more space in my apartment. It works GREAT and washes the clothes very well. The whole process from start to finish takes around 20-25 minutes if you do the process like it says. I wish the spin dryer was larger but I am extremely pleased with this product for the money. I was spending almost $10 a week at the laundromat and wasting time there, and now I can do it at home while I do other stuff around the house. It is worth the money!

Just let it do its thing and the load balances out within a few seconds!
