title: Works great.
text:
I love, love, love my Giantex washer and dryer. I've had it for a few months now and I use it EVERY DAY! Because of my schedule, I only wash one load a day. It definitely takes some work and effort, more than a normal washer and dryer. I use a large size, Home Depot bucket to fill the washer up with water. The outlet and inlet cord for water is just not long enough for how my apartment is set up. It definitely took some trial and error on how I could use it comfortable in my home. Some people who reviewed the Giantex kept theirs in their bathroom. I just was not able to do that with my two little kids, 4 years old and 6 months.
To be safe as possible and to have somewhere to let the water out to drain, I chose my living room right by my sliding glass door and patio. Any time I want to drain I just open my sliding glass door and it drains right outside. I just have to walk my bucket of water to and from the kitchen.
All in all IT WORKS! Having little kids, washing clothes is inevitable. I feel so much comfortable being able to wash clothes in my own home.
The dryer is more of a spin dryer. Depending on the fabric you are washing, it may dry completely and may not. I had to buy a dry rack and an electric dryer seperately.
Hope you enjoy like have.

title: I have had it 16 months now.  Working great in my small apartment. Saves me money and time.  :-)
text:
This little machine has been saving me money and time. No more dragging everything to the basement. Hoping for the one machine for 12 apartments. The $40 bucks for the full month just to have clean clothes! Manufacturer shipper and it was here fast.

Now the product. I got a coupon in the box $10 off their website. I was having a lot of lint. The clothes were not soft. Because I was just hanging them up. After some time I went to their website and shopped for a dryer.
But back to washer. You can wash about 1/2 the size of a washer. Plus the spin side does a great job getting the water out. The weakest part on the washer machine looks to be the lint trap. Mine has NOT broken. But it looks cheap. I don't know if I could get another. But they sell the ones you can just drop in the washer. For $1 but $8 for shipping. I didn't order it.
The washer is holding up fine. I picked up a 3-year warranty to be safe.
I am single and it just me. But it's nice not to have to go somewhere to do your wash. The machine downstairs broke down but got my money. Dragging my soaping clothes out to the car to go down the road. I just wasn't happy in the cold weather. The washer is sitting on my bathroom sink. I have it draining into my sink. I fill it with a handheld showerhead that I installed. I use a hair tie around the head and an S hook to hold it to the washer to fill. Works for me. If overfilled it just drains as you fill it.
Oh, It manual you have to wash (15 minutes ) the load drain it. Fill it back up with softener and run raise cycle ( 15 Minutes. ) The spin side is 5 minutes. Load evenly.
Okay - Machine is lite you can move it around. But there is no pump to drain it. I see it as I don't have that to break down.
Well, I hope this helps.

title: Update : 6 months later and still worked great!
text:
I spent along time researching this product before buying it. I’ve had it for over a month, and am very happy with it. It’s convenient, works well, and compact. What I wish was different about the design is the gravity drain, the quality of the hoses, and the inability to completely drain with a separate port. Plan on purchasing a separate hose, and make sure you’ve got space to put this up on something, like a bench. The gravity drain won’t work unless this machine is up high. Well worth the price, so far.
UPDATE: I’ve had this for half the summer and it’s already paid for itself in quarters and detergent.
I also have cleaner clothes and a more organized closet, because I’m not disconnected from my clothing. What I wear, I see and I wash myself. This is a machine, but it’s also a manual job. How? You’re not just throwing in your clothes and walking away. It doesn’t work like that. You’ve got to be discerning about what you’re going to wear, which informs the amount of laundry you must do. It’s a very good thing. I have a nice system set up and wish I had bought this years ago. No more laundromat for me, thank heavens. I’ve updated my rating to five glorious gold stars. I thought this would break on me, or not work. It hasn’t and it hasn’t. I’m very grateful.

title: Worked for almost one year
text:
I loved how it worked! It lasted for about 11 months of regular use. I did maybe two loads a week, sometimes I would fall behind and do three or four loads in a week. It could handle linens also- one set of microfiber wires sheets at a time or three towels. This week it started running the washer without the timer being on and there was a burning smell coming from it. Overall worth it, I was hoping it would last a little longer. It definitely saved me money in trips to the laundromat.

Tips I’ve learned while using it:
- definitely need a secondary option to catch the lint or it will end up clogging your pipes. I went with the wire mesh lint catcher that you can attach to the drain hose
- if you have pets their hair kind of lingers on your clothes after washing. I got a pack of agitator balls which helped get the hair off a lot.
- the hose won’t attach to your plumbing. I came up with taking my shower head off, cutting a latex balloon open and using that to attach the hose that came with it to where my shower head attaches.
-always spin dry heavy things (like towels) on their own if at all. I never did my sheets in the spin dryer because I like how they feel air dried. Towels will feel kind of ‘crunchy’ if you don’t spin dry.

title: Easy to use, clothes get clean and some items almost completely dry!
text:
Honestly a lot quieter than I expected! I can't hear this over my RV AC. It washes the clothes well and we've actually been having cleaner clothes than when borrowing a large regular washer. We couldn't get the inlet hose to fit any of our faucets so this is how our process goes:
1. Move machine into the tub/shower, stick shower hose in the washer side and set to soft. Turn water on and fill til about 1 - 2 inches above the clothes.
2. Add soap and wash on desired time. Drain and set back to soft. Fill tub again to rinse extra soap off but also add softener to the water. Run for a few minutes. Drain
3. Move small amounts of items into the spin dryer and spin about 3min each tiny load. Clothes are ready to dry!
It's really easy to use, so far haven't had any issues and I've run it like mad for these first few days that we've had it. Hoping it holds up well but we'll update if anything changes! If no update then all is well

title: The worst manual EVER
text:
Okay, so this washer is actually pretty darned good. I've been using it for about six weeks, and I'm not disappointed with it. It's light enough that I can put it in the bathtub without hurting myself. I wouldn't recommend it for anyone who has mobility issues, but a middle aged not athletic woman can pick it up, so kudos. The spin basket is great, the main compartment is about 2/3s the size of a standard washing machine. I can wash my complete set of queen-sized sheets and have room for a few extra pairs of socks. But this has the literal worst manual that I've ever seen. If you've never used this style of washing machine and are looking for guidance? Sorry bud, you're out of luck. I'm usually pretty good with manuals, but this was translated by somebody who learned about five minutes worth of English by watching Teletubbies. Some of the mistranslations are comprehensible and even fun. I'm especially fond of: "after use, please firstly unplug the power cord from the electrical outlet in order to avoid thunderbolt" which at least is all real words and you know what they mean (though I was hoping for Thor to show up, I'm not gonna lie).

But seriously, it's a good little machine, it's just that the manual makes almost no sense. I would have no idea how to use it if it wasn't for other kind Amazon reviewers who've written up their experiences.

text: I was getting really tired of doing my laundry by hand, especially since I don't have a lot of strength in my hands for wringing water out of my wet clothes. This mini washer does a great job! It is a little bit labor intensive, but I'm pretty pleased with it.

title: Neat little washer.
text:
This machine is the manual transmission of washing machines. Even so, it will change your life. How amazing to do laundry at home after going to the laundromat for years!!

As other reviewers have noted, the hose system has some major flaws. (The hose is actually completely useless.) I was too impatient to go the hardware store for a DIY hose-repair project, and filling the tub with a bucket works just fine.

If you're going to go with the bucket method, I would recommend dumping a full bucket of water on the clothes in the spin tub and then immediately turning on the spinner to rinse. Do that a couple times until the water coming out the bottom is no longer soapy. Rinsing in the wash tub seemed to take too many drain-and-refill cycles. Also, use about a quarter as much soap as you think you'll need. Getting the soap off was the trickiest part of the whole operation.

Some of the questions about the washer express concerns about the lack of a drain pump - I had absolutely no problem. Set the washer in the bathtub and the water drains right out. You don't need a pump.

The capacity is surprisingly large. I found that I could fit about half a regular size load in the wash tub, and about 1/3 of that in the spin tub. The spinner only takes 3-4 minutes, so it's not a terrible inconvenience to split the load up to "dry." Next day edit: I actually washed a queen size comforter in the wash tub. Had to take it downstairs to the community dryer to dry, but washing worked wonderfully.

Final note - you'll need a large clothes drying rack. The clothes come out damp-dry, but they still need a few hours on the drying rack. I originally bought the AmazonBasics Foldable Drying Rack - White, and after one day of laundry I've decided to purchase a more industrial size rack.

title: Great little washer!

title: Will save you money from going to the laundry mat
text:
Ok so I've been using this for 3 years as my apartment doesn't have washer dryer hook ups and I needed something that will allow me to do my clothes at home without spending 10 to 20 bucks a week at a laundry mat.

I use it in my bathtub and have a shower head that I can pull down to use to fill up the washer. It needs to come with a hose cleaner for when it empties out because mine is pretty dirty and I try to clean it.

I have 2 dogs and I reccomend getting a reusable lint roller because the dog hair covers my clothes. But that's where a dryer helps with that.

title: Cost effective, powerful, and lightweight!
text: I didn't want to write a review until I had used this for a month or so, and it's been almost a month and a half. You do need an adapter for the water hose, but not a big deal. I use mine on the kitchen sink since it's right across from the baby room, and where I hang all of my laundry to dry. Someone mentioned that it tears holes in their clothes, but just know that if you have delicate items, just use a delicate wash bag and those will be safe. The regular agitates clothes very strongly, and the delicate setting is more like a regular wash. Much stronger than I anticipated, and perfect for washing cloth diapers. With heavy soiled diapers I fill water for a 2nd time and wash again, and it gets just about all of the stains out unless they're white elastic. We live in an apartment, so it's perfect for a 3 person household. Just a tablespoon of liquid per size of cycle. Small =1tbsp, medium =2tbsp, large =3tbsp. The spin dryer almost completely drys certain clothes, and any other clothes dry in 2 hours when hung to dry. The only thing I would suggest is that maybe they could add a base under where the drain hose is so it's higher to drain into a bucket. Cost effective, and powerful.

It worked fine at the beginning but there were some inconveniences. The hose that drains is located at the bottom so its difficult to drain out the water unless its elevated higher. I also had to bring a bucket in order to drain the water because my apartments bathroom is so small that it doesnt fit in there. So now I put the machine top of table and walk back and forth from the bathroom to the machine to fill and drain water. Its a workout.... -.-

Things went very bad VERY quickly. I had the machine for about 2 months. One day, while it was washing my clothes, the machine was shaking so much that it eventually reached the surface of the table and fell. The machine broke instantly and the hose was teared up! Water was draining out and thus my whole floor was flooded.

I asked for a refund of some sort or to help send in a hose replacement for the machine but havent heard back from them for 3 days. So I filed a report about it and amazon said that the refund cant be issued. So much for customer service....

I lost $99 and felt so stupid in buying this. They are selling this for $106 now... pshh screw that! Not buying this ever again......waste of money.

title: My one year review and what I've learned...
text:
After about a year of use I've learned a few things...
*note*..I use this machine in my tub with a bath mat under it for cushioning. After many experiments I find this to be the most convenient for me.
1) Put some kind of filter at the end of the drain hose. Maybe a piece of hose or tights attached with a rubber band. You'll want to catch all the lint that the small filter inside misses. Yes there is quite a bit of lint not caught. You do not want that going into your septic or your pipes. Even if you use a bucket and pour the water in the drainage system somehow. I use a few types of filters I purchased off Amazon and put them together to make one filter and tie it on with a zip tie. One is mesh and the other is a metal material. I make a 'filter condom' so to speak.
2) Removing and cleaning the small filter inside the machine in between loads will help with lint catching.
3) The spinner will wear out before the washer side does. Mine I've noticed is starting to wear out already. It doesn't want to stop spinning sometimes when the lid is open. It's supposed to automatically stop right away for safety.
4) A little laundry goes a long way. Do not overload the washer or spinner. A little soap goes a long way. You only need to use a small amount.
5) The hose that comes with the machine...unless you can get very creative and make some kind of contraption that will make it fit on your sink or shower hose connection..throw it away.
6) It is a good idea to have an indoor/outdoor extension cord. That way if you find yourself washing outdoors you can plug it into a power source. I personally prefer one that can be used both inside and out.
7) This machine is not heavy and is very portable. Easy to use when I need it. To me this washer is only used when I can't to the regular washer and dryer that is upstairs from where I live, so I don't use it all the time.
8) I've decided that when this machine goes I'll probably invest in something different. I don't see myself buying this again. Time to get my research on.

title: You need a drain low to the floor or build a platform for the unit to sit on!
text:
I use this in my 5th wheel and use my solar system to power it.
It’s small and compact, runs 15 min. Wash cycle ( at about ~8 gal./load) and then you transfer it to the centrifugal “dryer” , for 1-6 minutes, which does a good job. Then I place the items back in the washer with rinse water and repeat the process.
So it looks like this:
Wash 3-15 min. Transfer to centrifugal for 1-6 min.
Then
Rinse for 3-15 min. Transfer to centrifugal for 1-6 min.
Hang items to air dry.
The instructions are fairly typical of China made items. Not the easiest to read... you figure out as you go and hope it doesn’t break.
As for quality...... it seems to be built quite sturdy for being all plastic.
Have an awesome day exploring life!!

title: FANTASTIC, SMALL WONDER!

All the advice, about putting the circle on snuggly on the clothes, when in the spinner, is absolutely accurate.  I really love it, it is easy to move and as long as you are sure to clean the filter, after each use, most will get maximum use out of this.  Don't hesitate--it might be the best item you purchase in a long time!  It is a real treat.  Thank you, Giantex, for making such a cool, little machine!  Also, for suspicious readers, I waited and used this machine for over a month before writing this review.  I have done 15 loads before writing this review.

title: Washer/dryer
text:
This thing is pretty cool. I use mine on my back patio and put the hose onto the grass and it works perfect. Cord is very short, so I do have to use an extension cord. And the “faceplate” given for the dryer portion cracked after like three uses, but it’s still working while cracked. I have been recommending this to my friends who also live in apartments. Definitely worth the $200+.
Will buy again!

title: A useful device
text: OK, I waited several weeks before offering a review. I have run at least 50 loads. I feel like I have almost paid for it, since my prior option was the laundry mat. Its a nifty device. But it is not a real washing machine and dryer. Its a washing helper. Here is how I use it: I keep in it in the corner in the bathroom. When I use it, I pick it up and put it in the bathtub. That makes it easy to fill using a two gallon bucket, and easy to drain.  I do not use the filling tube, as that would take too long. I put about seven gallons in. I use just a little detergent. I might add a tad of color fast bleach. I just did a load, I put seven short sleeve shirts and four boxer shorts in there. I could have put a little more. It says not to, but I use hot water. I turn it on at first for just a few seconds to get everything mixed with suds, then I let it sit for 15 minutes. When I come back, the water has cooled a little. Then I turn it on. The unit vigorously churns the water, but unless you are doing just underwear or something, the clothes tend to ball up at the bottom of the tank. I usually stand there and manually pull the clothes out of the ball between churning cycles.  Its not at all dangerous.  I churn things for like five minutes, then turn it off and let everything soak for ten more minutes or so. I might manually push stuff down and around with my hand during that time. Then I drain the water. Usually I squeeze the water out of the clothes when it is draining because I want as much soapy water gone as possible. Then I add about seven gallons of cold water and manually churn stuff around for a couple minutes with my hand to get all the soap out of the clothes. I could turn the machine on to do that, and sometimes I do, but then I have to pull the clothes out of the ball. Its easier to just slosh it around by hand for a couple minutes. Then I drain the water. I like to fill the spinner side with as much stuff as possible, so I hand squeeze some of the water out of the clothes as I pull them out of the washer section. I spin the clothes for like 3 minutes which seems to be enough to get most of the water out of them.  In the end, after drying on a hanger for a couple hours, my shirts turn out pretty good. Not the same as using a real dryer, mind you, but pretty good. Some shirts do better than others, and those that end up wrinkled, I iron. I am happy with my device. It requires a little more effort than just throwing the clothes in the washing machine and coming back in 30 minutes, but then it requires no coins or travel to the laundry mat, either. The unit seems well built and I expect it to pay for itself many times over. A good value. Glad I bought it.

title: It’s a beast. I’m in love.
text: You won’t regret this purchase. It’s fabulous and the spinner gets small loads close to dry. You will be shocked how much water shoots out during the spin process. By far my favorite step in the process. It’s fabulous. Give it a try!

title: Received defective unit

I didn't turn it upside down to look at the bottom until I already tried filling it with water, which promptly leaked out from everywhere but the drain hose. There are some small cracks in the bottom plastic section as well as it being utterly useless as it leaks. It is unfortunate that I got a defective unit. I don't believe it is very common.

title: Too good for the price

title: Works great!
text:
It agitates one way then the other. No need to hook it up to water. I fill it with a garden hose. The spinner is fantastic.
I have a septic and do not want to use bleach in my regular washer. I use this outside and drain it into the yard. I have not been able to remove the filter. I will get an assist on getting it out.

title: Satisfied customer
text:
This is the second unit I ordered. The first unit did not arrive, and had to process as a missing delivery. Not a problem, but took a few weeks to process between Amazon, Costway and Fedex. The replacement second order went smoothly and arrived as expected. It took a short while to understand the setup and proper running. The manual was poorly written and very small print.

I set it up in my bathtub on a couple of heavy duty plastic milk crates. This arrangement put it at the right height and avoided the unit sitting in draining water. The setup can be a little shaky when the spinning starts, but it stabilizes when it gets up to speed.

I have run about a dozen loads so far, and it operates as a champ. Both the washing and spinning work really well. The spinner capacity is about 1/2 the size of the washing tub, so every wash load requires 2 spin cycles. Total wash & spin cycles take about 25-30 minutes. It is not completely silent, but not noisy either. Most of the sound comes from the vibrations into the metal tub it is resting on. The cord extends only 2-3 feet from the machine, so you may require an extension cord as I do.

title: I love this washing machine
text: I love this washing machine! It gets the job done really well. I live alone in an apartment and so, this is perfect for me. The clothes will wash clean if you don't overload the machine. The tube that connects to a faucet to get water in the machine has a small opening; I just fill the machine up with buckets of water (about 2 and a half). The clothes come out a little damp from the spin cycle, but mostly dry. You can just hang them out for a few hours for them to finish drying.

title: Lifesaver
text: I’ve had this washer for over a year now. I love it. I live in a small apartment and we were spending so much money washing clothes at the laundry mat and we unfortunately only had the time to go to the laundry mat once a month. With this machine I can wash clothes when ever I need to. I did buy a rinsearoo and use that on my shower head to fill the machine. I do one wash this my detergent and then I drain and do a rinse wash with just water then I place clothes in the spinner. I also purchased a drying rack to hang the clothes to finish drying. I just recently had a baby a few months ago and had an able to wash so many of his clothes in one load. It is seriously a life saver. When I bought this washer I only paid 116 for it. I’m not sure why it’s almost 200 now but it does pay for itself in the long run.

title: Five Stars

text: I received this yesterday and since have done 3 loads. I'm very pleased! Clothes came out very clean and smell great and the spin did a very nice job removing excess water. The other issue is the power cord isn't quite long enough. I have my washer standing in the tub and it's a bit shy of reaching the closest outlet. I just used one of those short extension cords and that worked well. This is very convenient for apt living especially if you're like me with two small children and trips to the laundry room are too much of a hassle. Also, I thought that days it rains you can't exactly leave your dry clothes in the laundry room or carry them back in the rain. With this I can wash and dry from my apt! Note: I use the powder detergent so to make sure it properly dissolves I turned the washer on while I filled it to help with this. I also did what another buyer recommended and used fabric softener and my clothes didn't dryer super crunchy.

title: Good but Loud
text:
[[VIDEOID:b9bbbda8ccda3c4e14fe234d0da085ab]] Good but loud. This gets the job done, I usually have to keep a mat under it for soaking up water. It doesn't necessarily “leak” but if you fill it high as I normally do, sometimes that water can splash a lot on the inside causing a spill. It's not necessarily a manufacturing error.

It is loud, only time it's kinda quiet is if I'm spinning a small amount of clothes. Not recommended for wooden floors or surfaces it gets noisy and can rock if you're only using one drum. It's easiest to use this with a shower head that has a hose instead of hooking up the fosset. Other than that it saved laundry visit (except for large clothing and bedding of course)

title: Not worth it.
text:
This does not do the job for me. Some of that is my fault. I want something to wash towels. I can only get a max of two towels in at one time, which is not enough for me. Which is my mistake and not the washer. What I do not like about it is the amount of manual intervention needed to run this thing, and then the limited cleaning it does. This unit has no valve on the water inlet, so you manually have to add water. The drain valve is not automatic, again you must open and close the valve. OK, get past that. Next the agitation is not good. It does get some dirt out, but it will not get difficult dirt out. Then, it takes many rinse cycles. More than should be necessary IMO. One nice thing is the spinner, that it does a fair job at, but only one towel at a time.

Even for $90 it is not really worth it. I find it hard to imagine a situation where it would be helpful. Maybe it will work for my shop towels, but given how bad it is at cleaning it may not work.

title: Absolute Lifesaver during Pandemic
text: Our house was somehow built with no washer or dryer hook up capability, so we've trudged to the laundromat since we moved here 12 years ago.  Once the pandemic hit, we needed an alternative.  After realizing how unrealistic it is to handwash clothes for a family of 4, I went on a hunt for something...ANYTHING, to help.  We got this machine almost 6 months ago and it has been an absolute lifesaver.  I do around 3 "loads" twice a week.  Our first machine had a crack in the barrel of the spin side, but after a quick (less than 24 hrs) response from the seller, we had a replacement that has worked flawlessly since.  We have it set up in our basement with the hose leading to the floor drain, and we use a garden hose to fill the wash side.  Every wash load is about 3 spin loads.  That spinner is intense! It sounds like a jet plane taking off and leaves the clothes within it like 85% dry when they come out.  We then hang everything up overnight and poof, done.  I wish I had found this thing 12 years ago.

title: It has to be manually operated step by step
text: I have to say it’s my fault that I didn’t notice you have to manually operate this washing machine when I purchased it. I have to fill water in by myself and let it wash and then after a while I need to let the water drain.  This is too much work. I live in an apartment and it didn’t fit in my restroom. Make sure you have a perfect place that has a faucet and a drain. But it does the washing job well and spinning is very powerful. I sold it to someone else after a few weeks. If you are okay with manually operating it and you have a perfect spot for it, this is a good choice.

title: Works as intended
text:
The machine works perfectly. The design is old; in other countries this was the standard washer in the 70's and 80's, so it's a proven technology, not some gimmick. Of course it is not as convenient as a big $1,500 washer, but it's very cost effective. I like to put it in the tub and fill it with a bucket, then I hang my clothes to dry on a rack, but it doesn't take long with how much is spun out. It takes very little soap and I recommend starting with less time and seeing how much you actually need. Water stops coming out of my clothes after only 1.5 to 2 minutes in the spinner. As I have to do laundry very frequently for the baby diapers, this thing is a dream. It has also almost paid itself off compared with the laundromat.
The downsides are that it's more work than the big guys and there is a lot of lint left on the clothes. You can mitigate the lint by getting some floating lint traps, it does help a lot. Compared with gathering up the clothes and going to a laundromat, it's a lot less work. I strongly recommend using little soap or you'll be doing several rinse cycles.

title: Love it!
text:
UPDATE: It's been a couple of years now and the washer is still going strong!! I am getting one more just to help expedite the washing process. I have learned a couple little tweaks to get better results. Don't over fill it. It washes really well if the clothes have room to move around. The washer may start to vibrate on the spin cycle, but I just hold onto it for a minute and once it gets spinning it is amazing!! I NEVER write reviews of anything but I am still so happy with this machine. Love it!!!! We're retired and it's just the two of us! This little washer is a dream come true. I have not gotten this for free, I paid for it. I use it every couple of days...put it right in my shower and I recycle the previous rinse water to use for the next wash. Don't fill it too full with the clothes and it washes great. The spinner does such a good job that the clothes are almost dry when they come out. Just want I hoped it would be! I wanted to get a second one as a spare but it is no longer available! Please get them back, Amazon!

I have been using this washer for a few months now and I am still loving it! I have learned some little tricks to make it easier and less noisey and it has worked out great so far. It has paid for itself since I dont have to go 20 miles to the laundermat anymore. Don't overfill it with clothes or they dont agitate well. You may have to hold onto the washer until the spin dryer gets to spinning fast. I found that I never have to spin anything more than 2 minutes and the clothes come out slightly damp. I hang them out and that's it.Now that it's summer I have mine outside under the patio roof. I put the washer on four bricks, and drain it right to the patio stones.

title: Kind of cheap but you get what you pay for.
text: The top retaining ring on the spinner (the ring on top on the rim that keeps the plastic disc from rising up to the point it leaves the basket) came off and for a moment it was like the whole thing exploded by the sound it made and the way it lurched as my sweatpants got jammed between the basket and the inside of the shell.  Was able to snap it back in place though without any further incidents and it continued working.  Going to crazy glue it in place to make sure it doesn't happen again.  The 'water insert' fitting are useless as others have stated.  I just use a bucket to fill and run it in my bathtub though I had to buy a six foot extension cord to reach the outlet.  Machine cord is kind of short.

title: Prefect for my apartment!
text: Love this little thing! I only hoped that the drain tube would not have to be as low as it is. Other than that, perfect for my apartment.

title: Great
text: Works great. I love it. Soo much better than spending $40 a month at a laundry mat

title: Great product
text: Excellent product, easy to pick up and put into the tub, washes really well and spins dry.  So far been washing everything that doesn't have to be on hot and in a hot dryer.  So happy not to have to use apartment laundry room.  Cleans surprisingly well! Love the fact it has a lint filter which really traps wash lint very well!

title: outstanding
text: we bought this for our RV after our $1500.00 washer/dryer combo went out. got to say this lilt guy does the job I was totally amazed.

title: Stopped working after 8 months UPDATE: still working, not broken
text:
Pros:

It's good for small spaces.
The washer cleans and spin dries well.
It's good for small loads of laundry.

Cons:

The machine stopped working after 8 months.
The manufacturer (Costway from China) was difficult to get ahold of and wouldn't honor the one year warranty.
The Amazon product protection plan people were difficult to get ahold of and would not honor their plan until after the manufacturer's warranty had expired.

Overall, it was good until it wasn't. It might be smarter to buy a machine from a more reliable manufacturer, if available. If you buy this unit, be prepared to make repairs yourself if it stops working.

UPDATE: The washer wasn't broken, turns out there was a sock stuck in the drain tube.

UPDATE 2: I've had this washer for almost two years now and it's still working.

title: Awesome
text: I love it! Living in an apartment in New York all my life I have dealt with going to the laundromat. Then,  I found out that I can drop off my laundry and have it cleaned and folded. I was living like a king. But then I got married and had a son. I was paying a fortune to clean spit up covered bibs and poop stained onesies. Decided to try this out. It works amazingly. Gets all of the stains and dirt out of the baby clothes and our clothes too. Does take a bit of lifting as far as emptying the water but I'd rather do that than go to the laundromat. I also bought some anti-vibration pads and mats to lessen the noise as this thing is much more powerful than I thought it would be.

title: Worth it
text: Impressed with this little machine. Washes more than expected. I’d buy it again and would recommend.

title: Saver space
text: Amazing,  I will never believe what amazing and strong 💪 is this washer machine, I recommend 200%

title: Once we figured out how much water to put in it things worked alright...
text:
We went from living on a third-floor apartment with laundry in the basement and across the building to a small duplex with free laundry. Unfortunately for us, the machines look like they are from the 1970s and have rust on all the lint wires, etc. So we ended up getting this machine for some smaller loads. To be honest, I don't know how long it will last, but when it works, it works great!

Our first load was a disaster, the directions are awful and we actually appear to have put more water in than needed because water was leaking out the top sides of the bin. We contacted customer service who wanted us to mail it back! Right, because anyone is really going to pay a crap load of money out of their own pocket to return something this size! No way. We decided to give it another try or two. The second time I put less water in and thank goodness the leaking stopped. It's a fine balance with this machine, finding the right amount of clothing/water to put in. It does work better than I imagined it would, and we've been able to do good size loads. If it lasts, it will be well worth the 100.00 we paid. If it mucks up in the next few weeks then we're better off at the laundry mat... This is a manual drain machine so it isn't easy. You may be dumping buckets of water down the tub drain like I am but for us it's worth it knowing we are washing our clothing in a machine that isn't 50 years old and only has our stuff in it!

Okay, since the directions are awful, I'll give you a quick rundown of what they say to do here:

1) Make sure spin dial is on soft or normal
2) put in detergent
3) Fill tub with water
4) add clothes
5) Close lid and turn time dial on for however long you want to wash them for
6) When load is done, turn dial to drain and drain water out of washer
7) Place clothing in spin dry machine and spin dry them for however long you'd like
8) Turn dial back to soft/normal
9) Fill tub in washer again with water (NO detergent)
10) Place clothing from spin dryer back in washing tub w/fresh water
11) Close lid and turn dial on for however long you want to rinse-wash your clothes
12) When done, drain
13) Place clothing in spin dryer and spin dry

This is how I do it:

1) Make sure spin dial is on soft or normal
2) put in detergent
3) Fill tub with water
4) add clothes
5) Close lid and turn time dial on for however long you want to wash them for
6) When load is done, turn dial to drain and drain water out of washer
7) Fill tub in washer again with water (NO detergent, but keep your wet clothing in)
8) Close lid and turn dial on for however long you want to rinse-wash your clothes
9) When done, drain
12) Place clothing in spin dryer and spin dry

title: Great for small spaces, and cleans good too.
text: You can't go wrong for small washes, and its soooooo easy to use. I'm really glad I pulled the trigger on this.

title: Beware of lint
text: It works as advertised. I have been running it for 2 months now and it works. The spin feature is a huge plus. I live in an apartment with no hook ups. I put it in the tub, and run. I wish they had lint filter option for the drain hose. I use pieces of panty hose to collect the lint on the end of the drain hose. Without this I'm sure it would clog the drain quickly.

title: She lives in an apartment and would like to save on weekly trips to the laundromat
text: I purchased this for my daughter who asked for it for her birthday. She lives in an apartment and would like to save on weekly trips to the laundromat, both in money and time spent. So far, she has been happy with it. I was concerned about the longevity of the machine and only time will tell if my concerns were warranted or not.

title: Good washer
text: This little machine works great, my complaint is that it has a gravity drain without a pump!  Your drain must be lower than the machine which is difficult in an RV.  It cleans our clothes and handles a pretty big load in the washer but you need to separate into smaller loads to spin.  The spinner works great, the clothes are nearly dry!

title: Price noise level
text: great so far..... quiet product it does have its limitation to how much you can place in the tubs but once you understand that it is a small place washer it is great. Recommend it to all RVers. Light and easily stored.

title: Wonderful
text:
I live in a very small apartment and have to carry laundry up and down stairs. I find this machine to be a big improvement.
I was very doubtful about this machine when I opened the box--it looks like a toy for my granddaughter, but IT WORKS WELL. I store it in my pantry and set it up in my bathtub. It is a little awkward to pick up and carry (I thinks it's 28 pounds, empty) but it's doable.
I'm not going to repeat all the positive reviews before mine, but I will say this: temper your expectations. You can't wash quilts or rugs, but the Giantex handles double bed sheets and jeans. This is not made for a family of four.
The drain hose and the electric cord are both short. A visit to your local hardware store can remedy that. You will need to buy a connector to attach the water hose to your chosen water source but that is only a few bucks; I advise a heavy-duty appliance extension cord since you'll be using it around water. When I do laundry, I put a thick rubber mat down in the bathtub (to stop the machine from 'traveling') and attach the water hose to the shower head.
The spinner leaves even heavy items, like towels and jeans, almost dry. If you don't like to iron items like shirts, reduce the spin time, shake the item and smooth it with your hands when you hang it up. You may also want to turn items with buttons and snaps inside out.
UPDATE: I have just bought a second machine.

title: Works great...check it out on YouTube.
text: I bought mine & loved it at first.  But then it started to dance around, and then it started to make loud noises.  I finally had to get rid of it.

title: More powerful than it looks!
text: This is my 3rd apartment washer in about 4 yrs, the motors tend to wear out easy. This is by far the most powerful and easiest machine I have had yet! The spin cycle doesn't look like it would do much, but most light weight fabrics will come out almost dry! Hang it for a couple hours and its done! The instruction booklet that comes with it is very poorly translated, and wont give you much info, but it is good for a giggle! My recommendation is to watch one of the review videos or look it up on YouTube, there are tons of videos explaining how to use it. I have found you need very little soap, and you really don't need to run an extra rinse cycle if you ring out the cloths a little before putting them in the spinner, then run some water in for about a minute or so before starting the spin cycle. Everything has washed and rinsed very clean and doesn't use much water at all. Like most reviews here, I don't use the provided hose for filling it up. I have it set up next to my bathtub and use the shower wand. The only problem I've encountered was that the drain hose was on the opposite side from the bathtub, but I just got a bucket to drain it into. You could easily get some extension tubing to remedy this as well. Over all, I believe it is well worth the price if you have very little space and are tired of using the laundromat or the 50 yr old machines provided by your apartment complex. For $100 even of it only lasts a year, it has more than paid for itself.

title: Love this machine for my Yacht.
text: OMG, this little gem is under the bimini on the back of my yacht saving me countless trips back and forth to the far away laundry facilities.  It  is amazingly quiet, powerful, washes great, takes up minimal space, and spins the clothes almost dry without vibration.  Then clothes pop into my equally awesome Magic Chef 2.5 cubic ft. Dryer.  My son is at Home Depot buying fittings so it drains into the existing overboard drains and each bin has a water supply so no switching hose back and forth.  This is gravity fed drain, so drain has to be pretty much at floor level.  I can't rate for longevity, but got an inexpensive extended warranty for peace of mind.  I'm happy.

title: Worth the money
text: We got this to try to keep up in in between laundry runs. Ended up doing most our laundry in this neat little contraption. Saved the cost in the two months we spent camping at South Padre Island.

title: Great buy!
text: Great buy. This machine is awesome. Worth the money. Don't over load and it will work great. Does a great job spinning out the water. Very low noise considering that its in a small space.

title: My girlfriend really likes the performance of this mini portable ...

title: Had one overseas and loved it. Now I have one here.
text: I just love this washing machine. I had one overseas that needed to fit into a small space, nine years ago, and was delighted to see it's still the same machine that's available now. I use it for a small cabin, in the bathroom. It looks nice and takes up very little space. It's a more labor intensive than an automatic but I find it fun to use. Feels a little like playing house. It washes well. Anyone buying this will be amazed at how effective the spinner works.  I enjoy hanging the damp laundry in the sun and, having had so much moisture removed by the spinner, it dries very quickly. I follow the recommendation for amount of laundry to put in, calculated by weight. I have an old kitchen scale.  For example, a typical load might have three shirts, two pairs of pants, some underwear and socks. Or a queen-size sheet, 5 pillowcases and a couple of washcloths.

title: Gret size great product

title: Cool but so loud

title: Especially Great During COVID 19 To Protect My 81 Year Old Mother
text:
I now take care of my 81 year old mother in my studio apartment. Laundromat is three blocks away. Been really too scared to go for fear of bringing something back that may harm my Mom. So! This machine is the answer. I will probably do a big load at the laundromat, then keep up with this small wonder of a machine... maybe...

I looked at TONS of videos on YouTube, and read reviews, before purchasing. Within 30 minutes of opening the box, I started my laundry - deciding not to re-read instructions posted here. The so-called instruction manual included in the box is a joke, so I put down those instructions and my magnifying glass and "just went for it"! Thank God for common sense and logic!

I placed in my bathtub, plugged it up, put a little liquid detergent, as I filled the tub, then put some clothes in and ran for 15 minutes. Drained, refilled with clean water for the rinse, allowed to happen for 15 minutes, then split the amount of clothes and put half into the spinner. That spinner is AWESOME! Just like previous Commenters have noted, the clothes come out almost dry. There is an issue with lint, but I just shake it off, after the spin dry. With an electric dryer, there wouldn't be a lint problem.

You'll find you won't need that much detergent. Makes you realize how little one actually needs at the laundromat.

Another commenter stated they use a "grow tent" and box fan, as a sort of "dryer", but I don't think I'll use that; just need to buy a drying rack and return this grow tent... maybe...

My Mom wants to buy this washing machine as a gift for friends...

Everyone has their own way of washing. I figured my way upon the first wash. You'll find your way, as well.

Also, the box that it comes in is NOT identifiable as a washing machine. What a blessing!

title: Paid for itself in 2 months.
text:
I've been using this for 2 months now. No more going to laundry mat. It's paid for itself. I am a 50 yr old woman and I lift it in and out of my bathtub. I have not attached any hoses to my faucets, instead, I fill buckets of water and fill the tub that way. This makes it kind of labor intensive to rinse the clothes once they are in the spinner side, but there is a water inlet on this side too, so I could attach a hose. There is only one hose provided and it is made of cheap plastic with no threads or fittings. The water inlets are also without threads, so a tube with exact fitting rubber gaskets would be necessary.
After hanging to dry, I often have to use a lint brush or roller to get lint/hair off the clothes. Seems to stretch out collars of t-shirts.
Be sure not to mix fabric types, anything that gives off lint like terry-cloth will cling to other cotton or polyester fabrics.
2-3 pairs of Jeans with 3-4 shirts are easily washed. I've even washed queen size bedding. I certainly recommend this machine if your trying to save money or have difficulty getting to the laundry mat. I also like the ability to do laundry at my convenience.

title: Gets clothes clean.
text: Loved this machine, saved me many trips to laundromat. Cleans clothes well. But the filter did broke after a year. Could not connect the hose to the faucet, just used a pail. This size might be too heavy for some people to move around. It is bigger than it looks online. The noise level is low, not whisper quiet. If you have very little space and need to tuck it away; I would recommend a smaller model.

title: Great little washer
text: Great little washer, I’ve had it for a little over a month and it works great! When I received it the box it came in was very beat up, the washer had two areas where the plastic was cracked and slightly broken off, I didn’t return it because It did not effect the washers performance, it was just a cosmetic thing. This is a great little washer for apartment living. Gets clothes really clean. The only down side is the draining of the water, you either have to have the washer on a stand so the water just flows out the hose ( by gravity) and into the tub or bucket. Or what I did is put the washer in the tub with a non slip mat under it (so it wouldn’t shake around) and I also got a rubber tub stopper, made a hole in the middle of it ( big enough for the hose to fit into, but snug) and put it around the end of the hose that way the part where the water comes out fits perfectly into the tub drain and it won’t wet the bottom of the washer (and won’t cause a mess). Other than the washer not having a pump to pump the water out , it’s great for the price!!

title: Louder than hoped would be
text:
Overall an okay purchase.
PROS:
1. Washes fairly good overall.
2. Fairly easy to move in and out of bathroom.
3. Easy to operate and understand.
4. Both a pro and a con-washes small loads but a fair amount to hang to dry.
5. For some like me, this means not sharing a community washer and dryer with over 40 other tenants. One washer all to myself means less germs, etc.
CONS:
1. Can not wash and spin dry separate clothing items at same time as the spin side only works well when in drain position.
2. I feel needs drained and refilled to add a rinse cycle properly, Which takes more effort and time.
3. Do not plan to buy and use late at night if you live in an apartment building-too noisy to use at night without disturbing your next door or downstairs neighbor.

title: Great for Camper/RV life folks!
text:
I bought this in February of 2017. It is the BEST investment I made. It is labor intensive but not as much as taking clothes down to the river and beating them against the rocks. We bought a 24-ft camper for us to live in. The problem there is that small campers don't generally have washers and dryers. I was against spending hard earned money on change for a big washer so I bought this.

There were a few things I noticed though, so I'll offer a few tips that I managed to work out, in no particular order.

* We don't need to hook up hoses or anything, the way we do it, except the drain hose, which I just let loose into the tub. We just lower the hose and put it in our tub. I just use the detachable shower head to fill it up and run it.
* Because it's so small, be prepared to have to wash them twice at times. However, see note on soaking next.
* I found that soaking clothes for about 20 minutes before washing really helped to remove a lot of dirt. We live in a sandy, windy, dusty dirt area so our clothes, for whatever reason, really absorbs dirt. lol! It's that or with my regular washer in my house (my kids keep the house), I never saw the dirt so had no idea how dirty they really were.
* If you use it in the tub/shower the way I do, then be sure to rinse the spinner after spinning with soap in the clothing, else you add soap back to the clothes after the rinse. That is wash clothes > spin > rinse spinner > rinse clothes in washer > spin again.
* I would NOT put King sheets in this. In order to wash our Queen-sized sheets well enough to be clean, I can only wash one sheet at a time.
* I use fabric softener and I use about a quarter, or slightly less, of what is recommend for regular laundry. Be careful though because certain colors may turn the color of the softener. Test it first on something white that you don't care about, if possible.
* I've used bleach in this too, though a lot of RV folks are anti-bleach. I use about 1/4 c. but start with much less for yourselves. I rinse it twice, when using bleach. You may want to try a third rinse too.
* As for laundry detergent, if it has levels for a small load, use a little less than that, otherwise, I'd just about 1/4 to 1/8 of what a normal load would be. It really all depends how difficult it is to get the soap out. If you notice that the rinse water still feels soapy, then you need to reduce how much you use. It's easy though to fix, simply rinse until it's not bubbly anymore.
* This is good for about two adults. I saw a review for a woman who has a child but there was no way I could do with only this washer when my kids were small. I don't recommend it but if you're pushed and determined, you could get away with it.
* For RV users, [[ASIN:B01LZYLO2A I use this]] to dry clothes both indoors and outdoors, depending on the weather. I hook it to a kitchen cabinet handle and the bathroom door handle and it works great. It doesn't provide to much heaviness to damage either handle. The con is that it runs right down the center of the camper and is seriously in the way. I got to where I began washing clothes, linens, etc., daily and hang them at night, just before bed. They're dry by morning. You can buy more clothes pins but I overlap everything to maximize clip usage. You can even just throw it over the thing. Oh, one more con is that it does sink. I learned that I put the heaviest stuff near where the hooks are at the ends, then the light stuff in the middle. We have [[ASIN:B010OTUA9M this too]] but I hate it. It looks like it has a newer model now though, which may help. The other never balanced correctly and the clips fall off and so on. It was more annoying than anything.

Phew! Anyway, as you can see I've used it for a long time and I am aware of issues and problems. I've now shared that with all of you so you can have a good experience. Hopefully this helps. I highly recommend this! It truly is a life and money saver.

title: It beats sitting at the laundromat, maybe...
text:
I don't know how people can give this four or five stars. Automatic washer machines or ones you don't have to modify are four or five star machines, not this one. It's a good little machine, but it has some flaws. The filler hose is incredibly small. You have to hold it against the sink. After some time the hose will slip out of the cap. So using a bucket to fill it is better and much faster. The other flaw (and I knew this going in) is that the machine needs to be elevated above the drain hose or at the same level (placing in a bath tub, for example) for it to drain properly. You can drain it into a bucket, but you have babysit it as it does so. What I did not expect is for the drainage hose to be so short. The only way I can effectively use this machine until I modify it is to put it in the bath tub. I don't understand why it couldn't have been designed with and shipped with a stand to elevate it another 4-6 inches and keep it stable. There is no notification that the cycles are done except that the machine goes quiet. So unless you aren't playing music, watching TV or whatever, you won't know it's done. So one has to sort of babysit it. The directions are awful and written in broken english, though the machine is simple to use. Unless you want to do some work on this machine I'd look for another one. At the end of the day I'm sitting at home instead of the laundromat, so that's a plus I suppose...

After using it for a couple weeks I wonder if it would be more advantageous to go to the laundromat...

title: Things I have learned about this machine.
text:
Okay this is going to be long ;) I ordered this last yr. This is what I have learned in that time.
Do not add detergent to the laundry on its first time in the washer, you will be amazed at how much soap is left in your things using a regular washer.
I use vinegar and ammonia (1/4 cup of each) on my laundry, occasionally some bleach or Oxyclean . Less expensive, totally cleans and no perfumy smell. In this time I have bought only one large bottle of each. Go easy on the bleach, it takes way less than you're used to using.
Thing that takes the longest for me is filling it up and I am going to try and remedy that soon.
Clean the lint trap before your first load....

If you find a white residue on your clothes after they dry ? It is soap, wash that item alone using the vinegar etc.......and HOT WATER. The hot water loosens the weave in the clothing and allows all the soap to get out.

I am single so it is mostly office style clothing with some tshirts, so far so good.
I DO NOT USE THE SPINNER FOR MY CLOTHES........... I hang them to drip dry, otherwise they are too wrinkled to wear and I hate to iron .
I use the spinner for underwear, towels, sheets etc only.
I bought lingerie bags to wash bras etc, it was was unnecessary. Use the soft cycle and since there is no agitator, they just roll and spin in the water.
Once I am finished washing, I leave the lids up and let it dry out completely before shutting them and covering it. I have it in my kitchen in front of a window and I really don't want to look at it all the time :)

I FREAKING LOVE THIS THING !!!!!!!!!!!!! I loathe the apt washers in the laundry room .
Happy washing !

title: Great little washer
text:
Bought this in July 2016 and it is still performing well. The agitator is tough on clothes so I do not recommend this machine for delicate items. Pants and long sleeved shirts become tangled with other clothing. I use shaving cream for my spot remover and then wash clothing as usual and everything is spectacularly clean.

I usually wash spin dry then rinse and spin dry. Today I tried washing then adding water to the spin dry side while the clothes were spinning. The two water inlets add water to the washing tub or spin tub. The inlets are not for hot and cold water.

This little machine is great for cleaning regular somewhat hardy clothes and sheets or towels.

Take time to load the spinner tub carefully. I fold up towels, pants, shirts, and dresses. I add them to the tub. Leave the lids open and set the timer. Close the lid, ready to quickly open the lid if it is off balance. The ring on top of the tub has dislodged many times. I just re position and/or lighten the load. Push the ring back on the top of the tub and attempt the spin dry again. The first time it dislodged I thought I broke the spin dryer. I took a deep breath and examined the tub and noticed that the ring and tub seemed undamaged. I positioned the ring over the tub and pushed down til I felt the ring positioning down onto the top of the tub. I attempted spin drying and it worked flawlessly.

I have a garden hose with a cone shaped spray nozzle that I use for the water application. I just push the tip into the water inlet and start the water and the water flows into the machine.

I highly recommend this item to someone who lives in an apartment and just wants an inexpensive washing machine. This machine must be placed so that the drain hose is lower than the machine. So if you do not have a tub or shower area that will accommodate its size, you will need to find a way to raise it high enough to accommodate a bucket.

Wish you the best.

title: Damn good money spent. Would definitely buy again.
text:
This machine is really freeking good for the price. This washer/spin dry combo kicks my expensive home washer into the dirt! I bought this machine at first for my camper, for when my husband and I are out on the road for work. Some places are just really dirty for a place meant to get clothes clean. So we started looking into some small washer that could save us some money and exposure to whatever is in those machines at the poorly mantained public laundromats. We we're looking at stackables when we stumbled onto this one. I admit, I didn't expect much. Boy was I glad to be wrong! I use it all the time now. It cleans so well I have taken it over to my in-laws to show them! They RV too, and didn't expect this machine to take "clean" clothes that had gone through their expensive, brand name washer, and clean even more soil out of them! Nice! I have been using the machine since April, and it's now December. Still running strong, and still my primary washing machine. It has gotten a bit loud, so I am not sure of the longevity of the motor. It's the only reason I am not giving this unit five stars. It's gotten quite loud. I tried to open it up to see if it just needed a bit of oil/grease. (I have a background in electronics repair, honestly don't even attempt it.) It's a sealed bearing unit, so no go. This doesn't really put me off too much. I have saved money using this machine. When the motor says enough, I will definitely be purchasing another unit. The drier is a belt driven centrifuge in a separate compartment. So you can start another load in the washer while "drying". I really like this. I also got a laugh out of the instructions. The print is tiny! So, so small! The translation is far from helpful, you end up with more questions than answers. I also noticed a lot of people trying way too hard to come up with plumbing for this very simple process. Don't waste your money on hoses and cuplers. Here is my solution:

*Place the unit into your tub/shower stall. (I used a plastic stress mat to elevate the machine from the water draning into the stall/tub. It really helps with the noise from the motor as well)

*Take down the drain hose from the machine, point that toward the drain of your tub/shower stall.

*Use your existing shower hose and head to fill the washer. (Just drop the thing right into the washer compartment and fill. No need for special plumbing or any extra cost to you. I feel like everyone is trying to over engineer this problem. I love some of the solutions people have some up with, but this hack is really simple and free.)

So the water gravity drains. When you are finished with your wash/spin dry, you will want to pick up the unit and tip it toward the hose to get the rest of the water out of the machine. The centrifuge drier does a pretty good job at wringing the excess water out of the clothing. Hang dry overnight will work for even thick jeans or a Carhartt jacket. The clothing will be a bit stiff, but they will be clean and dry. If you hate the stiffness, you can use the washer and go to the laundrymat to dry and still save money. I find the lint catcher does a good enough job that adding a second one that floats in with the wash to be unnecessary. I have already saved enough money from not going to the laundrymat to have bought this washer several times over. I would absolutely recommend it, and if this one gives up the ghost, I'm buying another. Totally worth it.

title: Good for single-person household
text:
I'm just one person, and I do about three loads a week, because it doesn't hold a lot of clothes. But I'm guessing that an average-sized family would find that they'd be doing laundry almost every day with this relatively small washer. I'm not sure about the long-term reliability yet, as I've had it for only a few months. But I have some tips for those who are considering buying this item or who have already bought it.

First, as others have said, the intake hose that comes with it is inadequate. I went to Home Depot and bought a 10-foot length of clear, braided, 5/8-inch inside diameter tubing, as well as some fittings to allow me to connect it to my sink faucet. If you want to do this, first unscrew the faucet aerator and take it w/you to the store so they can match the thread. Don't get plain clear tubing; make sure you get the braided tubing that has reinforcing thread spiraling around the tubing. Regular unbraided tubing will soften too much when using hot water, and will tend to kink. The braiding keeps it from kinking and cutting off the water supply.

I also leave the washer lid open, fully upright, when filling w/the hose connected to the nipple that sticks up behind the tank. This takes stress off the nipple and keeps it from cracking/breaking by having the hose come straight down, supported by the open lid, instead of having sideways tension on the filling nipple.

Secondly, if you put this next to the bathtub on a raised platform/bench so that it can drain into the tub via gravity, make sure the supporting item is really solid and won't flex (i.e., do NOT use plastic milk crates, etc., as they are too flexible and will allow the machine to sway from side to side. I think a really solid wood or metal bench would work fine as long as it is high enough for the gravity drain to work (there's no electric pump to lift water up). But I finally just put the washer up on my granite countertop in the kitchen, so it drains into the kitchen sink. I put a cheap rubber door mat under the washer's feet. This gives it a solid footing, and keeps noise/vibration to a minimum, and also protects the granite counter top.

Also, be aware that most clothing will tangle horribly and get all knotted up during a typical 15-minute wash cycle, especially items such as long-sleeved shirts/long sleeved t-shirts, long pants, etc., and this will cause the items not to get as clean as possible. To avoid this problem you can get some medium-sized mesh washer bags. These are about 12" x "16" and several will fit properly in the washer tank. Larger ones will probably get jammed up in there, I think. But after trying mesh washer bags, I have opted to just untangle the clothing between wash and rinse cycles. Washing smaller items together in one load, such as socks, short-sleeved t-shirts and underpants, results in little or no tangling.

Really large items such as a full-bed blanket, etc., can be washed, but should be washed alone because they are so big. They will be too large to put into the spin dryer, so you can just use a portable drying rack. I stick my drying rack in the bathtub and drip-dry such large items; then I am able to dry them in my portable clothes dryer, once they are just damp but no longer dripping.
A few people here have noted that they are concerned about mold/mildew building up in the washer’s plumbing, but I haven’t detected any problem after several months. I leave the washer and spinner lids open and the drain valve open for about 24 hours after using, so it dries out well. If you’re still worried, you can always put a half cup of white vinegar in a half-full washer and swish it around for a few seconds, then drain the unit. The vinegar solution will kill anything that might otherwise grow there between loads, and will leave a mildew-resistant film on the parts.

https://smile.amazon.com/dp/B071L6QPXF/ref=psdc_3744371_t3_B071HM1TKK

https://smile.amazon.com/dp/B00H7P1GPO/ref=psdc_695488011_t1_B001UE8ILI

https://smile.amazon.com/Kasydoff-Portable-Foldable-Clothing-Automatic/dp/B07CNGJFX1/ref=sr_1_3?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1534786665&sr=1-3&keywords=Kasydoff+Portable+Clothes+Dryer&dpID=51HElumSF2L&preST=_SY300_QL70_&dpSrc=srch

EDIT: I have now been using this machine for many months, and it seems very reliable. NOTE: be careful not to fill the spin dryer too full. Leave a few inches between the top of the clothes and the ring around the top of the spin cylinder. If you do get it too full, the force will knock off the ring that sits at the top of the spinner cylinder, and it creates a terrible noise. It's not broken, but you can't use the spinner again until you put the ring back on top and seat it down properly again.

To do this, lay the ring on the top and put a long, solid object (e.g., a metal ruler, flathead screwdriver using the flat side) on top across it. Then go around the top ring gently tapping the long object near the ring as you go. It may take two trips around to get the entire ring seated snugly again. Tapping will bring it down about a half inch, where it should sit solidly again. Just make sure it is seated completely all the way around.
