title: Dont Hesitate Get it!
text: Durable little washer packed with a lot of power!I've had it for a little over 4 months I'd say mabey 20 washes I love this for parents with newborns and small children!

title: Good product, but requires lots of labor for 2 people's clothes
text:
I like the product in terms of functionality. I have used it for three weeks, and it's being doing well. The noise level is tolerable too. One important thing to notice that you need at least 3 circles to get rid of most of the detergent off your clothes, which is very troublesome and labor-intensive!!
If you have more than two people's clothes accumulated for around a week, it usually requires 3 rounds, with each round 2-3 circles. One circle contains 1 wash(~10mins), 1 spin(~2mins). So it takes roughly 12*3*3 = 108mins. Note that since it's not automated, you will need to switch clothes across two bins for around 10 times.

title: Great but a few things
text:
I bought this because my basement got flooded and my traditional washer is no longer working.

Money is super tight and I need something cheap and efficient so I can do my clothes as well as my daughters.

This gets it done. No question. However a few things you need to know.

Draining is a problem because there's no power pumping the water out you really can't just snake the drain wherever you'd like. It truly does have to be on a flat surface, the drain that is.

It's small but it is bulky. So if you're like me and have a pretty small bathroom, it's really not going to fit. I personally had an issue of finding a faucet adapter as my bathroom faucet simply wouldn't fit anything.

It takes a lot of water more than you would assume. You also pretty much need to monitor it because the loads go quick. I typically use the 9-minute setting, drain it, refill it it let it run for another 6 minutes.

The spinner is great. It gets the clothes basically completely dry but you will need to hang them or put them in some sort of dryer to get them perfect. The spinner is also super small. It only holds about half of what you put in the washer.

If I had to do it all over again I would do it. It's a great product but it's not the best although for the money what more you really want??

title: It does it’s job

title: DEAR GOD, I NEEDED THIS.
text:
After months of dealing with the machines at my apartment complex getting broken over and over again, I decided to get this. MAN, I SHOULD HAVE BOUGHT IT SOONER. While the loads are small, laundry still gets done quicker when I can do it in my living room without having to worry about someone else's misuse of the machines before I got there meaning I'm gonna come back to wet-and-still-dirty-clothes, or half-dry clothes that I have to shell out more quarters to dry a second time.

title: The plugs are super short and the plug on the washer has three ...
text: I ordered this washer about a week ago and it finally came today!! Who's excited is me??? So far I've washed 2 loads going on 3. The disadvantage of having this washer is that it doesn't come with a hook-up nor does it offer it when checking out to hook to the sink to fill up the washer with water. My son and I actually filled it up with water using  a koolaid picture and drained it in a huge gumbo pot. You have to sit it up on something or all the water will not drain. Trust, I learned the freaking hard way 😂😂. Oh and another thing. The plugs are super short and the plug on the washer has three prongs so if needing to get an extension cord like myself old get a. 3 prong 😞😞😟😟 I had to learned that that the hard way too. title: Very pleased.
text: Item has a different name than it says in the order, but it is the same. I made a platform with packaging materials so gravity feeds the drained water to a pan beside the washer. Not enough hose to drain in to a sink with the hose.... also the water hose from faucet to washer is small and u need to buy a dishwasher faucet connect to make it fit. (why I can only give 4 stars)  I can't have my washing machine in the temporary apartment I am in right now. This worked so well... Very pleased.

title: Ehh..
text:
Well I'll list the pros and cons of this machine in my opinion
Pros:
strong agitator,
Compact (Fits right in our closet)
Decent size wash side,
The spinner is awesome! I was very impressed ,
Gets clothes pretty clean

Cons:
Very cheaply made. Hoping it doesn't fall apart to fast,
Drain hose not that long,
Fill hose = useless,
Semi loud but nothing crazy

Sadly, mine came with what looked like grease or dirt on the side and a print of something on the lid of the spin side that will not come off no matter what we do.. we think it happened during manufacturing, but its really not that big of a deal to us as it still functions properly. After shipping took a week and a half longer than expected we jus decided to keep it.

Overall an ok washer/spinner for apartments! I'm gonna love not having to haul everything downstairs as much!

title: The product works fine, does precisely what it claims to do
text: The product works fine, does precisely what it claims to do. But the instructions are worthless. I had to go online and read reviews on how to best use it. Overall, it is definitely worth the money.

title: It worked for 6 months, then...
text: I bought this in July 2018 and it lasted until December 2018.  The washer/ spin dryer worked for a good six months.  It worked exactly like it was intended to.  Washed my jeans, shirts, undergarments, so on and so, you name it.  Then it dries the clothes as designed that takes 5 minutes to do.  I loved this machine.  Then, the pump burnt out.  It left a lot of black residue in my bathtub (I thought one of my socks fell into the electrical circuits and fried).  I don't know if the pump was faulty or if it was defective.  It doesn't matter because the seller, Giantex, did not respond to me, and now I am an unsatisfied customer.  Both of the washer and dryer no longer function.  I tried to contact Giantex for a replacement part, but they did not reply to me.  If it were not for their customer service, I would have given this product a 5-star rating.  However, when the pump completely blew out, and I did not receive any feedback from them, I decided this product should be avoided from potential buyers.  Six months gave me the same amount of cost of this if I had taken it to a laundromat, but with the convenience of washing clothes in my apartment.  The instructions have terrible English.  Giantex needs to work on their grammatical and customer support.  My last advice for the company: get some quality control!

title: it does a good job
text:
ive had this washer for a few months but didnt use it much till it warmed up.. i move mine in and out of the tub.. i place it on a cheap tub mat so it wont rub on the tub,, im a big guy, i place like 2 pair of bants, or 4 Tshirts or like 6 pair of underware,, then I top it off with about 6 galons of warm/hot water and some detergent just a couple of table spoons,, water is up to the last two vents on the filter. there is a 15 minute cycle but my clothes are pretty soiled so i run em for 3-4 cycles then drain the dark grey to black water out,, dump a quick rince bucket through,, then I load with about 6 galons or fresh for 1-2 cycles..then drain into the tub... then I take about half my itens and put them in spinner flatten and even then dial up a few seconds to check ballance if its good i set it for the 5 minutes clothes are usually wet but not drippy any more.. I do baby it and error on the side of less clothes I have not tried anything as big as a sheet but i think washer could handle it. if it holds out for at least a year Id call it a good deal the wash cycle goes clock for like 4 seconds then counter for 4 so good agitation.
get some lint bobbers

I wouldn't recommend it till the hose problem is resolved. They need to make a better hose for it. title: Excellant Addition to our RVcheapo
text: I have done a number of loads and it works very well. The hoses (drain and water supply) are light (fragile) and difficult to attach to anything . I use it in the RV's shower stall and fill with the shower head (mine is on a flexible hose and so easy peasy). There is no pump to drain the unit and utilizes gravity to drain (i.e. the washer has to be above or at the same height as the drain). The spin dry is surprisingly and amazingly effective. The manual is incomprehensible (I am not sure what language it is in but it does have a collection of English words randomly assembled that will give puzzle solvers and humorists great delight).  Very light weight and easy to use (the washer - not the manual). Truly portable. Clothes are very clean. We'll see how long it lasts. Very good value. Won't disappoint. I oscillated between assigning 4 or 5 stars but the cheap hoses and poor manual and the apparent lack of any warranty prevented me from giving it a 5.

title: Great purchase for house without laundry hookups
text: The house I rent doesnt have laundry hookups, and I started looking into one of these as I was fed up with going to the laundromat. My friend lives in a 3rd world country, and these kinds of machines are very common there; I used hers while visiting there so i was familiar with how to use it before I bought it. This model seemed to be the best deal for the size range. My roommate and I have been using it  for the last 2 months to do all our laundry. We've only been to the laundromat once, to wash our comforters. This machine has been a huge help, especially during the pandemic time. Although laundry takes more effort and time than with a normal machine, I'm quite happy with how this one works. We plan to do laundry on a sunny day so we can line dry the clothes. You do have to do multiple small loads, because it doesn't have a large capacity. It's definitely easier to wash lightweight clothes, like summer things, than washing heavy sweaters and such.  It's been a worthwhile purchase so far. Clothes are nice and clean!!

title: Perfect for small loads in an apartment with no washer
text:
Perfect for small loads in an apartment with no washer. The main reason I give it 4 stars is that the hose that comes with it does is not compatible with my sink or bathtub faucet. Instead I use a 3 gallon bucket to fill it up with usually about 6-7 gallons of water for a couple pairs of underwear, a shirts and maybe some jean shorts. Still experimenting with load size but it seems perfect for the small loads I need it for.

The instructions are in very broken English (some of it is pretty amusing) but thankfully there are plenty of videos on Youtube by other people that have purchased the washer and demonstrate how to use it.

The washer runs in spurts of about 6 seconds which is a little annoying to listen to, but it's not the worst and doesn't run for long (12 minutes max for one cycle). The spin dryer is practically silent and siphons the water out surprisingly well. I still have to air dry what's left, but that was expected. I've only used it a couple times but so far it was well worth my money to not have to go around the outside of my building and down to the basement to pay for my laundry.

title: gets it done
text: while not QUITE as convenient as advertised this thing gets the job done. as it's a portable unit I assume like me you will only be pulling this out when needed. well, it's not overly heavy but it is cumbersome enough that laundry is still going to be work. in addition, I have no idea where you would find a dedicated water supply in any place where you would use this instead of a conventional washer, which is good because i've never seen a water source that would be compatible with the hose in the unit. the unit does a very good job of cleaning as long as you load it properly, as in don't OVERLOAD it so the stuff has the freedom to move. the biggest issue is rinsing, thicker fabrics especially like my bath towels or my thicker sheets do not rinse out in 1 cycle, I've had it take as much as 4 to get the soap out, if I could use the water fill in the spin dryer that likely wouldn't be an issue but I can't. which leads us to the spin dryer, it's good but you will need someplace to air dry the stuff even after the spin, OR access to a tumble dryer. but it does the job you bought it for.

title: Bye Bye Laundromat!
text: I LOVE this product! It is so much more cost efficient and saves me so much more time than running to the laundromat mat! Also, another added bonus is you get a little bit of a work out when filling up the machine. I transport my water via a bucket so picking it up and pouring it in the machine and repeating the process a few times gets me moving a bit. It could also be viewed as a down side. As previous reviewers have mentioned my hose also does not fit the sink nozzle. Hence, using buckets. I would much rather transport buckets then going to the laundromat so it works great for me. It is a powerful machine. I was worried it wouldnt be strong enough to move clothes around and that I wouldnt be able to wash a lot at once. It can do more than I thought but not as much as what you get in a load as the using a washer and dryer machine from the laundromat. This is a compact machine so I can do two pairs of jeans or two bath towels or three tshirts, ect. I am sure you could put more in because it is powerful but I dont like to since the clothes seem to get more lint on them the more i put in. Make sure you clean that little lent bag out in the washer after every load! The washing machine has two settings normals or a gentle cyle. To be honest I can't tell a difference but there could could be one. This leads me to the noise. Its not a quiet machine. You defidentally know when its running and when it stops from the noise it makes. Its not so loud when you're in another room with the door shut but if you like things quiet this may not be the product for you. Its still a really good product and you can defidentally tell its washing the clothes throughly by the noise. I like the noise since I know when to switch out another load. The dyer also makes noise but its usually the loudest when it starts and not so much towards the end. The dyer wrings out the clothes and depending on the fabric some even feel dry by the time the cyle is done. Most of the time the clothes are damp and need to be hung up to dry over night. The washing cyle is 15 minutes and the dryer is 5. Its up to you if you want to do a longer washing time. I like to do a wash then rinse cyle, so 30 min total and then 5 min in the dryer. Also, I recommend using this product where you don't mind getting the floor wet, say the tub. It drains through the same type of tiny hose as you use to fill the machine. I have been using this machine for half a year and its held up nicely, even the hose are in good condition. Over all im really satisfied with this product! One day I hope to have a home with a washer and dryer machine and retire this machine for traveling say for a camper but for now I am greatful to not have to go to the laundromat!

title: Excellent washer

title: Perfect for small loads and low budget
text:
My husband and I were looking for a budget friendly washing machine. We decided to go with a small washing machine and looked over several brands. This one was within our budget, big enough for our small loads of laundry, and could be moved when needed.
It stores easily in the closet of our bathroom. Fits into the tub, so no water messes to clean up. Filling it ourselves, saves on water. The spinner gets the clothes dry enough to take maybe an hour in cool temperatures to dry. I don't have to carry heavy water logged clothing to hang outside, or have dripping water in the washroom if it is too cold or raining when we do the laundry.
It was a good price, arrived in good condition, and is easy to use. Even kids could use this under supervision.

title: Beats driving to the laundromat.
text:
Starting positive. My broke roommate considers it a godsend. I got it so I didn't have to visit the laundromat anymore or rely on various friends who actually had washer dryers in their homes.
It works well enough though it's not a heavy-duty washer for really dirty clothes. As the size goes I tend to put 3 pairs of pants in to make sure they wash well. The spin dryer only takes 1 pair.
The biggest downside would be the spin dryer. While it does get a surprising amount of water out it's still not dry. I don't like the feel of air dried clothes so I looked up portable and compact dryers and got one. The spin dryer is expectedly noisy but in a closed room shouldn't bother people a few rooms over. The spin guard (a round peice of plastic that's supposed to go over the spinner for our protection) was warped beyond use when we received it. Likely the heat.
The water inlet was too small as many are saying. So we took a big pot and filled it with hot water. Takes a few times but we get there. Probably faster that the inlet was anyway.
Finally, I will say while it isn't too heavy for we "youngins". It's still decently heavy even empty. Well over 50 lbs. It's about as portable as a washer can get.

The reviews for this machine on Amazon were very informative (thank you), great videos. I knew that the hose for the intake was not designed for US plumbing and the machine drained using gravity. For many who gave this machine 1 to 2 stars, I would suggest that you read the reviews before dropping money on a washer.

I like that I have control of the cycles - for dirty clothers, I can run two or more wash cycles. Clothes are cleaner than the clothes washed with my washer that died (came with the house). title: Understand the way to hack this and you will be in heaven!
text:
Honestly one of the best purchases I've ever made. It works 1000x better than coin laundry and it will save you a bundle. You need to keep a few things in mind and I've included my favorite hacks here for super clean clothes:

1. If you are looking for a set it and forget it kind of thing don't buy this. It needs babysitting. This machine is somewhere between hand washing and automatic. It does the work, but you have to do some work too.

2. Use only a tablespoon or two of soap. I suggest Persil or Tide.

3. Load and do not over-stuff. But it will do a lot. I can do a pair of jeans, 2 or 3 t-shirts, some underware and socks all in just one load. Don't overfill the water. Fill about 3/4 of the way up the lint filter inside. I set my wash time for 6 -9 minutes and that's all it really needs.

4. Drain and then refill again with cold water and run it for 3 - 4 minutes. Drain.

5. Now here is the step that really gets it all clean and all of the soap out of the clothes: Put about half of the load into the spin dryer. I have attached a funnel to the intake right next to the spin dryer and I use a hose from the sink to run water into the spin dryer for about one minute while it spins. This way when the water runs clear out of the hose and into the sink or tub you will know the soap is gone. Turn off the water. Let it finish spin drying completely.

Sometimes the machine will require that you hang on or support it while it spins. No big deal. I have mine up on the kitchen counter and just lean against it to keep it from walking.

Your clothes can then be line dried or check out the "Manatee" standing dryer here on Amazon for quicker hang drying. Clothes will be soap-free and not stiff if you follow these steps using the water intake for part of the spin dry to completely remove all soap.

title: Satisfied
text: Thanks to corona virus I am scared to go do laundry and decided to order this machine. I’m very happy with this purchase because it gets the job of washing clothes done. Don’t think that this machine is going to have the same result of doing laundry with a regular washer and dryer, you have to accept the machine for what it is. I will be doing a video of my laundry day routine to show exactly how the machine works and with specific details but let me try to sum it up for now. The wash compartment is big enough to hold most of my clothes (I do laundry every week) as long as I don’t wear a bunch of jeans and sweaters. The thicker/heavier the material, the less clothes you should put in. It is important to put only a little bit of soap because if not, you’re gnna have to do a bunch of rinse cycles to get all of the soap out. The little lint catcher that is in the wash compartment does a good job of catching lint but it doesn’t catch all of it. I remove the lint from the catcher after every cycle. I do three wash cycles... detergent cycle, softener cycle, and a rinse cycle and even after the spin cycle there is still lint leftover on my clothes when they dry on the rack so I use a lint roller. Not that big of a deal for me. The spin compartment is extremely small compared to the wash compartment. I have to get my sheets sent out to wash because they don’t fit in the spin cycle. When I wash jeans or really heavy sweats/sweaters I have to spin one at a time. I don’t understand why they made the spin compartment so small because I absolutely love the way it dries my clothes but whatever I accepted it and just take my time. When you initially turn the spin cycle on, it shakes like crazy and so it makes a lot of noise from rocking back and forth but after a few seconds the clothes balance out and it just makes a low noise and then as it’s slowing down to get ready to stop it makes noise again till it stops completely. I usually grab the machine and tilt it against my legs till it balances out because I don’t want it to bang on the floor but because of this, I have to dedicate a day for laundry because I have to be ready to grab the machine after the spin cycle is done before it starts going crazy again. The size of the machine is way smaller than a regular washing machine but still takes up a decent amount of space if you have a tiny apartment like me. I put the machine in my shower and use my shower head to fill it half way Because the tube that comes with the machine is good for nothing. I put the drain tube straight into my shower drain to get all the water out. I spray my machine with cleaner after every wash and rinse with hot water then leave the compartment doors open to allow the inside to dry to avoid mold. I also take out the lint catcher and allow it to dry to avoid it from smelling bad (it’s wet cloth). It might seem like a lot but so far I’m not complaining because it’s saving me money and I don’t have to go out and risk exposing myself to others. As long as I dedicate a day out of the week to properly wash and hang my clothes, it’s very convenient to have. I consider it more of a laundry assistant than a washing machine.

title: Works great and is durable
text:
According to the top of the screen, I bought this in October 2016. I still have it, use it and have had zero problems. It may be the best investment I've made. No trudging up and down the stairs. No paying $3.50/load in the building machines. And this holds about as much per load.

I found a tub height table that it fits on perfectly. I used to fill it with a bucket, but then got smart and bought a shower head with the handheld option that has a setting to stop the flow, so I don't get water anywhere. I just but the shower head in the washer and let it fill up. (I recommend getting one those cheap flower shaped lint catchers to back up the built-in one. Especially if you have pets.) After the first wash, I drop the hose into the tub and let it drain. Then refill for a rinse. Pro Tip: Be sure to move the dial back to wash before filling.

Next, move the laundry to the spinner. It will only take half of what the washer holds, so you'll be spinning 2 or 3 times depending on what your washing. The spinner runs for 5 minutes, but I tend to let it go about 2 minutes and my laundry is pretty much dry. I'll use the full 5 if I'm washing something that holds a lot of water, like jeans...or if I've gotten distracted. I set up foldable tv tray to hold the wet clothes, so I can spin the second load while I hang the first. If I feel that the rinse may not have gotten all of the soap out, I'll pour water into the spin cycle through it's water inlet. One of those really cheap small collapsible funnels fit it perfect so you can easily put the water in.

After I'm all done for the day, I lift one side of the washer to get any remaining water out. Open up both tops and let it air dry. And that's it.

It's a little bit more work than a typical washer/dryer. But it has already paid for itself a few times over. When it's time for a new one, I'm considering the all in one type - that's 3 times the price, but even more convenient. My only advice is to consider the set up for your home. If you can't figure out a way to gravity drain it - then you may do better paying more and getting one with a pump. If I have any regrets - it's that I didn't get the pump. But I got this on sale for around $100 and that fit my budget at the time.

Seriously - stop pondering and just buy it. You can thank me later. :)

title: Overall, pretty happy with the machine. Easy to use if you know what you're doing.
text:
Update: I have had this for a couple weeks now and figured out some "hacks" and tips.

I place this in my tub and found no issue with that. I use our bathroom sponge to balance the machine and ease vibrations. I also went to my hardware store and bought a showerhead diverter, a 30-in 1/2" faucet supply hose, and a brass "barbed" adaptor. *Ensure these all connect in the store before purchase!* Sadly, 8 forgot the hose that came with the package, but I zip-tied it a couple times to get a decent seal. I always leave a little slack so any stray leaks don't get on the machine. Makes life easier just turning on the shower and filling/rinsing the machine this way. Cost of this was $30 but worth it! I am a 6'5" guy and I threw my back out filling the machine over and over. Plus, you can do a rinse and spin to get the suds out.

With this machine, you must always think "less is more" and if it looks like enough, it's already too much. A decent load, to measure, is whatever can fit in the spin basket plus a one extra, light thing. When the wash cycle is going, you want to see a vortex... a whirlpool effect. If your clothes are floating and spinning at the top struggling to be washed, you've overloaded. Pull out items one by one until you get that whirlpool.

You can spin and wash at the same time. The spinner drains regardless of the middle knob is set to drain, and if you overfill the wash tub it will drain whatever overflows. Plan this accordingly.

Noise is compareble to an AC unit, and there are vibrations depending on where you place it and how level it is. I use a sponge balance and absorb some vibrations. Not fancy, but works.

I reuse my hot water, topping off the wash tub each time. The water may look gross but it's fine as there's soap already in it. Dry cleaners reuse their chemical wash hundreds of times over and your clothes come out fine, plus you'll rinse it all. My whites come out whiter than the commercial washers too, so you're saving money and resources.

I'm still very happy!

***

Where do I start? Well, I have spent a good portion of the few weeks looking at portable washing solutions as my apartment does not have a washer set-up, and I got tired of using the public washers in my apartment community. All the coins needed, going back and forth, waiting for machines to open, ensuring I had enough quarters at the time, and the entire day had to be devoted to laundry more often than not.

So, I shopped around, reading reviews and watching videos of different machines. This one stuck out as it's reasonably affordable and does a great job, according to reviews. I live in the Bay Area and this ships for Los Angeles, so I got it within a couple days (excluding a holiday and weekend). The box was in good shape and unclipped the ties. A whiff of "new plastic" and staring in awe, there it was, just as in the pictures. Unboxing was easy, unclip the ties and lift the top part off. A brand-new washer!

I grabbed the instruction manual and flipped through it. As other have joked on here, it's in Engrish with such gems as "choke the dial" and "put staff not under." I tossed it aside because it's useless, most reviews give you the rundown. Here's mine, if you need it:

Step 1: Place a splash of soap, no more than a heaping tablespoon's worth or the soap will take forever to rinse out. You don't need to measure, but just guess and be cautious.
Step 2: Place clothing in machine, one item at a time. Sort your items keeping towels in one load, basics in another, denim in another, and so on. Fill the machine just over half full with basics. Towels and denim should be washed in smaller loads as they're heavier fabrics.
Step 3: Ensure middle dial is set to "Normal" or "Soft" and fill with water. The "inlet hose" is useless out of the box as you need an adaptor that the manufacturer assumed you had. One end has a rubber gasket and the other end does not. The gasket end is the part that would go to an adaptor, the gasket-less end goes to the machine. Why? Because if you hook the gasket to the machine, it's harder than heck to get it off without nearly destroying the hose. During the inaugural load, I did not have an adaptor, so I filled the wash basin with a bucket. Fill just slightly over half-full, any more will splash out during the agitation cycle.
Step 4: Check to see of the machine is plugged in. I forgot to do this and sat there confused. Turn the "Wash" dial to 15 minutes and the machine will hum to life. Let the machine do its thing and come back when it is done. It doesn't make any alarm when it's done, just so you know.
Step 5: You may come back to, what I would describe as a burning smell. I was alarmed at first but nothing was wrong, it's "new motor smell." Turn the middle dial to drain and the water will come pouring out of the drain hose. There is no pump, so try to have the machine elevated or set in your bathtub.
Step 6: Open the spinner basin and place a few items in, ensuring that it evenly loaded (about half of the wash load). Place the plastic insert in the bin on top of the laundry, close the lids. Is the middle dial still set to drain? Good. Leave it. Turn the "Spin" dial to 5. If you have the "inlet hose" hooked to an adaptor, this is where you can do a spin and rinse. If not, you can spin the suds out and wash again in clean water real fast, then repeat the spin. The machine will vibrate during the spin, and if it vibrates to a point where you think it is too much, stop the spin cycle and rearrange your items. Everything comes out damp, not wet. Like others have said: "About 90% dry."

When putting away the machine, tilt it slightly toward the direction of the drainage hose to get the rest of the water out. I set the machine aside with the lids open as to prevent a musty smell in the future. I will say this: Don't overwhelm the machine. Do a couple washes and allow the machine to cool and rest for a couple hours, say, while your laundry is drying on a rack. If you overexert the machine, it will break. EEK! It's more for daily loads (every day or every other day) than for a single day of wash ("laundry day").

It's a great compact machine that gets your laundry as clean as most large washing machines. It takes a bit more effort on your part to tend to each load, but it's easier than running up and down flights of stairs, digging in the sofa for coins, and fighting over the next machine. I plan on finding a cart to place this on so I can store it easier, and find an adaptor that will fit the inlet hose.

I will update this as time goes on. It's a really simple machine, gets the clothes clean, and I am saving some money from the get go compared to the few bucks it takes each wash in the laundromat.

title: Good for college/first apartments
text:
I bought this so I didn't have to pay for (and go to) the laundromats at college. It has been one of the best investments I've made.

You can only wash about half a load at a time, but the spinner get things almost dry so you can hang them up and they'll be ok. It never damaged any of my clothes and always got the dirt and stains out.

title: So glad I bought this machine
text:
So glad I bought this machine. I've waited a few months to write a review because I wanted to give and accurate representation of my experience with the product. This is a solid performer as long as you don't overfill it. I personally fill the washing compartment with water add soap then add my cloths. After the wash, I drain it with my clothes still inside and refill it with more water to get out the excess soap. Finally, I place some clothes in the spin dryer for a few minutes and hang them up to air dry.
5 out of 5 from a busy New Yorker.
*update*
5 years later now and my machine finally burned out. My family has been coming over every few days to do laundry since the pandemic so I’m not surprised. I was looking to purchase it again but I’m not so sure this time. When I purchased it back in 2017 it was $113 plus tax. I don’t know if I could say it’s worth $192 plus tax. But hey that’s supply and demand for you. Would definitely recommend to anyone who wants to give it a go. Just treat it with care and it’ll last.

title: Awesome option for apartments w/o washer/dryer access
text: I bought this compact washing machine while living in an apartment without a washer/dryer. It was great to do smalls loads. For what I needed it for, it was great. My bf and I used it very frequently and it held up really well. It doesn't replace what a real washing machine can do. You do have to manually add and drain the water with each load so I kept it near the bathroom. The spinner does dry clothing very well but still slightly damp where you would put on a drying rack. It doesn't take out any type of animal hair/lint that a regular washer would. You cant fit a lot of heavy big items. But these considerations are just general information for any type of washer like this. I would def. recommend this washer if you live in an apartment with no washer/dryer.

title: Does a decent job of getting dirt off but not so good about getting any kind of stain
text: Quick wash with <15 minutes. Does a decent job of getting dirt off but not so good about getting any kind of stain. Make sure to soak and remove stains before you set them in by washing. The high speed spin drain/dry is great at getting them almost dry. Dryer holds about half of the washed clothes. Overall very handy to have as full time traveler in my camper.

title: Neat little washer
text:
After a few months of researching this and other portable/automatic machines, and being fed up with going to the laundromat, I broke down and bought this. I am fully aware this machine will require a bit more "work" as opposed to an automatic, but I'm ok with that. I don't have much laundry anyway, but I plan on just doing more frequent smaller loads throughout the week, and still have to go to laundromat for comforters, but that'll only be every other week. I figured I could suck up losing 100. on this vs. 300. on an automatic portable one if this ended up being a dud. I do have regular laundry hook ups, but my old style washer broke down, and I'm trying to baby my septic system. I have my eye on a full size HE washer in the next few months, and a plumber to re-route my washer grey line.

I've used this a few times now, and initially I was disappointed at how small the washer tub seemed, the videos made it appear larger. I thought they sent wrong one, but nope, it was right. Just to give an idea, the tub part to wash is about 19 inches deep-from my elbow to middle finger tip. And, there's no high water mark that I can see, I just go by the lint filter, and fill to about the middle of that; which is about 5-6 inches from the top. I think if you go much higher than that, it'll start splashing out of the lid.

First, I want to note, as others say just a bit of laundry detergent is needed. When filled up, this is about 10 gallons of water. I cringed at some of the videos where all you saw were suds. That doesn't equate to cleaner clothes. It can actually attract dirt and grease if not rinsed out good, and make the clothes stiff. I just did two loads of sheets. First was twin fitted, flat, 3 standard pillow cases. I realized after I should've used a bit more water. The sheets kind of bunched at the top rather than doing the whirlpool thing. Washed for 15 mins, then drained the water, refilled the tub part and added fabric softener. Did about 6 min rinse in the tub part and drained. Moved the 3 pillow cases to spin for about 3 mins. I noticed the polyester materials spun out almost dry, and the cotton one was fairly dry. So, next round I decreased to 2 mins and they came out the same.

Next load was queen fitted, flat, and 2 standard pillow cases. They fit and washed fine, just made sure water level was high enough. Some may say ewww, but I reused some of the rinse water from previous load to wash this load. My clothes aren't soiled badly, and the water was clear. I used a 5 gallon bucket. I have a small cheap walmart end table that's just higher than the bucket, sit it next to my bath tub, and use my shower head to fill it. I also picked up a 10 foot outdoor extension cord at walmart. It's a light duty I believe, rated for 13 amps. I think the back of the washer says it uses just over 13 amps(?). I've checked the cord plug, it's not running hot/warm, have had no issues. I drape it over the shower pole and up the top of the bathroom door.

Washer is easy to use. Oh, the directions....Even with my reading glasses, I can't read them. Print is itty, bitty, tiny, small. And was written by someone with English not as their first language, but what you can read of it was kind of amusing. Fortunately I'd done enough research and a bit of common sense, I had a very good idea of what to do/not do.

-Most important, research this washer. It's not an automatic or a typical washer. Lots of videos here and on youtube. They'll show you exactly what's needed to be done to use this. Some people can't or don't want to do the extra work. Some of us don't mind it.
-Yes, you can use the wash/spin at the same time. Make sure drain is closed/set to normal. There will be some water come out from the drain hose from the spin though.
-Use soap sparingly. Lots of suds is not a good thing, it does not equate to clean.
-Do not overload washer or spin part.
-Overall it's quiet, but depending on the load, and what it's sitting on, there may be some vibrational noises-just an FYI for those in upstairs apartments. Saw someone mention using a rubber mat to help absorb the vibration/sound.
-Be mindful, especially those with RV's or septic systems, each wash fill up that's full will be using about 10 gallons of water, and depending how you rinse(in the washer part or the spin part-another 10 gallons in the washer part. I'm still trying to figure out the best way to reduce the amount of water being used. Need to figure out how to rig something up to use the spin part for rinsing since hose won't fit from my shower to the intake part. For now, I'll just reuse the rinse water where I can, maybe even use some for mop water.
-It weighs about 25-30 lbs. I don't find it heavy, but I'm used to lifting heavier items. It does scoot easily on floors too. Look into a furniture dolly, about 13. at Home Depot if you have trouble lifting/moving.

title: Some manual work but TOTALLY BEATS GOING TO A LAUNDRY MAT with a bag full of quarters!
text: I got this yesterday and have already done about six loads between last night and this morning- it is great! For a single person with a small apartment I am beyond excited to have this. The wash feature works really well and the dryer actually does drain out most of the moisture. I had to leave clothes on a drying rack over night for them to try off completely, but that is it. I also did buy a universal hose so it would reach up to my shower head- the one that comes with the machine is really short and does not fit with most hoses. I watched the videos before buying so I knew what I was getting into and the videos were very helpful! Excited not to have to get quarters and haul my laundry to the laundry mat!

For every wash, I put the water twice . First time with soap and the second time with scent boosters. Then I will dry clothes on a drying rack. We are a family of 4, this size will hold 2 days cloths of u.

title: Awesome so far
text: I love the washer dryer combo so far. The hose attachment for filling water is small but I used my shower head hose by removing the head and it fit perfectly. Just remember not to use alot of soap I only say this because my hubby did and it took 4 rinse cycles to get it out lol. Now the dryer part was different to fully get the water out I had to turn it to 5 min 4 times and by the 4th it was perfect. Now it won't be fully dry so you have to hang it up for awhile but not long. It's a great apartment size washer and dryer

title: Great apartment washer
text: Great little washer. It's just me and my daughter and we love this. It makes life a lot easier. No more laundry mat. The hose supplied socks but we put it in the bathroom and use the shower hose to fill it up. And the drain hose just goes right in the tub so it easy to drain. The spinner is amazing and it really spins the water out of the clothes. I am going to find a way to make another hose some day but for now it's working great for us doing it this way. We have washed a few small blankets to it worked great. You do have to watch you load size but we use the rise water to wash the next load. It saves on a lot of water. Tip do your colors first so the water from The dark clothes don't bleed in to your clothes.We do towels a but three at a time. We just wash about three or four loads with the same water. I figured if I was doing a normal load they would all wash in the same water anyway. We do the rinse the same. And no problems. This will save you guys  a lot of water. Washed tennis shoes in this two. You have to figure out how they go in the spinner so it will spin on balance but it works. Put my daughters shoes in the open window and they were dry in just 2 or 3 hours.

title: Total waste for me
text: I only used it 3 different times and it broke. This was around summer so I only washed light and thin clothes in the washer so I don't know why it stopped working. I spent too much money for this machine to break down. Customer service is horrible. No responds. Would not recommend.

title: This Company Get 5 Stars

The spinner is excellent! Your load will dry quickly because the spinner removes most of the water. Their customer service is excellent! Sent several inquiries, they respond very quickly and assess the problem to give you a quick resolution. Would definitely Recommend!!

title: Best toy ever!!!
text:
I did 4 loads this evening. Thank you everyone for such useful reviews! I hope it lasts. If so, it is definitely a game changer. I could have saved a lot of money if I had bought this year's ago. Definitely use it in a bathtub. I used my shower head to fill it. This is perfect for a single person such as myself. I will keep you posted if anything develops.
For the record, don't bother reading the directions. Read reviews, or watch a you tube video. It will suffice. Also, I recommend using eco-friendly detergent/fabric softener.

title: Wash away!!!!
text:
What a powerful mini machine!!! It’s perfect for my small studio. Easy to use an not expensive! I do recommend this machine!

A year later and my washing machine is still working well! I felt I needed to update because some reviews said the machine gave out within a few months. Key to this is remember it’s a mini washer, do not over stuff it with heavy garments. Good for undergarments t shirts thin sheets an I work in a hospital so like 3 scrub outfits at a time. The washer is powerful spin is great! Just don’t over stuff it.

title: Good machine for lighter loads
text: We have had this machine for about 2 months now and it works really well as long as you have the correct set-up. We have custom built a wooden shelf/table to set this machine on and the tube leads down into a plastic storage container (for under the bed use) which catches all the water after it drains from the washer/dryer. This method works really well but lifting the tub of water into the bathtub is difficult to do alone. It does a great job cleaning the clothes but things like towels are much too heavy for the washer and dryer I think. Very user friendly and easy to figure out. So far so good!

title: Noisy product
text: It was a noisy product with the poor quality. I had to return it.

title: Portable Washing Machine
text: The first time I used this product,  I noticed water on my tile floor.  Later when I went to drain it into my toilet, only a very small trickle came out. So I got a low basin and had to drain it in increments.  This is a very labor-intensive product to use.  More water came out from the bottom somewhere when I drained it.  This is not a very nice product. I would never recommend it to anyone else.

title: Great machine for cost, light weight, effective
text:
We have twins on the way and didn't have a washer in our actual apartment. This is a realistic and cost effective purchase for our growing family. I am really happy with how clean it gets the clothes. Spin cycle gets clothes almost dry! Quiet and quick, makes daily laundry much more manageable.

Keep in mind:
-I did have to build a stand for it in my bathroom to enable the gravity drain.
-The fill hose provided does. not work, had to get an opinion to fill machine.
- need to consider your drying options, I am hanging after washes. But sometimes it takes longer than expected to fully dry some items.
- The instructions provided are very confusing and I had to search for a how to video to ensure proper and safe use. Seller should consider revisions on instruction booklet.

title: You certainly get what you pay for
text: I’ve had my unit for about 3 months now. It works good for what I need it for and I find that I can do quite a bit of laundry in a short amount of time. Just like all the other reviews, the hose that they include is trash and won’t hardly work on any fittings. I’ve also noticed that my unit doesn’t work at all when I put it on the “soft” setting. Not sure if it’s there strictly for looks or if I just got a defective unit in general. Overall I’m very happy with the overall functionality of the unit

title: Nice product
text: Washes clothing well. A hassle to hook up to a hose that fits. Wish it was a heated dryer instead of air dryer, but all around great product for a small apartment.

title: It's loud. It's really really loud!
text:
It came to me dirty on the inside and out, and looked like it had been used.
It washed clothes fairly well. But good lord it's loud! I've done every thing I could possibly think of to lessen the noise. All my efforts have reduced the noise to around 40 to 50%. And it's still to loud.. I only use it mid day when every one else is at work hoping I won't get complaints from my neighbours ( I'm still anxious I'm going to get a noise complaint though). To give you an idea of just how loud it is with all my noise abatement stuff on, you can still hear this washing machine 2 apartments over. TWO APARTMENTS OVER!
Being disabled I really needed this. I really wish I could get my money back. It's going to take me a while to save up again to get a different washer. Extremely disappointed and unhappy.

title: 4 out of 5 mostly because the hose for filling is useless
text: I love this mighty little washer!! I wash several loads in 1 day at my own pace while I'm home doing other things around the house. Great for emergency washes like if your child gets suddenly sick and throws up on everything..  I've had this machine for almost a year!! I love it so much I am buying another washer and giving my sister my old one to use for the new baby so she doesn't have to bring the baby clothes to a laundromat. It took about a month to figure out the best way to wash our clothes but I use this for 3 people, 2 adults and 1 child. I wash a week's worth of clothes in 1 day, I hang the clothes around my apartment on hangers, I have an over the door clothes hanging system a canopy bed that I hang the clothes around the frame and if I run out of room I just use the shower curtain rod. You can soak the clothes if they are extra dirty, sometimes my husband gets his clothes extremely dirty from work, so I soak them in moderately hot water for 25 minutes with a tablespoon or laundry soap (I don't actually measure just kind of eyeball  it) wash the full 15 minutes, drain the water, rinse for a minute with fresh water, then refill tub with fresh water and maybe some fabric softener, wash for another 15 minutes then spin dry with water for 1 minute then respin for the full 5 minutes. The clothes come out just barely damp, way dryer than the laundromat! I also use Downy wrinkle releaser spray for when they are drying to keep the clothes softer. I only use a small amount of laundry soap maybe like a tablespoon, it does go a long way! I have it stored in my bathroom and the set up is super easy I use 2 upside down milk crates in the tub with a piece of plywood to cover the top of the crates, I put the washing machine on top of that so the hose can gravity drain right down the tub drain. Also my husband and I went to home Depot and got a few hardware pieces to make the filling much easier, I used some tips from a previous reviewer, we got a split for the shower head and an adapter that we attached a hose to. Also the split for the shower head I just pull up on the nob to switch over to the hose, the push it down to switch back to the shower head. I really recommend this amazing machine totally worth the price and I'd say get the warranty just in case totally totally worth every penny!! Also since I've had this machine I've still gone to the laundromat a hand full of times and have regretted it everytime!! Mostly because of lost socks and how extremely and grossly soaked our jeans come out!! I also refuse to dry jeans at the laundromat I always  bring them home and hang them to dry. Also another til my husband is 6 ft tall and wears a size 40 in jeans/pants/shorts so I am able to fit 1 pair of his big work jeans and 2- 3 of his tshirts in 1 load and they wash beautifully. You really want to make sure that you clothes can spin freely to wash well so don't overstuff! And water level depends on how big your load is I generally fill between the medium and full line.

It’s awesome!

Watched another person's video review and I agree the water inlet hose does need a better attachment it's not so easy to find a place to attach to a faucet or spigot and would be nice if it had a more Universal attachment and came with possibly two hoses instead of one for attachment for the rinse cycle and the wash cycle. title: Best investment ever!
text: So glad I ordered the washer/dryer combo. The only thing missing is good hoses and better instructions But I spend several hours doing laundry and found it to be easy to use. Clothes do come out very clean. The spinner does leave the clothes too wet but I'm still learning. Thank you!

title: Can't believe how well this works
text: I bought this to take with the family on a week long trip to the river and then to permanently live at my hunting cabin. I was pleasantly surprised with how well this thing cleaned clothes. I was even more pleasantly surprised with with how well the spin cycle removed water from the clothing. The clothes came out of the spin cycle almost dry. The only caution I'd advise is for people with soft water. Err on the side of too little detergent. This is a small tub, so a little soap goes a long way. If you use too much by mistake, you'll have to rinse multiple times. A tablespoon of liquid detergent is really about all you need to get the job done. I highly recommend this product.

title: Already Love It!

title: so good. Doing my second load now
text:
So far, so good. Doing my second load now. Clothes seem nice and clean, spin cycle works great.

NOTES FROM A LICENSED ELECTRICIAN:

1. Do NOT use this on anything other than a Ground Fault Interrupter (GFI) plug. That's the kind in your bathroom with the push button in the middle. Cuts the current if a short is detected. Lotta water, lotta current, lots of potential shorts, Chinese make, so a bit dubious on the safety end. You could die. Probably not, but you COULD die.

2. Drop it in the tub, no need for a table. It's light. A normal woman can lift it empty no problem. Do your thing, put it in the closet etc..

3. Wear rubber soled shoes (flip flops, trainers, etc) while you're using this. Water gets on the floor, dry it up. & if you don't have GFI's & you're renting, take pictures. Your landlord is probably violating code, & you can maybe hold that over him. If you own, get GFIs bathroom/kitchen because DUUUUUUUUH.

title: Adorable small washer
text:
Don't expect to fill it to the brim with cloths and water and walk away to read a book. This is a great little machine that does an awesome job for small loads (think 1 complete outfit). Washing load is 10 pounds of cloths and spinning is about half that. The drain is gravity fed so you need to place it INSIDE a tub or shower when operating!
I fill up the washer, load a few things, add 1 squirt of detergent, set for 5 minutes, and let it wash. I do have to open the door with caution to untangle the cloths. Once wash ended, flip the switch to drain, once all drained, flip the switch back to wash, fill the bin with water to rinse. Set timer for 3 to 5 minutes. Once it 'rinses' the cloths, I transfer half the load to the spinner and set for 3 min to spin.
We use this is our 27' camper trailer. It weighs 37 lbs and we place it in the shower to use. During a three week trip we used it many times to wash our cloths, after the spin cycle, the cloths hang over night are are completely dry in a few hours. LOVE this little machine.
The base was broken when it arrived but we were leaving the next day so Hubby taped it up since we did not have time to return it.

title: As incredible as everyone says
text:
Third update:
I have been using this washer for three years and I am still happy with its performance. Sometimes it leaks a little bit out of the foot in the back on the washer side, but I put some plastic underneath it and it’s good as new. My partner just moved in with me and I am showing them how to use this janky, majestic machine. It’s a family heirloom. Best $100 I ever spent.

Second update:
I have had this washer for over a year and continue to launder all my clothes, towels, and some queen-sized bedding (sheets and duvet cover) in this glorious machine. When I overspend on Amazon purchases, I think fondly of all the money this washer has saved me and I don't feel as guilty. I love this washer and will immediately purchase another one if it someday kicks the can.

Updated review:
I have had this washer for six months. I am a single person with a roommate. I have washed all my clothes and bedding with this washer for the past six months, and my roommate uses it weekly for sweaters and underwear. I remain impressed with this product. It truly changed my life and saved me from the coin operated laundromat. I have also saved a ton of money since my landlord pays for water.

My roommate used some tubing from an old aquarium to fill the washer directly from the utility sink nearby. While the bucket method worked perfectly well, this is better for my back. I am also able to use the spin cycle with clean water flowing through it. I will do this with smaller amounts of clothes, but for bulkier items I still use the method below, where I do a second wash in clean water to rinse them better.

Get this washer! I wish I had found it sooner.

Original review:
I have had this washer for a month and it is incredible for the price. The spin cycle rings so much water out of my clothes that they line dry faster than when I line dry clothes washed in a regular washer. I have elevated my washer using a cheap IKEA coffee table, and I use a bucket to fill and drain the water.

I read and watched several reviews here on Amazon to learn about how different people made this less-expensive washer work for them. Here's the formula I've been using successfully: I wash the clothes with soap for nine minutes, drain, spin dry for about one minute (usually needing to divide the load into two), then I wash the clothes again for nine without soap and spin dry for three minutes.

If you have the space for this washer, you should definitely buy it. It's been a game changer. I even washed towels in it!

title: Great value for the price - washer works wonderfully, dryer is OK
text:
[[VIDEOID:17208bca5f1737fa52db9c606755afe4]] Like most people here, I bought this washer/spin dryer combo because I was sick of lugging my laundry to a community laundry center and shelling out $$ every week to clean my clothes.

I love this washing machine! It gets my clothes clean quickly and fairly easily. It definitely takes more work than a traditional washer/dryer, but a lot less work than lugging your clothes somewhere outside of your home.

The instructions are fairly useless, so I watched all of the review videos here, which were fairly helpful. There were some questions I couldn't answer easily, like if you run water while the dryer is spinning or before hand, and I have created my own review video that I hope will address any questions not answered in videos by other reviewers.

To make the water tube work, you will likely need to adapt it as I and others have. I was able to get it to work with my shower head thanks to the recommendations of Vijay Bhatia (another reviewer.) I personally had difficulty finding the parts as he named them, so here is a written list:

- 1/2 inch coupling
- hose clamp big enough to slide over the coupling
- 1/2 inch nose adaptor (may also be referred to as nipple)

Small correction to my video: the nose part of the adaptor goes into the tube, not the coupling. The other half of the adaptor should screw into the coupling, then the other half of the coupling should screw into where the showerhead was.

As mentioned in my video, I was not fully satisfied with the dryer on this machine. It does a great job of spinning out excess water, but your clothes will still be damp and you will need to hang dry them. I tried hang drying and my clothes ended up being very starchy and uncomfortable, so I eventually splurged for a heated dryer - a Panda Portable Compact Clothes Dryer (PAN60SF) w/ 13 lb capacity.

Why the five stars, then? For the price, the machine is a top performer. I would recommend it to anyone who wants a washer but doesn't have a hookup for a regular one. Just make sure you watch the review videos so you know what you're getting into. Combined with the heated dryer I bought, this machine satisfies my laundry appliance needs.

I was NOT compensated for this review and I paid full price ($105.99 at the time) for the product.

title: Wonderfully simple washer, just needs
text: Works great! We used a two part coupling from Lowe's to connect the fill hose to our shower pipe. The first piece, BrassCraft part number 125-10-8x p, connects with the 'barbed' end into the narrower end of the hose. The second piece, BrassCraft part number 207-8x p, connects the first piece directly to the shower pipe. If you have a handheld type shower head that detaches from its hose you only need the first piece, but we got both just in case. Connecting the hose to the pipe is necessary if you want to rinse the laundry in the spinner. The spinner does not run with the lid open so there's no other way to rinse while spinning. The hole assembly was less than $10 and is significantly more convenient.

title: Best product at the right price

title: I love this thing for the price
text:
I have washed a couple dozen loads with this machine, so it has already paid for itself compared to the (creepy) laundromat at my apartment complex.
Pros:
It cleans really well, better than any conventional washer. It is well-designed for forcing water through your clothes without the harshness of an agitator in a large machine. It's gentle on your fabrics.
My dirty laundry no longer piles up until I'm "in the mood" to do laundry. I use it as a hamper and when it gets 2/3 full, I run a load. This could be a pro or a con, but running small loads more often means dirty clothes don't sit around. I need to wear a company shirt at work, and I only have three of them, so this washer comes in very handy.... No more hand-washing something I need tomorrow.
Cons:
The hose it comes with is cheap and useless. I fill the machine with my shower sprayer and run the machine in the bathtub.
Because of the incline in bathtubs, it woudn't work because the surface is not level. I used a sturdy plastic chip-and-dip platter underneath the right side of the machine to make it level.. Weird solution, but it works. I'm plumbing-challenged and didn't want to bother with complicated hook-ups for filling and draining. It's easy to lift in and out of the bathtub.
This unit will not handle large, heavy items like comforters, throw rugs or a load of towels.
It is not an automatic washer. You have to wash with soap, spin, wash with no soap and spin again. It is not a dryer, but your clothes come out only slightly damp. Hang them to dry and they come out smelling good.
This is not a family-size machine. If you have four kids, you'll never keep up with the laundry. If it's just one or two people, this unit is perfect.

title: Giantex Costway Portable Washer Working Out for Me
text:
Writing this review for others thinking of purchasing this portable twin tub washer. Reporting about my happy purchase now six months in. I was washing a lot of lighter weight or delicate hand-washables. That meant I used to wring my hand-washed clothes by hand and it started to hurt my hands and my wrists doing so much wringing out of hand washables... that's a way to get carpal tunnel.

Machine was delivered early Jan. 2021. I placed the machine in my large shower stall because I happen to have one of those shower benches in there. I usually lift it and place it on the shower floor to use, and put the extended drain hose down the shower drain. I measured and bought an extension cord that was right for my needs. I did purchase an additional 3 ft. drain hose as I didn't want a super long one. I was able to cut the add on hose end off to feed it into the existing drain hose.

So, I'm happy to report my Giantex Costway washer is working out for me. I am careful to not overload it and so far it's worked fine. The cycles I run are usually under five minutes, as it's a very efficient machine. I used it today---- I did 3 tee shirts, 1 thermal long sleeved larger tee shirt, and two long nightgowns, so 6 items I don't have to lug to the laundromat. It gives an efficient wash. I noticed it agitates in one direction, pauses, then agitates in the opposite direction. Neat! I can do a normal or soft wash cycle. Then, drain, refill with rinse water, agitate, then once rinse water is drained with water going right down my shower drain, I move the clothes to the spin side. I hang the clothes, but this little machine spins the clothes almost dry. I looked into the mfg. co. , got the extended service, and did a lot of research before I purchased it. I sure hope it keeps working.

title: Love my washer so far.
text:
05/15/20
Purchased it a month ago, used it about 3x already and works great.

Pros : Washes very well, spins really well almost dry. Portable indeed, fits mostly anywhere and it isn't heavy.

Cons: Spin side can get pretty noisy (don't overload to avoid the shaking and sound)
The hose is short and it drains with gravity (which it is explained in the description)

Tips: Get a hose adapter.
Small table or stand wide enough for the machine to stand on so it can drain completely (I suggest tilting it towards the left to completely drain before putting it away so water doesn't sit at the bottom).
Extension cord.
Clothing rack.
If you don't already do this (separate clothes before washing; shirts , pants, jeans etc into small loads so machine doesn't over work).

Great buy!

title: Apartment dwellers read my review to avoid trial and error.
text:
I have wanted one ever since I got my first apartment without a washing machine, now my life is complete and I no longer have to hang with the weirdos at the laundry mat while handling my undies in public. It's perfect!

It took some maneuvering to find the easiest way to make it work in the apartment but I eventually found some things that I think the average user living in an apartment would find helpful.

1 - In an apartment; set it up right next to the bathtub. Hauling water is no fun. At first I thought a 5 gallon bucket would be sufficient but as a 5'1" 100lb girl, it was not. To do this you are going to need to find something to set it on that makes it higher than the bathtub to allow the gravity drain to work properly. I got lucky and found one next to my dumpster (seems like every time I pray to the dumpster god he provides) but my original plan was to go to the Habitat for Humanity Restore (if you have one in your area) or look on Craigslist, you can get an old kitchen wall cabinet that's almost the same height as the bathtub. The cabinet adds more useable space under the machine for storing items like the detergent and toilet paper. PRO TIP: save the foam from the packaging to place under the washer to keep it from bouncing around. Don’t forget the drain hose can be moved from one side to the other as well, just look on the back of the machine you’ll see.

2 – If you are following my advice, you have it right next to the bathtub so don't bother with the plumbing. Like everyone here says, the included hose is short and it won’t fit anything American and chances are whatever water source you hook it up to, you will also need it for something else. If you plan on still being able to wash your hands or take showers and you have a washing machine hose in the way you will constantly have to hook up and unhook it. It’s a pain and there is a much easier way to do it. If you have an extendable shower head, use that instead. If not, it's an easy upgrade and you can get one for less than 10 bucks. But why not go ahead and spoil yourself and get one with multiple settings for your personal showers. Kill two birds with one stone and get a massage in the process! You need a hose that will reach it, so 5' minimum if yours is set on the opposite side of the tub from the showerhead. (Mine was) This is probable because the plumbing is usually all in the same wall so therefore your toilet will also be on the same wall. 5’ is standard for most shower heads, but be weary, I came across a few online that were shorter (non-American) so pay attention when you are shopping. I got mine for $19.99 with 5 settings. It was as easy as unscrewing the old one, adding some plumbers tape and screwing the new one in. My roommate thought I was a home construction wizard… ;)

3 - ONLY FILL 3/4 FULL WITH CLOTHING! The washer works great if you don't overload it. The ratio should be about 3/4 clothes - 1 water. If you have something heavier like jeans in there keep an eye on it and make sure it’s able to spin. I have had to pull heavier items out a few times, or go in and separate things that have knotted together and become too heavy. Examp: my bra can get tied to a sweater and it becomes a ball of sopping wet heavy clothing that’s hard to separate. After a while you’ll get a feel for what not to mix and how heavy is too heavy to spin.

4 - USE LESS DETERGENT! In a regular washer you wouldn't see the amount of soap that gets left in your clothing but now you will. 1. The washer is smaller so you need less, 2. You probably already needed less than you were using. I barely add any now. If you have soap residue left in your clothing your clothes will be stiff because you’re not going to tumble dry these in a dryer to soften them up. See number 7.

5 - USE VINEGAR. I know it seems like it would be smelly, but it’s not it washes right out if you don’t use too much. If you don't have a dryer, lint is harder to get out of clothing. Vinegar separates the lint, hair, etc. from the clothing. You'll notice more lint in the trap after using vinegar in your load. And don't forget to keep that trap clean!

6 - Winter use drying - It would be lovely to be able to place this outside to dry, but either you don't have an outside or the weather prevents it. So set up a space with full circulation to get the fastest dry. Hang pants from the bottom (see pic). It dry’s much faster, also spin that extra minute. I’ve noticed if I spin about a minute more than what’s necessary to get most of the water out dry time is decreased by about a full day. Usually you can remove some of the lighter items from your dry rack in about 6 hours to give the heavier items more air space. With this method I am able to get clothes fully dry within 24 hours.

7 - This one is counterintuitive because I’m going to tell you the opposite of what everyone else is going to tell you. Wash cold/rinse hot or warm. I usually do it like this: 1st wash cold with detergent, 2nd wash is a rinse with vinegar to remove cat hair and lint and break down the rest of the detergent, 3rd wash hot with a small amount of fabric softener and some essential oils for the smell good just washed feeling. Here is why. The last wash leaves the clothes warm/hot and they dry faster and warm water softens the material and it doesn't leave them stiff. You can do all hot washes but your electric bill will go up. This took some trial and error and my clothes were very stiff the first month of using this. Finishing it in hot water and using vinegar made all the difference! After the clothes are dry just whip them out to get the last of the stiffness out, like snapping a towel at a bare butt, you know what I mean... It’s how I compensate for not having a dryer to tumble them in. I thought I was going to have to live without fluffy towels from here on out but using this method got my towels fluffy again!

I’ve included a pic of how much dirty water is coming out of clothes to prove how clean my laundry is getting.
Hope this helps!

title: Defective Product
text:
We were so excited to try this little machine after carefully reading the reviews and watching the videos. We received it quickly and were excited to use same day. I noticed the machine's exterior was dirty and scratched in places as if it were used. The hose that comes with this is basically unusable. We filled the machine using a a detachable shower-head. I carefully selected the test batch of three light shirts, 3 cotton sleep shorts, and a few undies; loaded these carefully and evenly and filled the tub with water and a small amount of liquid detergent. Turned the knob on the wash setting and...NOTHING. No clicking noise from the button, no motor whirring, just nothing. We checked that outlet we plugged into was working (it was), that there weren't any switches on the back of the machine we needed to flip (there wasn't), then tested the "dryer" portion and found that it was working. The button for the dryer made a clicking noise and the dry tub immediately started rotating.

Well, the only conclusion we could come to was that this was defective. I had to agitate the wet clothes with a heavy duty ladle, and then i moved them over to the spin dryer. This dryer was loud but effective as the clothes came out almost dry, and were completely dry within an hour of being placed on the laundry rack.

The seller was great about returning the money (minus tax). However, I would recommend a bit of caution to the potential buyer as you may get a dud. The dryer portion worked great, the washer - not so much.

title: STELLAR PURCHASE!
text:
Possibly the best purchase I have ever made in my life.
I live in a small apartment which is a 4 floor walk-up and this machine keeps me from lugging heavy laundry bags up and down the stairs to the laundromat unless the items are really big like comforters.
It leaves clothes super clean and almost completely dry from the spinner. It's light, doesn't take up a lot of space and it's fairly quiet. My only complaint is that the tubes are too small, other than that a Stellar purchase.
Furthermore, the package was delivered in great condition as expected and with great timing. A++ Seller.

title: Great customer service
text: I had a minor issue with the inlet hose. I emailed the seller and they offered to refund me to purchase a new hose elsewhere or to send me a replacement. The customer service response was quick and extremely helpful. The washing machine itself is easy to use and convenient for us as we do not have the plumbing for a normal washing machine. It is light for me to move it easily to the tub or outside on a nice day.

title: Leakage
text:
The machine leaks water from the seam that connects the main unit to the base. The leak is a small dribble, but I was surprised (and annoyed) by how much water pooled on my floor. I'm considering sealing the seam with silicone rather than returning the machine. Also, the plastic hook that holds the drainage hose broke after 2 attempts to store the hose-very flimsy, so handle carefully.
The wash and spin components are great; better than the commercial unit in my apartment building.

title: Beast
text:
15 minutes for washer and 5 mins dryer for perfect laundry. I personally feel that this machine does a good job than the apartment washer and dryers. Air drying the clothes gives longitivity to your clothes than gas dryers. You just need to do your laundry for 30 minutes everyday and you are done!! Get a clothes drying rack and hang your clothes on it. It takes just 5 minutes of your time after washing and drying for 25 minutes. It takes an hour to dry and jeans take 2 hours to dry. Well, you can also see how dirty your laundry is while the clothes are in the washer. Based on that you can drain and add water again to get rid of the dirt. I wish I purchased this sooner but then better late than never ;)
Things to know:
Drain hose needs to be FLAT to get rid of the excess water. If you are using the drain hose like a roller coaster, then some of the water will be left behind.
Buy a wheel stand if you are going to move the machine from one place to another.
If you hang the clothes with clothes hanger on the drying rack, your clothes almost don't require Ironing;)

title: Perfect for 1 or 2 People
text: Purchased this several months ago for our small apartment that has shared coin-operated laundry in a dank basement. It has paid for itself more than once since then. The washer has small, medium, and large load marks on the inside. I usually fill it with clothes to the medium mark and then water to the large mark so that the clothes have enough room to move around. Otherwise its too cramped and the clothes will not spin in the washer. Half the clothes from the washer will fit into the spinner. The spinner gets most of the water out of the clothes, they do not drip when placed on a drying rack. This washer seems to get our clothes cleaner than a normal washing machine. If you have close neighbors it is a good idea to put a blanket or towels on the floor and a blanket on top of the washer while it is running so that the neighbors are not annoyed by the sound/vibrations. We live in a very cramped and old apartment building so you may not notice the sound/vibrations as much.

Other then hand filling/hand draining it’s really not that bad!!

Also, there is a lint trap that can be a fire hazard if left ignored.

title: Five Stars
text: good

title: Great investment! I am beyond pleased
text:
Let me start by saying this. I rarely leave reviews, but this machine has served its purpose. I was scared at first when reading comments saying it stopped working or smelled like motor oil or was leaking. When mines arrived it had some grass in it, but it does say in the small print that they test each one out before shipping it out the warehouse. I’ve had it since sept 10, 2019 and it is working just fine. I think people don’t know how to use it properly and that’s why they had water leaking when running the machine. Idk. Each person is different. I know for me it works amazingly. At first when running it for hours it did start to have a weird oil smell, but that didn’t make it perform less than normal. It’s not hazardous or anything. When it doesn’t have air flow at the bottom and running long the motor does feel warm, but it’s not going to explode or stop working. This things have way more pros than cons. I haven’t been to the laundromat since. Only time I go is to wash big comforters and expensive coats. This washes just about everything. FYI At the beginning you don’t want to wash colors on normal because it will strip the color. U have to break the machine in a little before doing that. After awhile you can do it without it striping the color away from cloths. And if you do have it on normal just add a nice amount of water . If you aren’t sure of this just keep a light wash until after the first couple of weeks then it won’t take so much dye out the colors from the strong force.

How I filled the machine with water:
I just simply unscrewed the shower head and taped my water cord that cane with it there to put water into the machine for cold and hot. When done , I just unTapped it and screw the shower head back on. Some people made the filling the machine up with water part extra difficult when it didn’t have to be.

TO DRAIN, you must have the machine elevated higher than the place it is draining into. If your do that you should never have any issues. I purchased the extended warranty as a just Incase , but I still haven’t had to use it. This is great to have for an apartment. It’s small to not take up space and it does wonders without running up the electric bill. I had to give this machine a great review. It’s so good that if it did go out i would still probably get another one even if I was upset and mad at the world lol. I’m a very stubborn and picky person so that should say a lot.
