title: Great Solution for Apartments!
text:
I am writing this as someone who finds themselves in a place for the first time without a washer and dryer, someone who is short and doesn't have a lot of strength, and...as someone who was very nervous to make this purchase, but glad she did!

I've had this for about 2 weeks now. I was very worried to purchase this, because I thought it wouldn't work. After reading reviews on here and watching a ton of youtube videos (while at the laundromat!), I decided to buy it and I was NOT disappointed! I have ran this maybe about 8 times already.

I have a few comments that were not covered in review videos:

-If you are a single person, such as myself, do your laundry once a week. Do NOT let your laundry pile up, or you could very well be doing laundry for HOURS.

-The above may seem like a no-brainer, but what they don't tell you is that because the wash time and spin time are so short, be prepared to basically babysit this thing. 15 minutes can go by very quickly, then you're off to start loading the spin cycle..

-Which brings me to my next comment, and why this did not get a full 5 stars from me - the spin cycle capacity drum is very tiny! Why they didn't make it the same size is beyond me! This has been the most annoying/frustrating part, and why I say you have to babysit your machine.
Normally 1 washing load takes me 3 loads to put in the spin cycle, and the spin cycle only lasts 5 minutes. And maybe 5 minutes isn't enough sometimes (although that 5 minutes is as powerful as most people say, and I'm amazed every time how mostly dry they are). It is NOT that I am overloading - but for example, you're not going to want to put a towel and 2 pairs of pants in the spin cycle - the towel will probably be enough to go in on its own.

-Prepared to get wet.
As you see, most people fill it up first before putting clothes in, which means you have to plunge your laundry down. Before they go into the spin cycle, obviously they are sopping wet, which you're not used to with a normal washer.

Tips
-If you are not going to put this in your bathtub or shower, make sure it is elevated for draining. I've seen people use a small table or crates. Unless you are using this outside, you cannot just have it flat on the floor and try to drain it in a bucket without it being elevated - it will not drain, it uses gravity.

-I found a brilliant hack for using the water tube from a video on youtube - get a rubber glove, snip off the tip of a finger, and put the hose through it. Secure with rubber band. Put glove over the shower head and secure with another rubber band. Easy peasy!

-I have not done this yet, but it was suggested to get a lint catcher ball, and I've seen people use those spiky dryer balls in there for more agitation.

-If your clothes are very soiled, it's best to pre-wash them by hand to work on any stains.

-Detergent pods DO work and disintegrate in this!

-Even if you normally don't, use fabric softener. It helps.

Final thoughts:
This washer has already paid for itself for the hassle it saves me from loading up my laundry and going to the laundromat (which is worse when you have stairs!) I wouldn't say it saves me time, but it gives me the freedom of being comfortable in my home instead of a laundromat. But realistically, this is not the end-all be-all. As long as you don't expect that, you are going to be very happy. I knew buying this that I'm still going to have to go to the laundromat for my comforter and big items, and I'm fine with that.

The spin cycle truly is amazing and wrings out your clothes 90%. But this is not a heated dryer. For some reason, portable dryers are twice this cost, but they do exist!

For myself being short and not having much strength, I am able to lift this into the bathtub. I suggest surveying your apartment for where you are going to store this first before buying - luckily my small dining room has enough space to store this while not in use.

I am lucky that I don't pay water at my complex, which is why I felt I definitely needed to try this, but I have read in reviews that people's water bills do go up with this, so be forewarned.

Hope this helps!

title: Great Machine Overall worth the Buy
text: This machine is a very great purchase overall. I really like that its relatively light and easy to carry. The cons with it are not major. First of all, it gravity drains so it must be elevated to drain. I put mine on a little table and put the hose into the tub for easy draining. Not a huge deal but kind of an inconvenience. Also since its semi automatic, you have to manually fill it with water each use which can be a pain if you don't have a hose to fill it. It holds quite a bit of water so definitely invest in a hose of some kind to help if you don't wanna fill a pitcher a million times. The pros are that it actually fits a decent amount of clothes and water. You dont need much soap either, I intially put too much and had to pour water in and rinse a few times to get the suds out. Also, the spinner works very well. After a 5 minute spin the clothes are pretty much dry. It is very easy to use and also pretty quiet. Overall this was very much worth the money spent.

title: The greatest thing since sliced bread.
text:
I read all of the reviews carefully before making this purchase. the plastic tubing provided is a bit flimsy, for the water inlet and outlet. Also, the inlet tube in no way easily fits any kind of sink reasonably. it doesn't even seem to be made to. Also, this thing is, as advertised, not automatic. The tube must be moved from washer to spinner if you want to rinse your clothes while they spin, which is the best way. Clothes must be moved from the washer to the spinner, in batches. If you're a fussy, whiney, complaining type that thinks you're buying a $1000+ automatic washer & dryer, don't get this. This is a shockingly underpriced <$100 tool that makes non-automatic laundering a total breeze. My apartment has no hookups, and the facilities in my complex are too expensive and unsanitary. The Giantex, which I have dubbed Big Momma, is a lightweight, portable, extremely efficient way to wash, rinse, and wring your clothes so they dry pretty quickly on the rack. You get through batches so quickly that you run out of rack room fast. I had to get an extra rack. The washer portion is spacious, has a working lint filter, and the motor really knows how to go. My clothes get SUUUUUPER clean on this, and i only use 9 minutes on the timer for normal loads. And i mean SUPER clean, and SUPER soft.

I used this thing right out of the box because I had done so much research, I didn't even need to read the instructions. I put it up on my kitchen counter next to my sink. I add detergent, pop in clothes, hold the water inlet up to the faucet and seal it with my hand while it fills, (two minutes, max), let it wash, move the wash to the spinner (which RULES. its WAY easier to balance than my stand alone spinner), switch the hose over to the spinner, run the spinner while i send water up to the spinner to let the clothes rinse (just a few seconds of water rinses it all fine), wait till the spin is done, pull the clothes out and hang them. The washer and dryer drains to the same tube. I just put the end of the drainage tube through the handle of the detergent bottle so its pinned in place and water goes into the sink. At some point I plan to go to the hardware store and make an easy little adapter for the hose to my sink, make life even easier. But this thing already makes it easier. If you take care of it, the tubes will last just fine. My unit does not leak at all. Thank goodness no more handwashing clothes, or hand cranking mini washers. Ugh. This is a 1,000 times better. Takes like a week to arrive though, so plan ahead. It's TOTALLY worth the $.

title: Awesome washer/dryer, and even better customer service!!
text:
First off, if you are on the fence about what small clothes washing appliance to buy, you live in an apartment, and you're tired of wasting time, money, and energy on doing the laundry out in a laundromat that'll probably leave you with mental scars from the daily fights there, then this is the washer for you. I no longer have to go out into the madness of the city to try and find a half decent laundromat to waste time and money on, I can do everything from home, the machine will pay for itself in a month or two.

Don't bother with the "instruction book" it comes with. Put enough clothes in to fill the washing tub half way, put in a tablespoon of detergent, and add water via 5 gallon bucket. After adding the first gallon or so, turn the machine to slow, and turn up the timer to 15.

Add water until you see a nice "vortex" or "whirlpool" of water and clothes moving around freely.

When it's done, drain and add in the same amount of water, washing it again for 5 minutes to rinse.

Then move it on over to the drier, fill up the drying bin, and place the plastic grid in the bin ontop of the clothes.

Make sure your middle knob is still set to drain, then turn your spinner to 5 minutes and let it go! (It really helps to keep the machine ontop of the foam that was on the bottom of the unit in the box to keep down vibrations.)

After it's done, your clothes will be somewhat damp, but nearly dry. Air dry on a foldable drying rack (for storage convenience) and give it a few hours.

Point a boxfan at it if you wanna speed it up.

PS customer service is EXCELLENT! UPS lost my package and I didn't see any updates for weeks. Giantex was kind enough to send a replacement. I am so excited to finally be about to liberate myself from the madness of laundromats thanks to these guys! A+++

title: Not worth it

title: Surprising
text:
When I first open the box which wasn’t packed too well I was a bit worried. I’m fighting with extended warranty and parts issues trying get my washer fixed so I needed something to hold me over for a month. First look is it’s all plastic and pretty cheap looking. What is surprising besides having to manually fill and spin only a few pieces at a time to dry and the useless fill hose is that it washes great. Maybe even better than my big computerized washer and it’s quick, 15 minutes, fill again to rinse, then spin bucket and our dryer but the spin works so well it would dry outside quickly. If the washer doesn’t spin the water back and forth you have too little water or too many cloths, maybe 2 jeans and 4 t shirts about and some socks and underwear is about max but that is what I needed.
It was a good purchase for me and maybe the wife and daughter would use it for delicates.

* update* mine starting making weird click noises like something was hitting, then a nut dropped off the bottom. Put it back in and tightened it up and the noise went away.

title: Get ready to change your life
text: I bought this for my uncle and he absolutely loves it! It works like a dream and I’m very happy with. I recommend this 100% one thing that we do different, we don’t fill the spin basket with water we just drain out the soapy water add fresh back in and let it go for 5 minutes the we just put the wet clothes in the spinner and it’s all to go great great washer

You will spend more on this dead paperweight than just going to the laundry mat. Don't buy it, it is made with cheap parts and motors.

title: Great washer
text: Love this washer. At this point think manufacturer would figure out USA pipe fittings.

title: It is a jewel
text:
This is a little work horse..... it works well but one must have patience.... it is not an automatic that most are used to.
Some of the reviews cracked me up..... one said it washed her clothes well but did not really dry them..... it is not supposed to dry them...... a spin dryer is nothing more and the spin cycle of an automatic washer...... it requires a two step process.
One person wrote that after a spin cycle he had to tip the machine over on it side and turn upside down to get the water out..... if the drain hose is laid out in the bottom of the shower or bathtub...... it should drain on its own.
Only spin small amount of washed clothes at a time and they should come out from 50% dry to 90% dry depending on the type and weight of the fabric. I wear under armor briefs and they come out 95% dry...... one pair of jeans still 40 to 50 % wet.
Even if I wear it out in one year it is worth going out to get a new one.
The convenience of not dragging it out to the laundry mat @ $30 a trip makes this a little jewel!!!!’
LOVE IT THUS FAR AFTER 30 days of use!!!!!!!!!

title: Great compact washer/spinner!
text: My wife and I live in our RV year round.  We do not have the space for a washer/dryer in our RV.  We bought this compact washer/spinner have have loved it.  We store it in our bath tub in the winter and do laundry right in our RV when it is cold out.  In the summer we store it in our shed and do our laundry right out side.  It is perfect for us.  The spinner works wonderfully and the clothes come out virtually dry.  We just hang them up for a bit more and usually by the next day they are completely dry.  The washer even stand up to our work clothes.  We can wash fairly decent loads.  The spinner takes smaller loads.  No complaints at all!  We are very pleased with this purchase.  Keeps us out of the laundry mat which is a double bonus!

title: Good. But

title: Works great.
text: Works great.

title: Overall, I'm glad I got it
text:
Overall, I'm glad I got it. We're college students in a small apartment with no washer/ dryer set-up and this little thing works as well as we paid for. It takes a lot of time to do one load, which is my only real complaint. Rinsing after washing is highly recommended before spinning, but it adds like 7 more minutes to an already timely process. However, the spinner works incredibly if not overloaded. The clothes dry quickly, and are well washed!

Tips because the instructions for this are TERRIBLY written:
-There are plenty of good YouTube videos for how to use this thing
-I have found that about 2 tsp. powdered detergent per load with a cycle without detergent to rinse in between works well or the clothes will dry oddly crispy
-If you can, put it in your shower to do the wash. Be very careful of electrocution and be safe, but the draining is so much easier if in the tub
-It will be pretty noisy

title: Best thing I never knew I needed
text:
I'll preface this with, I have a full-sized washer and dryer in my house. However, the layout of what constitutes a "laundry room" makes it almost impossible to use. Not to mention I have mobility issues that makes carrying laundry up and down my spiral staircase very difficult. I got this product to try out in my tub upstairs and it is a game changer. Yes, I have to sit there with it for the 15-20 minutes it takes to complete a full cycle (washing, rinsing, drying) but it saves me time overall and more importantly, pain.
It's a powerful little machine that is easily put in and out of the bathtub and gets my clothes clean and mostly dry. For small items they get totally dry but long sleeved shirts or jeans, not so much. And thats okay! They get dry enough that hanging them for a little bit finishes the job.
One thing to note, especially with winter here - the dryer will not work on your thicker sweaters. I manually ringed out as much water as I could before putting it in the dryer but it was still too heavy.

title: Wow

Filled tub with a little  more than half full of water, added all clothes for the rinse. Repeat drain and spinning. Hung clothes to dry. Very satisfied with the machine. Easy to hook up. Beats going to the laundromat.

title: Works great. I use it 4 to 5 days a ...
text: Works great. I use it 4 to 5 days a week. Towels, sheets, work clothes. Even my bathroom rugs. Have to be careful what items you wash together  because you will have a lot of lent on items you don't want lent on.  I even washed a full size comforter but it wouldn't fit in the spin dry. I definitely would recommend anyone doing that I just wanted to see it it would work. After I wash I just hang them up in the closet with my round floor fan angled upwards and the clothes are dry in about 30 minutes​. Not bad for under $150.00

title: My most favorite item I own!! review gives how to instructions and tips
text:
I first found out about this style washer going to Belize. I loved that my clothes were softer, not torn apart and I just enjoy the process. it is a process but if we invest any money at all in clothes then why not give respect and wash them in a more manual, caring way?! it gets more dirt off my clothing and doesn't stretch or rip things around that middle agitator in standard washers.

Currently my washer is used in my bathtub but will be on my patio when the warmer weather comes. drains out tube for washer. underneath for the spinner

it is a small washer but I'm single, size works for me. me+1 would be manageable. size up if you have more people to wash for.

to use:
fill up with water, add a small loads amount of detergent. powder/ liquid work
put in clothes but do not overfill
wash for however long you need
**WRING** out water from clothing as best you can then place flat in spinner.
balling up or soaking wet clothes WILL NOT dry and also you will get a horrible clunky spin

then
have an additional tub with water and softener in it
when clothes stop spinning, pull them out and place in softener for 1 to 3 mins
**WRING OUT**
place back in spinner
hang dry

1 drum of water will wash my unmentionables and blouses
drain water, refill and new detergent
shorts, leggings, pillow cases, kitchen towels
drain water, refill and new detergent
so on and so forth until all your wash is done

(keep in mind, the loads are smaller so first wash is bras, undies- wring out spin- wash socks and a few tops- wring out spin- last of tops- drain water and wring out)

title: Eco-friendly! Save $$! Cleans your clothes!
text: This is AMAZING! Truly one of the best investments I've made as a single individual in a small apartment. I was spending $8 traveling to the laundry mat, $10 for washing ALONE and another $8 back home every week before getting this washer. That's almost $30 a week/$120 a month!  This has definitely paid itself off. I was concerned the setup would be complicated and maybe I'd need extra parts but after watching a few tutorials on Youtube I realised I only needed an extension cord for this to work for me. The product is less than 30lbs without clothes or water in it making it easy to lift. So I can keep it in my living room closet and easily take it out to use and yet keep it out of sight/the way when guests are over! Like most people, I set mine up in my shower so it can drain without any mess and it's close to the water faucet for filling. For me a load can carrying 3 pairs jeans and 3 pairs tights as an example. A little detergent goes a long ways too so don't forget or you'll be rinsing your clothes out non-stop! I wouldn't say the machine is loud in washing mode but drying sounds kind of overwhelming when it first starts up so I WOULDN'T recommend it near a sleeping baby. Only maintenance I have between loads is popping out the small lint trap and emptying it (which is located in the washing port NOT the drying one). The dryer also doesn't use heat so it won't crank your energy bill. It just spins out the water and really well actually! The clothes will still be damp coming out but shouldn't be dripping. Giving them a few hours to hang dry afterwards they do completely dry. I look forward to keeping this around as I move/travel in the future knowing it's easily portable and works effectively!

title: Great laundry machine for the price
text:
It's a great small appliance to have to save time on going to a laundry mat or using a common laundry area. It's easy to use. I use it in my bathtub as it doesn't drain so well unless the drain hose is directly o the ground. Also bought a shower hose in order to fill it up with water. The attach hose doesn't work so well.

I used the machine on multiple occasions and looks like it does a better job of washing out my dirty socks than the common building machine. Most of my white socks looked dirty until I washed the, in the portable machine. Would highly recommend if living in a small space and don't want to use the common laundry or laundry mat. Keep in mind, you need to hang the clothing to dry as the clothes are still damp after the spin cycle.

title: Great for apartment.
text: This really saves money and clothes are much cleaner than using the laundry room. Is a little labor intensive as I have no space to leave it set up. I put it on a plastic storage container and put in front of bath tub. Can not connect to faucet or shower so I fill it with shower hose. Works great and clothes are so much cleaner. Alternates spin directions. Keep lint filter clean or lint will be a problem. Spin side works great and clothes dry fast. Not to heavy, can lift with no problem. Not too loud for apartment living. Washes full set of queen sheets, three sets of scrubs. Clothes do wrinkle but I prefer ironing to dragging my clothes to wash room. Small loads are fine as it is just me. Do all my wash once a week. Even washed clothes after a mud race and it did a great job. Have had for 6 months and have had no problems with it. Would buy it again for the money I have saved. No longer go to bank for quarters and the convenience of doing laundry at home is so worth it.

title: No more hauling my laundry!
text: Great little washer for the price. It agitates so good that it can tie your clothes into a knot but I found that if you put the was cycle on the slower setting that helps a lot.

title: OMG
text: So this thing is amazing!!!! It washes my clothes so well. It takes out all the water from the spin cycle, leaving it barely damp. My clothes dry with in the day or night if I washed in the evening, probably faster if you set them outside to dry. Its not heavy at all, so I move mine into the bathtub whenever I am washing so that I can drain the water in there. And yeah, I can't recommend it enough!

title: Caution! Destroyed by a Nickle Coin!  Buying Again!
text:
Fantastic little washing machine, Love it!

Mine lasted 4 years before I made a costly ($.05) mistake and broke the machine. I left a U.S. nickel in a pocket, it ended up destroying the spin side of the machine. The coin fits perfectly into the groove on the bottom of the drum, it wore that nickle down to half it's original thickness before the spinner failed.

I really like this washer so I bought it again. Haven't had to go the the laundromat for 4 years. Sure the folks you meet there are interesting, but saving quarters is pretty cool beans as well!

Yes it's a bit of a hobby doing laundry with this small machine, it takes more time. You'll get very good at fine tuning the procedure to get you clothes very clean. This little machine has plenty of power to pound the heck out your filthy blue jeans in the wash side. As for your delicate unmentionables, it will beat them without mercy until all the filth begs to be let down the drain.

On the spin side, it is surprising how fast it spins your clothes getting them close to dry. Just be sure no coins end up in the spin side (especially nickles)!

It's easy to recommend this washing machine, it's a beast!

text: i have had this unit for a few months now, and i don't have any idea how i lived without it! this washer / spin dryer is small enough that i am able to put it right inside my bathtub, which makes it extremely easy to fill with water and drain. i just use my handheld shower nozzle to fill it, and i drain it right down the tub's drain. i am a bachelor who lives in a small one bedroom apartment, and this unit's capacity is perfect for a single guy! i can wash a large 90" x 90" blanket (NOT a comforter) and a pair of sweatpants, a couple of pairs of shorts or a t-shirt in one single load. too small for an entire family, no doubt, but absolutely perfect for a guy like me - and the spin dryer also works great! i bet it removes about 85% of the moisture from my freshly-washed laundry, thus minimizing the amount of time i need to hang dry it... at the time i purchased this unit, it was only $89 - and i consider this as money VERY well-spent!! quit stalling and buy one NOW!!! :)

title: Great Little Basic Machine
text:
I recently moved from a huge house with a large washer and gas dryer to a very small but very cute little apartment that was built in the 1800s. Since its just me, I thought this machine would be great. I did a lot of research before purchasing.
This little machine has been a godsend. I watched a LOT of videos on how to use it and Im glad I did because I was READY.

1. The instructions are hilariously awful. At one point it says to spin the Revolution. I was like.. say what? Watch the videos. Its a pretty simple process.
2. The intake hose is useless. It doesnt fit any faucet known to mankind. You will either have to buy an adaptor but my solution was to set it up next to my standing shower and use my shower head. When I first got it I used a bucket of water. Works fantastic.
3. You need to put this machine upright to drain it properly. There is no pump to drain the water out. It uses gravity. I use two long wood boxes I have turned upside down and it works great.
4. You will find that your clothes actually FEEL cleaner. For some reason maybe its the agitator is better, but my clothes smell and seem cleaner and fresher.
5. Ok so LOTS of people run their clothes with a cycle with soap and then drain and then just put it in the spinner. Thats kinda gross, guys. To do a rinse cycle you just drain the tub and refill it and run a little 6 min cycle to drain the dirty wash water off of your clothes. Thats why rinse cycles exist.

Honestly you guys.. this thing is a 100 bucks DELIVERED to you. It works. Its a simple design, which I actually prefer because its less electronic crap to go wrong. For not having to go to the laundromat or to my moms house for 4 hours while she inspects my clothes and comments on my underwear.. its great. I wish they had these when I was living in NY. Would have saved me MANY trips up my 4th floor walkup with a laundry bag and a granny cart.

title: Worked great for over a year! Then the agitator stopped working.
text: I bought this in 2020 when it was $169. It lasted for over a year and then one day the agitator stopped working. I plugged it in, turned the knob, and I could hear the timer, but it doesn't agitate anymore. The dryer part still works and spins things dry. The belt is on the washer, so I don't know what the issue is, but I've been going to the laundromat for over 6 months now and I am trying to figure out which one to buy next.

title: Yes, buy this!
text: I LOVE THIS MACHINE! I finally bought it and I wish I had gotten it sooner.  Best purchase I've made in years! Great for small spaces, its not too heavy, washes a decent amount of clothes.  Only wish the dry spin side was a little bigger.

title: best buy for the money
text: very happy with this machine

title: Great for small apartments
text: I purchased this item in April. Works great, no problems at all, super quiet, gets clothes cleaner than the community washer where I live, by far. Until today. It clicks, no agitation, no nothing. The spin side doesn't work either. I've kept the lint trap clean, I've been gentle with it, even. I will see what the company says (it is still under warranty) and report back. 200 bucks down the drain? I hope not.

title: Clothes come out dirtier...
text: We needed a washer and dryer for our RV and figured this would be the perfect solution. The machine is small enough to fit in our shower, while not taking up much space when it is not being used. However, after the first few washes the clothes began to come out dirtier than they went in. Almost any piece of clothing that is cotton and/or dark will be covered in dog hair, lint and the clothes still smell dirty. We tried cleaning the wash tub portion with bleach and oxiclean and have had no luck in solving the issue. So, if it looking into a long term solution, I would not recommend.

title: Great
text: We don't have a working washer machine at the moment and usually wash our clothes at the laundromat. But considering COVID-19 and the quarantine, its best to avoid laundromats, and we bought this. Works very good. Smaller loads, obviously, but its better than nothing. It's also nice and compact and we can fit it in our bedroom when we aren't using it. My ONLY issue, if i HAD to have one, is that the dryer is real loud. However, we do have a working dryer so that isn't an issue for us.

title: Great
text: We don't have a working washer machine at the moment and usually wash our clothes at the laundromat. But considering COVID-19 and the quarantine, its best to avoid laundromats, and we bought this. Works very good. Smaller loads, obviously, but its better than nothing. title: This product has SAVED US HUNDREDS of Dollars
text: I have a family of 5(3 children under the age of 2 and 2 adults) and trips to the laundromat would cost me from $80-$100 every single month. This product nearly eliminated the need to go to a laundromat, the only time i wash at the laundromat is when i wash my queen size or twin comforters plus the occasional times we get backed up on doing laundry. My husband and I both love it. It is very easy to use, lightweight, holds a lot of clothes for its size. Anyone who has kids know there is a lot of laundry involved. We have washed crib sheets, fitted sheets for my queen and twin beds burp cloths bibs clothes pillow cases towels jeans stuffed animals. This product is truly amazing!

title: Great little machine
text: I lived on the third floor of an old walk-up building, carrying laundry every week sucked. I got this little powerhouse and while it takes time and effort to use was still better than hauling my laundry up and down the stairs and spending the day in the laundromat. It did get a little loud after about 6 months of use. I popped it directly into the tub and ran a hose from the showerhead and drained it right into the tub drain. I used this for well over a year and my electric bills were not significantly higher and it never faltered. Obviously you cant just toss your crap in like you can a normal washer you have to rinse and spin yourself but if you have limited space and cant afford a full size unit give this a try!

title: Good for some things- not all things
text: I’ve been using this for a month or two now, and I would say if you have to pay for laundry, it’s really good to be able to use this machine for light items that don’t have embedded pet hair on them, like t-shirts, socks, underwear and towels. However, you have to be super careful not to put too much laundry wait in the machine otherwise it won’t spin. About half full or less is your best bet. In order to prevent wrinkles as much as you can, be sure to run it twice, once with detergent (then drain) and once with fabric softener (then drain), before spin drying. It’s a pretty manual process, but it works well, considering I don’t have a laundry hookup and can’t buy my own washer and dryer.

title: Movable, stowable. Space saver.
text: So far I am very pleased. Having recently taken a broken washer to the dump, I have to say it’s very nice to have one that I can move and stow easily. You can’t load it down like the old washer, but it’s pretty handy and it gives me more space in my little house.

title: Great for the price but not for everything
text: I rent a house that doesn't have a washer and dryer. Honestly its not in my budget to be able to afford a really nice one. This is REALLY GOOD for the price. I use it for small loads and I don't recommend it for anything like bedding or towels because it takes so long to get the detergent out and takes so much time. It's really good for small loads of underwear and clothes you may really need washed like dresses, light-weight pants and shirts. Heavy items I wouldn't recommend but it's great for when I can't make it to the laundromat and it fits perfectly in my bathroom cupboard. Hose for draining is too short so I have to leave it in the bathtub it isn't long enough to do it from a sink without getting some kind of extension. Will be great for the summer with bathing suits and it's super light-weight so it can go most places. Easy to lift and I'm not that strong.

title: Tiny workhorse
text:
Game changer for me. I'm not fond of going out and spending time at laundromats. I regret not buying a machine sooner and I'm happy I went with this machine. It's lightweight, easy to maneuver in my small bathroom. It also has handles you can use. It cleans so well, all I had was scent-less detergent on hand and even my most disgusting clothing came out smelling fresh. It can be a bit loud, but I also have it set up in my shower so that probably doesn't help.

But straight up, I've recommended it to so many people already. Its a tight fit for my bathroom, but it fits perfectly in my standup shower.

Only con is the tube you're meant to use to fill the tubs, its very short and rarely fits anything. I'd recommend taking the hose to lowes or home depot and get something better to give you the ability to fill it. I'm just going to get a handhelded showerhead and use that to fill everything.

title: Find another washer
text: Does not clean very well, had to re use it for tge same wash, 2 or 3 times to get my clothes clean.

title: Nice machine
text: I ordered it for my wife a month ago. She loved it so much. No more trips to laundromat. The only problem is that the water outlet hose is too short to reach my bathtub. So I went to homedepot to get a longer hose to connect it. Problem fixed.

title: Not too shabby, but not too good
text:
I'm using this washer in my bathroom in lieu of using my apartments charge washers. It's a pretty good little washer for small loads of laundry, but it does not do well with washing towels due to their weight once submerged. If you want to wash towels you pretty much have to do 1 or 2 alone to get them to spin correctly. Also the inlet hose was cracked on arrival but I use a detachable showerhead to fill it up anyway.

Edit: after 1.5 months the plastic drain tube is also leaking and I can't replace it with a higher quality steel one without taking the washer apart. Will probably return.

title: Best investment ever
text: Fully impressed by our little portable washer/spin dryer we got. Finally got to use it. This was probably one of the best things we got with taxes. I only did 2 loads of laundry tonight which included 23 piece of mine and my husbands clothes and 10 pairs of underwear. Washer works beyond amazing. Spin dryer gets about 80-90% water out. So by morning we will have clean dry clothes. Takes alittle longer then laundry mat. But definitely going to save us money. $20 every 2ish weeks are laundry mat, no more. This machine will be paid off with that math in like couple months tops. Definitely recommend for my friends that go to laundry mats or have to leave house to go do laundry. 😁😃😉🤗😆

title: Mostly great
text: I love the convenience. The noise level is a bit loud. It's super easy to maneuver which is good because I unexpectedly moved into a place with a claw foot tub. I have to place this 24" off the ground to be able to drain. It's light enough that it is easy.

This let's me do a small load or two a week and I'm good. About fifteen minutes to wash and five minutes to spin it out; the spin cycle leaves everything practically dry to the touch. My only complaint is the hose but I've found out that I can hook my hand-held shower head to it and drain it into my tub. I bought a short/wide rolling cart that I place it on and just roll it in and out of my tiny bathroom.

title: NEED A PUMP
text: I LOVE IT!!! But next time I will purchase one with a pump.

title: Works great, lightweight, and perfect for use in quarantine. Just beware it's not super quiet.
text:
Works very well. It does make as much noise as a standard washer so if you’re trying to hide it in a dorm or from your landlord keep that in mind.

The dryer is actually a spinner/centrifuge that impressively gets clothes 90% dry. I hung them to dry and they were 100% dry after less than an hour.

It's made of plastic so it's relatively lightweight and easy to lift in and out of the bathtub where I placed it for easy filling and draining.

I do recommend spinning the clothes then putting back in the washer to be rinsed again. It surprisingly had quite a bit of soap still on them and required multiple rinsing so use less than the standard amount of detergent or you'll be rinsing them out all day.

Overall I'm super happy with it. Very relieved to not have to use my building's communal laundry room during Covid-19.

title: GREAT!
text:
I bought this little fella about a month ago and love it.

I'm and adult and live in an apt. building. The package arrived without revealing the contents inside.
The good and bad side of the machine is that it has some DIY features which give you tons of wiggle room. I set this is up in my bathroom, and use a bowl to manually fill it with water. I try to stay on top of washing my stuff and don't let things pile up because the machine can't handle that much. On average I wash a week's worth of clothes (5 shirts, a sweatshirt, sweatpants, 4 pairs of pants, undergarments) This usually takes 2 loads.
The spin dry portion can't handle too much, so I end up placing no more than 4 pieces of light clothing in there (think 4 t-shirts or 2 pairs of pants, or 1 light sweatshirt). The one time I overloaded the spinner, the plastic lid got sliced off by something. This was totally my fault, and did not break the machine. I use a drop of detergent, and run the machine twice (6 minutes to wash, 2 minutes to rinse). The clothes come out a bit damp or really damp, depending on the material and spin time. I tend to crack open the window overnight, or put the fan on and it tends to dry fairly quickly, so try to do your laundry in the evening.

This has been a huge help in my home, and I haven't been in a laundromat in a month. I washed my towels, though this takes a bit longer and I prefer to do towels and larger items such as bedsheets at the laundromat--which I suspect I'll frequent once every month with a small load.
I recommend this machine to anyone who understands the struggle of having to cart a load of laundry 6 blocks, especially in the winter. You won't regret the investment.

title: the best purchase ive made in a while
text:
I bought this in December of 2020 and I still love it. I honestly can't explain how much of a difference this machine made in my life. I moved into an apartment in August of 2020 that didn't have washers in it, so I had to go to the laundromat. And every single time, no matter what I did, I had a massive panic attack. I just... couldn't handle the laundromat. So I started avoiding going, so I would double wear clothes. I not infrequently bought new underwear instead of going to the laundromat. Just to illustrate what it was doing to me.

Now that I have this machine, I can do my laundry right when I need to and I don't need to have a massive panic attack. I work in a medical clinic, so I'm exposed to a lot of bodily fluids, so being able to do small, frequent loads is really amazing. The spinner gets my clothes so dry that it takes about 6-7 hours for them to be completely dry (regular cotton underwear/shirts. My scrubs take maybe an hour and jeans/towels take longer).

I've found the best way to use it is to only do loads that fit entirely into the spinner, so basically half-fill the washer. Too much more than that and the agitator doesn't really get to move the clothes around a bunch.

It does leave my tub dirty, but again, cleaning the tub more frequently is nothing compared to the damage the laundromat was doing to my mental health.

title: Great machine for travel trailer or small space
text: I have used this machine for 2 r.v seasons a total of 9 months.  Use in my small travel trailer and love it. Place in the shower with 2 garden knee pads under it to cushion. Fill with shower hose, drain into shower base. Spinner pulls out most of moisture and can work as you are washing next load. Great little machine..be sure to use much less detergent

title: My life is better now!
text:
I’ve only had this machine for a little while, so can’t speak to its longevity, but so far: LIFE CHANGING! It’s powerful, seems to get my clothes nice and clean (though do note that if you’ve got pets who shed, some of their fur will remain on your clothes, but I’m fine with that!)

Other good points: it’s pretty quiet, extremely easy to operate, and easy to lift into my bathtub, which is where I now do my laundry. Also, the spin dryer is extremely effective!

title: GREATEST THING EVER!
text: When my Granddaughter suggested a portable washer, I was not optimistic. I was WRONG! This is one of the best purchases I've made in a long time. I was so surprised at how well this works. Gets my clothes really clean , it's quiet and lightweight. We store it in a closet when  we're not using it. PERFECT for apartment dwellers. I recommend to anyone and everyone!!!

title: Quarantine laundromat concerns?  Maybe invest in this portable product
text: We did a test load today.  We just sat in our bathtub (for draining purposes) and filled up the washer tub with water (you don’t really need to use the inlet, unless you want to eliminate the manual function of inserting water).  Clothes smell great and looks clean.  Washer noise is a little quieter than your normal washer but hey, it’s a machine washing your clothes.  Don’t expect whisper quiet functionality.  Spin cycle really works, leaving your clothes just a bit damp for air drying.  Wife is pleased, so am I.

title: Works Well, But Only in the Tub
text: My wife was eager to get this, and we are mostly pleased with it. It washes well, is of manageable size, and is easy to operate. All those are pluses. On the minus side, the spinner is smaller than the washer, so you need to run multiple spin cycles for each wash cycle. That's an odd design choice to me. (Probably done to keep the overall footprint at their size target.) More important, this MUST be run in the tub or the shower, as it leaks. The puddle we found after the first wash cycle wasn't gigantic, but it gave us enough of a warning that we DON'T run this on the bare floor or carpet. As long as you can hoist the empty washer in and out of your tub -- and place towels or sponges under the corners to counteract the rocking motion and the noise that comes with it -- you will be pleased with the functionality and ease of use. Those of highly advanced age may wish to avoid this, due to the need for lifting and carrying. Otherwise, a healthy adult man or woman of normal strength can handle this without any strain.

title: Great machine
text: Great machine, great customer service. Mine came domaged and they gave me most of my money back, I can't complain. Good thing to have, it washes and spins real good. I brought a shower line to connect the hose since it won't fit in the pipe.

title: SOLAR ELECTRIC POWER COMPATIBLE, CLEANER CLOTHES
text: This little power house of a washer is worth every penny.  It works great with our limited solar power battery system.  The clothes come out so clean.  To save on the motor we wash for a few minutes 3-6 then let the clothes sit and soak.  Come back later and wash another 6 minutes then drain then rinse.  The soaking really helps the dirt lift out of the clothes.  The little spinner is amazing, the clothes are almost dry when they come out of a 5 minute spin.  I want to buy another one to have on hand in case this one dies with all the work we are expecting it to do.  So far it is strong and out performs our $1,000.00 Whirlpool front loader no joking...

title: 6 months with a family of 4 and still going!
text:
I've now had this guy for 6 months. I use it almost daily. Our apartment only has pay laundry and with two kids (one in cloth diapers) I have a lot of laundry to do and don't want that extra cost. (Let's see 2 loads a day at $1 each.this guy paid for itself in 100 washes since the washes are about half the size of a normal washer)

I set it in the tub. Fill it with the handheld shower heaD and wash. I can get three days worth of towels/clothing and household laundry done in one day. It takes some organization but I figured it out.

It cleans cloth diapers as great as a full size normal machine. I don't do anything special either. Just a wash and a rinse.

Super happy with this guy. I've even washed a set of king sheets in it with zero problems.

title: Works as advertised, more work but worth it.
text: So far so good, doing my laundry in it. The wash tub holds alot of light clothes, and is very limited for heavy stuff like jeans. Plan on being able to wash 2 pairs of jeans at a time tops, and spinning one at a time. For a single guy who hates the laundromat as much as I do, this is fine! It takes longer to do them, but no quarters and no blaring soap operas. Do reference the videos for solutions on the main sticking point which is the water intake hose not being designed to attach to anything at all. I'd recommend against the bucket filling method because this cuts out the important part of being able to rinse a bit in the spinner.

title: Favorite purchase
text: [[VIDEOID:8fabe3d7158d52d8fb025fd7f31f6a01]] I loved it!!! When the pandemic started I did not want to leave this house. The news made it so hard for me lol. I’m glad I searched this up and bought this because it’s been super useful. One of my favorite purchases. It cleans my clothes well, dries 80% of it (so I hang them), doesn’t leave my clothes soapy (I also don’t put as much soap as I would in a laundry mat). The only con I have is how it connects to the water from my shower. I have no idea how other people do it because the little tube it comes with doesn’t fit the shower hole so I use tape to hold it. It works every time; Scott blue tape. And the reason why I have a little bench is because it super helpful to drain out the water.

title: Big and Easy to Use
text:
So far this washer works amazingly. It’s big, but it still fits in my shower. It’s mostly really quiet as long as you make sure it’s on a completely flat surface. You do need to keep it in a tub or shower for draining purposes, but it isn’t too heavy at all.
The instructions are pretty clear, but I wrote my own instructions for my roommates to easier follow them without all the extra stuff added.
It comes with a tube to connect to a faucet if you want to fill the washer that way, or what we do is just use the shower head.
You can wash a decent amount of things at a time, and you can run in a few times in a row comfortably.
There’s also a little lint trap in the washer and it does work very well.
The only downside is really that the cord isn’t very long, but it still reaches our outlets.
I’ve had this for a few weeks now and it is going great, but will update review if necessary. We did purchase the optional insurance.

title: Best

title: LOVE IT!!!
text:
Love it, love it, love it!! I actually have a working, nice full size washer and dryer. However, I'm looking for ways to try to stretch my money. No raise this year! I found this washer and spinner and decided to try it. It's cuteness factor caught my eye, but this baby does a great job washing! I have been stunned at how much dirt it gets out of my clothes. I can wash my secretary work clothes when I come home and the water looks like I had been out mud wrestling!! My clothing has never been this clean, even with my full size Maytag!! It is more hands on doing laundry but I control how hot or cold the water is. It's done in roughly 15 minutes, although not large loads. But I'm not daily washing small loads in the Maytag now and not wasting many gallons of water and electricity. The cons are the intake tube is worthless, so I use a small bucket to fill it. It's a gravity drain so it has to be above where you drain it. I use the bathroom counter and drain in the sink. I have been thoroughly pleased with the machine, but I will say if I had to do it over, a pump draining system would be nice so I could set the machine on the ground. I hope this one lasts awhile, but when it does bow out some day, I personally plan to get one with a pump, although I really have no complaints with this workhorse! I like to hang my clothes outside. The fresh air and sunshine really make the clothes smell good. But as a backup, I recently got one of the Panda "pod" dryers for hopefully a cheaper way to dry than a 220 electric dryer.
UPDATE: I've had this machine about a year and I still love it!!!

title: Five Stars
text: I like it

title: BEST PRODUCT I HAVE EVER SPENT MONEY ON!!!
text: OMG! I love this little washer. 11 years of going to the laundrymat and washing by hand in the tub in between trips. I am in love. I stayed up to 2am washing clothes yesterday, the day it came in. Dirty drawers never felt more like christmas. It holds a lot more than I expected. So far I have only used it up to the medium wash line, with the strength of the agitator I am afraid that filling it up to the high line might cause the water to spill out from under the lid. But (1) load washed 2 of my leggings size xl, 2 xl womens shirts, mens long johns, 2 boys school pants, 2 uniform shirts, 3 long footed fleece onsies for the baby, 5 t sirt onsies and about 8 pairs of socks... I probably could have fit a few more onsies in there, but I am still learning what works best as a full load. I even did a load with 1 pair of my husbands jeans (hes 6ft). 1 f his t shirts, a bunch of socks, about 4 onsies and some random socks. This I found since the jeans are heavy, you want to make a light load. I had to take a few onsies out because I felt it was too much strain on the agitator. The spin tub is small and you have to split the load up in 2 to spin dry... but the spin dry is fantastic. It gets so much water out. I swear I almost cried when I saw how clean the clothes came out and how dry they were left from the spin cycle.. NO MORE HAND WASHING AND HAND WRINGING!!! I set the washer on a bench and used the sprayer from my sink to fill up the water. This is a gravity drain tub, so the drain has to be lower than the machine. I use a 50 gallon sterilite storage tub to drain the water into, then dumped it in my bath tub. This is difficult, but I was so excited to use this thing, that I havent really thought through the whole "where am I going to put it" scenario. I think it would work best to get a sturdy storage rack for my bathroom and store it next to the tub, and use my shower sprayer to fill the it. I found the hose to hook it up to your faucet to be useless, didnt fit and its so narrow that it looks like it would take a while to fill that way. The largest wash set to the highest water level says it takes 46L ... dude thats 23 - 2L pepsi bottles.. thats a lot of water.  But anyway.. awesome product. If you live in an apartment, I would highly recommend to buy this to anyone.

title: Excellent
text:
Works better than expected. And quieter than expected. That said, the instruction book is horrible - nearly unreadable translated Chinese in a tiny font size!

The one thing I see that is done incorrectly on almost all video reviews is the rinse cycle. Most of these videos tell you to do a 2nd or 3rd cycle in the washer with just water. The rinse cycle is supposed to be done in the spin dryer. That's what the second water inlet is for - rinse water. The drain for the spin dryer is always open, regardless of the position of the switch for the washer. You simply turn the water on and it sprays into the spin dryer to rinse the clothes while they're spinning. Once the drain water runs completely clear of soap, turn the water off and continue to spin dry as needed. Far quicker and uses less water than trying to rinse in the washer tub.

title: "Essentials" use only
text:
Great small washer for camping. Excellent price. Slightly larger than expected but great for washing "the essentials!"

Didn't expect the time commitment. Did a week worth of laundry for a family of 4 and overall it took several hours. A typical load of 2 pairs of jeans might take 40 minutes to wash + hang drying.

Stick to washing the essentials in this thing and use a laundromat to not waste your life washing, spinning, rinsing, spinning. At a laundromat an entire 2 weeks of closes for a family of 4 can take an hour if you know what you're doing.

A couple tips:
- Comes with weird hose that doesn't really fit anything in North America (but it's just as easy to pour water in at the lid).
- Make sure when you use this thing that you wash loads by colors _and_ by fabric type. For example, washing jeans (cotton) with yoga pants (floaty space-age fiber) just doesn't work that well due to the small agitator at the bottom of the wash tub.

Overall - WORTH IT

title: I love mine! It works!
text:
Update 3/02/18
Little washer is still up and kicking. I wash all of my laundry with this. Works great! The water outlet hose did get a little tear in it (probably because its on the bottem) I hot glued it and everything is just fine!

Update **** 10/09/17
I've had my Giantex Portable Mini Compact Twin Tub for awhile now and I absolutely love it. I wash all of my clothes and my sons clothes in it and have for months now. It works very well and it is very nice. It came with a tube to hook up to a water outlet, but its not big enough and honestly too much work to even bother with. I fill my washer by bucket, which really isn't a big deal at all. It washes for 15 mins on normal or gentle cycle.

I've used my Giantex Portable Mini 4 times now. It is pretty decent, it gets things clean. You will definitely need to buy these 5 things separately: 1.) a 3 prong extension cord (the cord on the machine is very short), 2.) an adapter of some sort to hook the water hose up to your sink faucet (the one included does not fit any faucet in my apartment, I bought a chicken baster and cut a hole in the end of it, works sometimes, this part I'm still struggling with), 3.) a little table to set your Giantex on (the draining system is run by gravity), 4.) Lint catcher, ones made for portable washers (the lint is insane). 5.) I purchased a portable dryer (Panda Portable Ventless Cloths Dryer) the spin dry doesn't get the clothes completely dry but it gets them a very good way there so this is optional. Also, something you need to know.. when you unplug the device the system completely drains. I flooded my kitchen because I didn't know this first off. I also flooded my kitchen not realizing the hose wasn't in the bucket when I initially attempted to use it. So PLEASE be more careful than me :/. It is a good device, you are able to wash and spin dry at the same time! I received the package in a good amount of time, it wasn't damaged at all. The device is actually bigger than I expected. I was just able to wash a blanket, 2 towels, 2 pairs of pants, a bunch of socks and undies, and a shirt all in one wash. My sons queen comforter is much to big to wash in this machine, so that tells you the capacity. Overall, good device. A little bit of effort on your part but it beats going to the laundry mat.

text: After watching literally every video demo I could find on YT about theis type of machine I opted to order this one. It's not junk at all but, not near as solidly built as it seemed to be implied. DO NOT use even close to the usual amount of detergent. This machine is terrible at rinsing and you will never get all the soap out. Not using this machine anyway. It doesn't have an inner tub. Only a square compartment. Like some normal size machines, this has a small agitator in the bottom of the square compartment and that's what turns. If the inside was round, it would have to work a lot better. You can't do larger loads or larger items like, work coats or insulated coveralls. The spin dry compartment has approximately half the capacity of the wash side. It does get most things very close to dry in only 5 minutes but, be prepared to do a lot more ironing if wrinkles bother you. This machine would definitely be better than the 5 gallon bucket and plunger method. Lol. I do wish I had stuck to my original intentions and spent just a little more for the one with the round stainless steel inner tub. All in all, this machine is definitely better than nothing, does an ok job but, I wouldn't order this again.

text: Does it says. We use it to wash our baby's cloth. Probably done over 50 loads and so far so good. The frame and casing are all made of plastic so it's really light. A little bit noisy but overall still good value.

title: Some things to be aware of...
text:
The machine is compact (meaning small) and can't handle a full load of laundry. Generally speaking, you could probably fit about five or six T-Shirts and a pair of jeans into it. Anything more is too much. The dryer is even smaller than it's washer, and you will most likely only be able to fit *half* your initial load into the dryer at a time (though the spin cycle for the dryer is also half the washer's cycle, so this isn't too much of an issue).

Buyers be aware that the dryer is a non-heated spin dryer, so by it's nature it won't be able to get your clothes completely dry. Buying a drying rack or a seperate dryer is almost necessary. I would recommend running the drying cycle twice and then putting your clothes on a rack for a couple of hours. By then they're set to go.

The washer possesses a lint catcher, which works, but doesn't work great. You'll find yourself picking lint off your clothes during each wash, but not enough so for it to be considered an inconvenience. (I generally only find lint on a couple of things I put in there, but that's it).

The washer drains via gravity, so keeping the dryer on the floor is a no-go unless you have a large bucket to properly drain it with. I personally put mine in the bathtub and allow it to drain that way.

Overall, it's a washer that functions, and is great for apartment dwellers who don't want to go to the laundrymat every week, and for the price asked for, it works just fine.

title: Better Off With A Rock By A River
text:
We bought this washing unit a couple of years ago to use in an RV. When we initially tested it with small loads of laundry the centrifuge spinner (that removes water from the washed laundry) quit working.

There is minimal online information about the washer and what was found said it was necessary to replace either the fuse, a "connecting switch," or the entire electric motor in order to fix the spinner problem. A continuity tester found the fuse was fine, the "connecting switch" appeared OK, and having to replace the electric motor on the spinner was out of the question because it meant taking the entire washer apart.

We kept the washer because the "washing" side still seemed to work. We lately decided to run the washer to check its status, and as soon as we turned the washing timer dial on, it started and then immediately stopped and failed to run.

The "Giantex Portable Mini Compact Twin Tub Washing Machine" (labeled with the brand name "Costway") is going out in the garbage!

There were many negative reviews of these portable washers when we made the purchase but we took a chance and bought one. In retrospect, buying this machine was a mistake, and unless they've seriously improved these types of portable washers in the past couple of years we would have to recommend that you look closely and think carefully before buying one!

title: Tired of sharing a washer? BUY this then!
text: My husband and I are expecting our first child and are currently living in a apartment. We didn’t want to wash our newborn’s clothes in the shared washer and dryer with the rest of the tenants so we purchased this machine. Clothes came out perfectly clean and just feels so much safer using this for our baby (and us)! We placed the machine inside our shower (we have two bathrooms, so one of them is now called the “laundry room”). We watched a ton of YouTube videos of other customers for tips. The washer has 6 small (about an inch) agitators to help clothes move around while washing. We run the normal cycle twice (each is 15 mins) for a nice deep clean. The spinner looks very small however, when you place the clothes evenly in the spinner and press down your clothes come out about 75% dry.  As it initially “takes off” the spinner is loud and does shake a bit but after a few seconds the machine settles and noise and shaking subside. We propped up the machine on bed risers so the machine wouldn’t be sitting in the water. The bed risers do collect a little water so we drilled 4 holes in them for drainage but machine fits perfectly on them. So far we are very happy with our mini Washer/Spinner.

I do one sheet at a time ( I do have a king size bed) … but no big deal Bc it leaves all my stuff very clean … I let it run for 15 mins… drain the water out…throw it in the spinner to get rid of all the soapy water … refill the water and have it run for another 15 ( without adding detergent the second time) and it’s good to go! It’s a little more time consuming then washing in a regular washer but I can’t beat doing laundry from the comfort of my home and the fact that I no longer have to spend 5-10 minutes sterilizing & cleaning a public washer prior to doing my laundry! title: I just got the washing machine a few hours ago ...
text: I just got the washing machine a few hours ago. So far I am impressed for a washer that is only $85. It seems to clean the clothing quite well. However, there are a couple of complaints that I have about the washer though. First off, the water inlet hose is too short and does not fit on any faucet. Because of this, I have to fill the washer using buckets. Usually I pour in three buckets of water, that is enough to get the water to the medium line. Also, the drain hose is gravity based and does not use a pump motor. So a drain that is lower than the washing machine itself will be necessary for draining. I learned the hard way to *never* fill the water to the high line, because the agitator is so strong in the washing machine that the water will actually start spilling over the seams of the doors. So I consider the medium water line to be the maximum amount that I can put in. I am still learning to figure out the proper amount of laundry detergent to put in the washer. It does not take much detergent to end up with excessive suds, so only a tiny amount of detergent is needed with this machine. I also noticed that the machine arrived with damage to the plastic on the spinner side. Luckily though the damage is only cosmetic.

title: So far so good!
text:
Ok so far it's a good little machine. it's keeping us from going to the laundromat! So I have no complaints there. It is all plastic, but it's fine. I used it 2x with multiple loads. I can get a rather large amount, but I don't push it as I don't want to break it.

That being said, I can't believe the connection to this thing. You will need an adapter or you will have to use an extendable shower head to fill this machine up. I don't have either. So I had to take the shower head off and fill it up that way. Mind you that is potentially dangerous since it is electric, so be careful and make sure it is not plugged in! Or you can fill it with a bucket of course. Also the directions are disappointing and ridiculous! I wish too it gave options and sizes for the correct adapter. But it has non of that!

I can easily lift this myself and when we are ready we could store it just fine. When I want to use the machine I have mine propped up in the tub, on a crate, then I fill it. Prop it up though if you have it in the tub! I haven't been able to go to the hardware store to get an adapter because of all that's been going on, don't want to risk it. So I have to make this work. The spinner works great, but you can't put much inside, but it takes 2 min to spin and I find that the water is drained enough.

The other small complaint water does get left somewhere inside, you have to be sure all the water is completely drained. I just tip it over as much as I can to make sure it is drained. then I leave the top open to make sure it is completely dried.

Other than that, its a nice little machine i can see using this in an apartment, but it is a little bigger than the smaller ones, so unless you plan to leave it in you bathroom, you will need a place to store it it. I recommend watching youtube videos so you can see how it works.

title: Cheap materials
text:
This product arrived on September 22nd. So we're about a month into owning it and consistently using it. The piping at the bottom to drain the water is extremely fragile and cheap. It's got a hole in it already because the washing machine holds this tube up by little clasps, but hey, guess what, those clasps punctured a hole in it and didn't really do a great job of holding the tube up in the first place. It was always falling off when I was moving the machine around. The other tube to let the water enter the machine is made of the same material. I didn't even bother ever using it and just filled it with my shower head since we have it in our shower in our motorhome we're currently traveling in.

And now the real kicker, the spinning side that helps remove as much water as possible from the wet clothes no longer want to spin at a fast pace, leaving my clothes twice as wet as usual and I'm insanely furious that I can't even return this since it went defunct about a week after I could return it.

Don't buy this one. Save your $$, because this machine is DEFINITELY not worth the asking price. I absolutely expect something that costs about $200 to work longer than a month. I was trying to save money and not use the laundromat.... and now I've wasted a ton.

title: Worth it!
text: Overall super great! I use this in my tiny studio apartment about 2-3 times a weeks. The drain works by gravity so I elevate the machine by setting it up in my bathroom on an old IKEA end table. I use a rinseroo to to fill the larger drum and drain water right into my shower. It’s a little difficult to move around so I may get a wheeled cart or utility dolly to move it in and out of my bathroom. Was super helpful during the pandemic when laundromats were closed. I can usually get away with washing about half of what I would in a full sized washer per cycle. I use concentrated detergent and use very little (a couple tablespoons). I wash in the larger drum on Normal for 15 minutes, drain the water, put the clothes in the spinning drum for five minutes to spin the soapy water out of the clothes. Then I put the clothes back into the larger drum with just water for 15 minutes on Normal for a “rinse cycle” and then drain and transfer the clothes over to the spinning drum for 5 minutes. The spinning drum does get out a lot of the water, though it can be noisy. Overall worth the purchase!

title: A few things I don't like--plus shipping delays galore
text:
I think this product used to be a lot cheaper. I watched reviews where people bought it for ~$145 dollars in the past, whereas I paid ~$212 for it (included shipping). I did not like the price, considering it was cheaper in the past and other models and brands have comparable products. However, I bought this one due to the abundant rave reviews.

Also, shipping was INSANELY long. I think it was a weather related delay, but it said it was going to arrive an entire week before it actually got here. And then it said it was going to arrive on a said day (getting my hope up again), but it ended up coming the next day. Not a big deal, but I have a newborn and had a batch of dirty baby laundry ready that day, so waiting longer than initially quoted was slightly frustrating.

Pros:
-Wash setting is not loud
-Fairly large wash capacity
-Simple to read knobs (you can read the manual if you are second guessing yourself, but it really is pretty self explanatory)
-Easy to operate
-Still lighter and easier to move than a regular washer, since this is only 33 pounds. There are even handles/divets/depressions to help you lift it on the side.

Cons:
-Shipping delays
-Price
-Filling hose is not useful. I just fill it a couple times with 5-6 potfuls of water.
-Draining hose is too short. The manual says not to place it near a bathroom or place with lots of water, but it's basically MADE to be put in a bathtub. Unless you rig it or Macgyver something (or use it outside and drain it into the ground), it's basically made to be inside a bathtub. The hose is just not long enough to drain anywhere else, if you don't modify it.
-Short electric cord. I had to use an extension cord, as it's so short that if I actually placed it that close to an outlet, the outlet and plug would get soaked in water.
-Spinner is -loudish- but I'm not sure I can actually complain about that because a spinner would be loud no matter what, I'd imagine, given the weight of the machine versus the force needed to spin and wring the excess water out.

The product itself is a 4/5 stars.
But the cost and shipping delays really killed it for me--which may not even be the seller's fault. But that made the experience a total 3/5.

title: Beats the laundromat

I fill the washer up with a bucket but I read reviews so I expected to do that when I bought it. I’m able to keep it in my bathtub because I only use my standing shower.

It’s a spin dryer people. Not an electric dryer. But it works really well. It’s squeezes everything out so nice I just pop it into my portable mini electric dryer and bam I’m done. Blankets won’t fit in the spin dryer . It’s a little problem for me right now.

title: I'm in love with this washer.
text: I bought this for the camper. Our 1 1/2 year old household washer went out. I pulled it into the house, and  placed it in our claw foot tub.  We used it to help catch up on our laundry.This thing is amazing!!!! I've never before been able to control how much water and laundry soap get used. Our clothes have never been so clean, or smelled so nice. The spin cycle wings almost every drop of moisture out of the clothes. I would hang them on the hooks in the bathroom and with a fan going, they would dry in 1 hour. What?!! Yes! Seriously. It takes 10 to 20 minutes to wash a load and spin dry. I washed all the sheets in the house, curtains, table clothes, small rugs. I enjoyed the heck out of this thing. I did not want to stop using it. Husband insisted we buy a big one and put this back. I can't waite for our next camping trip, so I can use the washer again. Tips: Cut open tide pods. You cannot wash quilts, poofy jackets, or comforters.

title: Great Investment
text:
I got this machine for my mom for her birthday to help alleviate trips to the laundry mat since she doesn’t have a washer or dryer.

First of all, I ordered this in mid/late October to make sure it arrived in time for her birthday which is early November. It came way earlier than anticipated! This is also the best investment I’ve made and I regret not getting this as gift for her sooner!! She LOVES this washer. She tells me it’s so easy to use and is so much more convenient to wash items here and there when needed. She will typically wash a few items as needed for work and has also told me it’s great for at least 1 light blanket (about 46inx60in). She’s even told me that the spin dryer does a fairly decent job of ringing out the water from the damp clothes. Only draw back is, ladies, definitely do not wash your delicates as wires will come out.

My mom puts hers in the tub when in use and can easily store it away when not using it.

I HIGHLY recommend this washer for those who don’t have washers or dryers in their apartments, camping, dorms, etc. It’s totally worth it.

title: Clean Fun
text:
I believe I read ALL the reviews before I purchased this little beauty. Very impressed but there is definitely a learning curve.
First where to put it...the bathtub! How to elevate it for drainage...several tries and finally ended up with plastic shoe boxes. I doubled them up to handle the weight, moved them to the back wall of the tub for stability then placed two in front on the machine to provide steadiness when washing. The boxes in the front are great for holding the clothes as you are moving thru the process. I did use some duck tape to connect the hose to my handheld shower hose the I am able to fill washer and use for the rinse spin cycle if I choose.
I purchased plastic clips that snap onto my hangers for drying. I put up another shower rod to handle the extra weight. Then just put my fan in the bathroom and everything is dry in the morning or when I get home from work.
Once I'm done the shoe boxes stack together and I store any extra stuff in them til the next time.
This is a great investment and for me the laundry is more fun and less dread.
The pictures show my shoe boxes in action, an addition lint filter available on Amazon, the plastic clips and mesh bags (I have several they stop a lot of the clothes from mingling with each other, part of the learning curve I spoke of earlier).
Final note...buy a steamer, very helpful with any wrinkles you need to remove!

title: Perfect little washer
text: Love this! Bought right before we were about to hit the road across the Great USA. I really didn't want to have to worry if RV places had laundry rooms. Have to say this washer has paid for it self! I use the tubing when I'm allowed to use it outside or if I don't mind leaving the RV door open. Pictures show when I use it in tub so I'm not draining soap into grass.  Thats when I use the shower head to fill it.  Either way works perfect! I wash an easy small load (4 shirts, running shorts, running pants few underwear)quick. Its super easy to use TOO...1: load washer side with clothes, water and detergent pick a wash time and start. 2: Then drain place clothes in spinner for 2 mins. 3:Next place clothes back in washer fill with water and select time. 4:Last put clothes back in spinner for 5 minutes and they almost come out dry! If you hang outside dried in an easy 15-20 minutes. If you dry inside dried overnight! I'm probably going to use this once back home for quick small washes!

title: Works well after you figure out inscrutable instructions - but great customer service
text:
This little washer seems to work well for small loads. I used it for socks and underwear; it will probably handle shirts and pants, but not sheets or towels. It requires very frequent attention to fill and empty the tub, move wash back and forth between tub and spinner.
The instruction book requires very careful study to figure out what is meant by the directions. I am used to fractured English in many instruction books written in non-Anglophone countries, but this one is beyond the pale. It would have cost the manufacturer very little to hire an unemployed former English major (or even a bright junior high school student!) to rewrite it in English.

ADDENDUM 4/24/20
I did not mention that the machine came damaged, with a hole in the casing corresponding to a dent in the shipping container. It was ugly but did not lead to a leak. The company nonetheless gave me a full refund, much appreciated.

title: So happy I bought this little machine- works great!
text:
This machine was just as I expected and exactly what I needed. Like a lot of other people, I got tired of going to the laundromat. Living in the Northeast, the winters can be harsh and I was not looking forward to walking in the snow in order to get my laundry done. I've been thinking about purchasing a portable washer for quite some time now and finally decided to go for it.
This little machine is a blessing. It's quick, efficient and it gets the job done.
This little machine is quiet. We live in an upstairs apartment and I am always conscience of our downstairs neighbors. I've lived below noisy people before so I know how it feels to hear nothing but noise, coming from upstairs.
At first I though the machine was loud. But in talking with the neighbors, they said they can't hear a thing. So I am thinking I am just hyper aware of any noises that might bother the neighbors.
I do have to agree with the other reviews, though. The drain hose is too short and the fill hose doesn't fit onto a standard faucet (the fill hose is about the size of a dime). My remedy for that like many others is to use a bucket to fill the washer and drain the water into a 5 gal. bucket. It's a minor inconvenience.
Figuring out how much laundry soap to use is difficult. I am still experimenting with that one.
The 2nd time that I used this machine, I thought I had somehow broke it. I put the clothes into the spin tub closed the lid and set the timer- Nothing happened. I turned the knob back to zero and set the timer again. Still nothing. So I re-arranged the clothes and tried again, worked like a charm. Needless to say, if your load is not balanced in the spin side, it will not spin at all.
I am so glad that I finally decided to buy this machine.

title: Great buy

title: Plastic
text:
Read many reviews and bought it. Read the instructions Placed it where I wanted it and did a test run with water only in the wash tub. Motor turned on but no movement. After trying different things, I emailed the manufacturer. They said take the back off and check the belt. Sure enough, the belt was off, I attempted to put it back in place and the entire motor unit moved. Didn't think that was right but I'm not mechanic. They gave me a full refund and told me to discard the unit! As it turns out, I layed it down and found why the motor unit was moving......cheap plastic (see picture) broken motor mounts. So disappointed.
I will say, customer service was good!

title: Ideal laundry solution for one person or a small apartment
text: This little machine is fabulous. I live alone in a small apartment without laundry and the dirty, expensive laundromat was getting annoying, so I got this and a drying rack. It works perfectly. My method: lower it into the tub, add water (I use a simple pitcher and fill with water from the tub right there, 3 pitchers full to wash and 3 more to rinse) and soap, move to spin, return to the wash side and rinse, spin again, done. My water and electricity bills have not gone up noticeably -- it uses only 6 gallons of water total per load. At a laundromat cost of $5 a load, it and the drying rack combined pay for themselves during load #43, sooner when considering gas and time costs.
