title: Well hello stay at home laundry
text:
I bought this in conjunction with: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01EGN8EXQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 . Here's my take on the whole system. I recently moved to the bay area in California and as some of you may or may not know this entire area is expensive so when I found a nicely priced place with a real backyard I could sit out in the sun and drink beers in I was pretty excited. The only downside: no washer or dryer or any place to put real ones at. I have no desire to sit in laundromats once a week for two hours or have to worry about dirty machines and everything else so I decided i'd look around and after checking things out decided on these two items.

The washer: Yeah the hose to the sink doesn't work, it's short and doesn't fit like it should. Others have mentioned ways of getting around it, i think i'll just buy some hosing, a funnel, a few heavy duty rubber bands, some duct tape and call it a day myself. The power cord is also extremely short, get an extension cord. It works for regular day clothing pretty well as long as you don't fill it up, I expect extra wear on the clothing as a result of this machine though. The spin dry gets quite a bit of water out of the clothing but will leave your clothes very very wrinkled so you will be ironing them unless you like looking like your favorite buddy gave you a purple nurple....except you know.....everywhere. Overall pretty happy with it and as long as it lasts two months i'll be good.

The dryer: I hated this thing when i first opened it. It doesn't want you to succeed in setting it up. But I didn't want to role play a super soaker so I got fed up and took the wheels off the base to make it easier. I then took the cover and put it over one side and put the rods in through the cover on the other side. After that it wasn't so bad. Take the middle bar of the middle rack out. Your shirts and pants won't hang fully if you don't and it just makes them dry more uneven. If you want to add a bit more space I suggest measuring the length from the sides and buying some PVC pipe or just getting some and cutting it then putting it over the middle side racks. (would work well for underwear and socks) It dries pretty well, expect about an hour or two to get things pretty good and dry depending on how full it is. (side note i haven't done jeans yet so yeah that'll be a while) Mine didn't come with the remote but I guess i'll live with it. Some good frabric softener would help make the clothing less stiff when it's done. I was going to put the wheels back on it after I was done building it but I decided I didn't need them. I mean unless you want to wheel around your laundry all the time because you think you're cool you can just pick it up and move it when it's not needed.

As it is i'm happy. I couldn't live in a place where I had to drive to a laundromat every week for very long and I get to pay less for rent! If these machines stay working I've found a decent solution and only have to go once in a while to do big loads or blankets and stuff. (sheets should be fine one at a time in the washer) These things are time consuming and much less fun than just doing laundry but hey I can't complain too much. Best of luck to anyone looking to get away from laundromats like me!

title: It is NOT a replacement for a 'real' washing machine. It's fine, though.
text:
Works for (very) small loads. An outfit, some socks, maybe a towel, too... You'll definitely overestimate the capacity a few times before getting it right.

The spin dryer is actually pretty neat. Things come out mostly dry. On a hot, dry day you can put one of the t-shirts on and it'll be dry in a few minutes outside. One habit I've taken to is running the clothes through the spin between the wash and rinse cycles. I find it makes for better results.

Do bear in mind this will not replace the laundromat or an 'actual' washing machine. If you're doing more than a sheet, or half a blanket, or a quarter or a comforter, you'll need standard equipment.

title: So happy I bought this!
text: After reading reviews and watching other videos I felt like I had a good handle on how I was going to set this up. Its true that the tubing the machine comes with is 100% useless, BUT there's an easy fix! One trip to Home Depot to get vinyl tubing (found in plumbing department, sold in 10 foot pre-cut sections), shower head converter (Glacier Bay brand found in shower head isle) & hose barb adapter (found in plumbing department). I can now use my shower as the water source & not have to continually take off shower head to attach tubing. Just "toggle" between the 2...its great. As far as the capability of this machine, it really is very impressive. I just set it in my bathtub and its fairly quiet, drains easily and isn't too heavy to move about my small apartment when I'm not using it. I hope the pictures I attached are helpful. Good luck!

title: Saved me so much
text:
I love this thing. I’ve had it for about a year so far and it has easily saved me its worth. The only reason I gave 4/5 stars is because of the hose, which didn’t work very well to begin with and after a year doesn’t work very much at all. I instead got a
hose and two adapters, one which connects to the tub and the other to the machine. That has been working fine. The spin dryer gets almost all of the water out, but they still take at least a few hrs to dry. T-shirts can dry in a few hrs, jeans for me usually take overnight. So if your used to drying your clothes right away that might take some adjusting to.

UPDATE: so far has saved me close to $200 in laundry, and I don’t have to drive to the laundromat. still works just as well, so giving 5/5 stars

title: Perfect for a college student that needs to save time and money.

title: If you know what you're getting into, it's perfect.
text:
As long as you understand that this is what it is and not more than it is, it is perfect for what it is.

Pros: It's faster and easier than washing by hand. The spinner gets most of the water out. It's light weight / portable. It's thin and fits in tight spaces (I use it in the hallway of my RV and store it at the foot of the master bed). It uses less water than a conventional washer. It only takes 15 minutes to wash and 5 minutes to spin.

Cons you should already know from reading about this machine: The drain hose is too short, you have to be very close to a drain source. It will not dry your clothes.

Personal cons: The clothes tangle together in the wash.

Overall: I love it. It gets the job done. The only part I don't like is the possible stretching that can be caused by untangling soaked shirts. You just have to be careful.

title: Best Apartment Purchase Yet
text:
I love this portable washing machine. I still need to work out where and how to place it so that I can let the washing bin drain easily after the cycle is done. Currently I just place the machine on top of two stools so that it sits above the tub, although placing it in the tub works just fine, too. Once you work out the kinks of hooking a hose up from your sink to the machine, it's a real dream if you don't have your own washer/dryer units. I found the spin cycle gets rid of a lot of the excess water, and all I have to do is hang my clothes for a few hours (hot/humid climate) and it's great.

I definitely 10/10 recommend this if you were hoping to save a little cash by washing small loads of clothes at home. I've already done several loads without incident and been very pleased with the results. Oh! Be wary of clothing that sheds/creates lint. I put a new sweater in the wash and it created a lot of lint on my other clothes (I think this can be fixed with a lint catcher), but otherwise there are no issues or complaints I can think of.

title: Broke after about 4 months of light use
text:
Bought this during a home renovation that ended up taking much longer than anticipated. The machine is relatively simple and easy to set up and use; you need a water source and drain. Watch the online videos that demonstrate how to set up and use the machine. The amount of items you can wash at one time is obviously pretty small, and the machine can take time to wash anything more than a couple items (wash in one compartment, spin in the other compartment).
When the machine worked, it did an adequate job washing everyday clothes, towels, etc.; don't expect great results on deep stains or very dirty clothes.
Should be OK for an RV, boat, if your apartment/home space doesn't have connections for a standard washer, as an emergency washer, or if your budget doesn't support spending a couple hundred dollars more for a more conventional machine.
Our unit stopped working after about 4 months of light use (2-3 times a week max). Troubleshot, but couldn't find any broken wires/connections, etc. At this point our laundry area was done and we didn't want to throw time or money on further troubleshooting/repair.
While this unit may fit your needs/budget, our machine didn't last too long and I would not buy it again.

title: I couldn't have asked for a better solution
text:
This washer was one of the best purchases I've made so far on Amazon. I had another manufacturers model and it broke. This was a great choice and the solution for my needs.

It's a perfect size for an apartment especially if you can't get a normal washer/dryer through the stairwell on the third floor like we are. It's lightweight and easily maneuverable. The inlet and drain hoses can be placed on either side.

The washing action is strong and the larger bin size is handling my family of 3.

It's easy to move clothes from the washer to the spinner, The spinner is faster than my old one and smoother on the start. Sometimes you have to hold these spinners still so they don't rock. It even has a lint filter.

All in all I'm overly satisfied and it's a pleasure to do the laundry now.

title: Five Stars
text: Wow, I'm impressed.

title: Paid for itself!
text:
I bought this for my apartment. I have four kids and was spending way too much time and money at the laundromat. I figured if I could wash most of their clothes with this, it would pay for itself in no time. I was right! I only have to go to the laundromat for my comforter. The clothes come out clean and the spin dryer cuts down drying time.

I can fit about 6-8 of my kids outfits in one load. It will fit queen size sheets, and twin blankets... though the blankets can not fit in the dryer. I have gotten into a pattern where once I am going, I'm starting a new wash load every 30 minutes.

It can do bleach loads which was a life saver after a stomach flu went through the house. I also add a little fabric softner and rinse well so the clothes dry soft and fluffy.

There was an issue with the first washer I received, the wiring on it was wonky but it was replaced for free with no hassle. I'm noticing that this new one doesn't have the quirks the other one did, so I'm sure it was a rare issue.

title: My parents are shocked I bought a washer and dryer for under $100!
text:
This washer has saved my butt! I live in a small apartment with three friends and we don't have a washer/dryer hookup. The apartment complex has a laundromat, but it costs THREE DOLLARS for each load. I can't afford that! I can barely afford rent. I had a $73 Amazon credit, so I decided to do something about my problem. The washer came in a few days later, fully assembled and ready to use right out of the box. It's about as tall as my kitchen trash can and about twice as wide. It's not super heavy, and there are little things on the side I can grip to carry it (not quite handles, but little indents).
The washer is a little more work than a regular washer and dryer, because I have to put the water in myself and drain it, then put rinse water in and drain that, then put it through the dryer and then hang to finish. It IS a lot easier and more effective than hand-washing, however! The little hose it comes with for the water inlet is useless; I just tossed it out with the packaging. A bucket is much more useful. Also, the instruction manual is very poorly translated and pretty useless, so you may need to go to YouTube for a tutorial.

title: Works well, but not without hiccups
text:
I eventually got this working and it does it's job admirably. Clothes go in dirty, add a very tiny amount of soap, wash, rinse, maybe rinse again, spin dry and then throw them on the drying rack for a day.

I followed instructions from the other reviews. The person that suggested using bags made of netting for a filter is a genius.

That said, there were some build issues. A screw was missing and that meant the "control panel" popped off while moving it. After putting it back on and putting in a new screw, the machine wouldn't start at first. I figured out that the metal contacts that detect whether the spin dryer door was messed up. Bent it and the machine finally worked.

Had it for a month or so now. Pretty happy overall, given the price.

Do not over stuff or it will not rotate the laundry on the contrary overstuff the spinner otherwise it will wobble. title: Died the day after the last day of the return period
text:
Update: customer service answered my email promptly and offered either to send parts for repair and give a 50% refund, or I could get a full refund or a replacement, after I return my non-working one.

When I emailed to describe exactly what was happening, they offered a replacement or a full refund only, with no need to return the machine. The replacement is supposed to arrive in about 8 days, or around May 13-14.

If a working replacement arrives within two weeks I will change my review to two stars.

If it's still working in six months it gets three stars. After a year I'll go to four stars, and after a year and a half I will give it five stars because by then I will have recouped my investment by not spending money at the laundromat.

//////
I would have given it a 4 star review if it had not died after a few weeks, or 5 if the tube that is supposed to be an intake hose was functional at all.

The spinner in this thing is great.

title: More hassle than it is worth.
text:
The product works, but there are a lot of issues that you will encounter while using it.
For one, it is fully gravity drained. if the hose isn't lower than where the washer sits it is not going to drain well. so this makes where you are going to put it a complicated scenario.
secondly, the connections on top. the inlet is a very awkward connection, only a friction coupling with one hose that is very short and the glue on the hose kind of came undone. probably could attach some other kind of fitting on it but it is very awkward especially for the drain and rinse side.
and finally, the draining from the washering tub leaves the clothing soaking wet to be put into the spinner. once it spins it is great but the transfer just makes it a pain to use.

in closing, I would have returned this but the packaging they use falls apart and they would not accept it returned other wise. Over all this was a very unsatisfying experience. Find one of the smaller ones that are single drum with an actual pump drain. will save you a lot of a head ache.

the product itself isn't bad for what it is, but it is not worth it compared to other options.

title: Portable washing machine

title: Durable and convenient
text:
It’s exactly what I needed for my apartment. What I love most about this is how durable it has been. I put it through some abuse and it just keeps working as intended, even eight months later.

I use it in the tub, and fill it with the shower head instead of an inlet hose. So it sits at a mild slant and still works just fine even though part of its job is balancing and spinning.

Earlier today I walked off and accidentally let it overfill. It does overflow into the spinner (“drying”) side, but once I let all the excess water drain out, it went right back to working perfectly.

It operates quietly (by my standards—I’m running window ACs right now and can’t hear it over them in the next room).

This saves me from having to go to the disgusting laundry basement in the building for all but the largest items. Yes, it’s more hands-on with the rinsing and hanging-to-dry and ironing things, but it’s still better than dressing to run outside and find someone else using the machines I need. And I’ve saved so many quarters.

title: Washer for small spaces
text: Washer washes clothes very well. You have to fill with water, then drain, you have to fill again to remove laundry soap and drain again. You have to continue this process until the water that drains is clear before putting it in the spin side. The spin nearly spins the clothes dry. Do not overpack. It’s not that kind of a washing machine. The hoses are super short, so it’s difficult to find a place for the washer to drain. We sat it on a table and put the hose in the kitchen sink. When you do that the washer is up so high you can see to loan clothes.

title: Surprisingly good!
text:
I live in an apartment and with the covid19 outbreak, I no longer felt safe going to the laundromat. Bought this lil dude with low expectations bc it’s so cheap... I was WRONG. This thing is a BEAST. It does take some work to get started the first time (instructions are a real treat if you’ve got a sense of humor) and the hose doesn’t fit a regular US sink (not that big of a deal if you just run to the hardware store and pick up a quick connect with clamps) but this thing cleans SO WELL. It’s obviously not a full size washer load but I got 4 t-shirts, a full sized towel, a pair of jeans, 2 pairs of shorts and a small garment bag of intimates in one wash. The trick is to not overfill it and you’re fine. I just bring the water up to the second notch on the filter, add less than a quarter cup of liquid soap, liquid sanitizer, and a bit of liquid softener. My clothes smell great and my whites are way brighter they were at the laundromat. The first time I used it I smelled a “new electronic” smell but it hasn’t happened after that. It will leak a little at the bottom if you overfill it. I have one child and myself in my home and can do a full days laundry in one wash (provided its all darks). It is super compact (I laughed at first bc it looks like a toy) and it fits in my very small bathroom no problem! This is hands down my best purchase in the last year.
TLDR: I thought it would be trash but turned out to be pretty fantastic.

title: Way better than going to the laundromat
text: This thing does exactly what it says. Perfect for campgrounds, RVs or apartments. The plastic tubing that came with it for water hookup are useless, but if you wanted to, you could get some hoses and clamps at the hardware store to make it work. We place it in the shower and add water manually. It's a bit time consuming this way, but much better than a trip to the laundromat.

title: Great value and perfect for small living spaces
text: I absolutely love it. I have had top of the line W/D sets for 30 years but we downsized to 19' travel trailer forcing me to give up that luxury. After a few times using laundromats, I was desperate to find a solution. This fits in our small shower so it's easy to use. The complaints about the cheap useless hose is valid but since I don't need to use it, it's irrelevant. I suggest if you are using this in a small apartment, just set it in the tub or shower for use. It's easy enough to lift. I use my shower head to fill the tub. This is so much easier and cleans so much better than the laundromat machines. You will still need an occasional laundromat visit for heavy/bulky items like blankets, rugs and winter coats. The spin cycle does a great job. I hung up the clothes, went out to run errands and came back to dry clothes. This was 5 percent of the cost of my last washer/dryer and I am very pleased with it.

title: Great for baby clothes
text:
I got this as a registry gift and it's been a lifesaver since babies wear like 5 outfits a day and go through 100 burp cloths daily. This is a GREAT registry item or baby shower gift for anyone expecting who has to leave their house to wash.

A couple notes.

I live in a Brooklyn apartment that does not have or allow regular laundry in the apartments. This machine uses less water than flushing the toilet so it won't be detected.

Noise: i have to have it in my tub because there is no safe elevated place for draining. This makes it kind of loud (imagine being downstairs from 15 min rumbling in a tub). I know other reviewers are saying it's quiet, but consider the space you are in. It DOES make noise. It's not silent. And depending on where you have it will determine how much reverberation there will be. It relies on gravity to drain, so consider where you will be washing and plug access.

Dryer: this is not a dryer. It's a spin cycle that "rings" the water out. Buy a drying rack. Also keep in mind, unlike a tumble dry, clothes will not come out soft and fluffy. They were rung out and air dried which can be kind of crispy. Having said that, the spin cycle works excellently.

The hose: idk what this is supposed to attach to (because it fits zero sinks) but just use a large pitcher or a rinsaroo to fill it.

Remember to rinse lol. Wash cycle will wash your clothes. Then you need to drain it, refill with fresh water to rinse.

Weight: for what it is, it's pretty light. I could pick it up and out of the tub right after having a baby. It feels about 40 lbs and has handles on both sides.

Size: it's very compact and fits well in my tiny bathroom.

title: Nifty Little gadget
text: I'm writing this review as its been exactly a year since i bought it..And still running with no problems..i did find however that even 1pair of jeans is too heavy for the spinner cycle..Just some tips as i read other reviews..If for instance you wash  5tshirts at once..Then you Spin 3tshirts..Then spin the other 2shirts..Doing Bras..DO NOT..Spin them for 5mins..As the spinner eats them & they get caught..You must ALWAYS use the rubber piece & Spin them just for one min..i use just one 5lb bucket per load..as the hoses arnt the greatest...i just wished there was a way too take the hoses apart too clean them or at least have hoses too buy & replace..Because i'm worried of mold..You must check the filter after each load..I Clean it under warm water & found its easier too clean while the lint is wet..Also if you just air dry filter it goes back in the washer easier & stays clicked in..

title: WOW! What a powerful machine!
text: I received and used this little guy last night. Came in perfect condition, does have that slight odor another reviewer mentioned. But not too bad. Use much less soap so we'll save some money there as well. Washed a full set of sheets which came out pretty much dry. I'd say after 15min of hang drying, they were completely dry and ready to put back on the bed. I bought the hose attachments, but honestly, if you have a shower arm, you can just save the money and use that to fill the washing tank. That's what I ended up doing. You do have to walk back and forth a few times, as the entire process takes exactly 15min of wash time and 5min of spin time, but I'd much rather do it in the comforts of my own home then spend a day at the Laundromat. Also, I live in a walk-up apartment in NYC, so this saves me a lot of hassle. I do recommend a little lint trap, mine is still 'en route' so I will review that once I receive it. Thanks Giantex for making our lives A LOT easier!

title: Worth it if you don't mind tending to it
text: It's great for my tiny house on wheels! It fits alot in a load! The lint trap catches hair surprisingly well, we have 2 dogs and a cat. It has a hard time with jeans, just do jeans separate and only two pairs at a time. It takes awhile to do laundry, 15 min wash, 15 min rinse, and 15 min rinse. Three or four load does our two small baskets, so it takes a few hours. But it's a fill and leave sort of thing, just gotta tend to it. We take the showerhead off and thread on some vinyl hose. Love it though! Saving lots of money opposed to the laundromat.

title: BEST LITTLE WASHER FOR AN APARTMENT
text:
I have had this little machine for about a week, I have done wash everyday, I am in love with this little machine. I read all the reviews and watched youtube videos before I purchased so I knew what I was getting into and what the limitations are, in no way is this going to replace a full sized automatic washing machine, but I live in an apartment and this has been a godsend, I am very pleased with the cleanliness of the clothes and the ease of the machine. I was prepared and went to the home depot before the product arrived so when it came I was set to go. I bought a 1/2" coupler,
1/2" nipple and a hose clamp and a shower diverter, once the machine arrived, I fixed the hose it came with (important to note: one end of the hose fits the inlet of the machine the other end is basically useless, important to take of the end of the hose that will attach to the diverter, its a little plastic piece and easily comes off) nest insert the end of the hose to the nipple and to that the coupler ( the coupler will then attach to the diverter, the hose clamp tightens around the host insure no leakage) easy...I move the hose from the washer tub over to the spin side for the rinse. I am very very pleased.

title: Great Alternative to the Laundromat
text:
This little washer is very simple to operate out of the box. Watching a few review videos first will make things very easy & you'll find lots of great hacks & examples of wash loads. I elevate the washer on 2 dining room chairs at the kitchen sink & drain it into a bucket. The filler hose doesn't fit on my faucet, but I have a sprayer hose on my sink, so I use that. I've also used it in the tub, draining it directly into the drain, but this requires lifting it into the tub, which can be tough on your back.
The washer doesn't need a lot of soap & my clothes get clean. The spin cycle is AMAZING, leaving your items darn near dried! Be gentle with the lint trap & clean it often. It's also good to rinse & wipe the inside of the machine out once you're finished doing laundry to keep the grime at bay. I like to leave the lids up for a while to let the machine dry out too. I wish the machine was taller & on wheels for easier transport, but I'm going to get a cart for it to solve these issues. I'm grateful that I no longer have to lug everything to the laundromat!

title: Great for Apartments, Cheaper than a Laundry Mat
text: Excellent washing machine! It is a great alternative to spending 20+ dollars at a gross laundry mat. I had to buy a new hose and connector to hook it up to my sink. It uses gravity to drain, so I usually hook it up to my kitchen sink and place it on top of a spare coffee table to have, and drain into a five gallon pail I dump down the bathtub drain. It has a surprisingly decent compacity and cleans fairly well. However, it is more of a rinse, so if clothes are especially dirty, a pre-scrub is necessary. It usually takes a couple rinses to get the soap put of your clothes, and you have to be careful about what type of soap you use. I first used a regular liquid detergent and after 10+ rinses the soap was still not out of my clothes. I recommend a low suds, biodegradable camping liquid detergent that you can find at a sporting/outdoor goods store. It rinses out much cleaner. The spin dryer has a much smaller compacity then the washer, so you have to break the load down to dry it. The spin dryer works really well, most clothes are only just damp by the time they come out, which is great because I just use a drying rack and I can hang the clothes overnight and they will be dry in the morning with no puddles on the floor. Overall, this machine is more time consuming, with a smaller load size then a regular dryer, and you have to manually fill and drain multiple times a load, but it is an excellent, cost saving alternative to using a laundry mat.

text:

The capacity is way larger than expected, I can fit my husbands entire military uniform in it in one load no problem.
The dryer IS about half the size of the washer, which is kind of a pain but it still does the job.
The dryer is similar to the spin dryers you see to dry your swimsuit at pools, it does a good job of getting most of the water out, but the clothes still have to be hung to dry the rest of the way.

This is easy to use, light weight, and definitely worth the price. We have saved double what we paid for it within just a couple of months of using it.

title: Our clothes just were not getting the good solid cleaning they needed
text:
Our washer had broke down months ago and we were hand washing EVERYTHING. We have 5 people in our house. That is A LOT of laundry. We got so behind on it so it just piled up and piled up. My husband and I both worked full time and with 3 kids and 5 different schedules, there was no time for us to have someone come and look at our washer to fix it.

So this is where Giantex Portable Mini Compact Twin Tub came in. I was trying to find something and quick. Our clothes just were not getting the good solid cleaning they needed. I talked to my husband about this one and did some review searching and found this one to be the best.

It arrived a few days later and I IMMEDIATLY put it to work. It is a small tub but can do a decent amount. The spinning tub is much smaller and you will have to do things in batches (which I was fine with because I was gunna have clean clothes!!!). The water hose to bring water into the tubs doesn't fit onto any faucet we have but we just used a big bucket filled with water to fill up the tub. I ended up doing about 5 loads or so, which in a regular washing machine would be about two. OH MY LORD! I was sooooo happy to finally have clean smelling clothes. I felt like a new woman! I will NEVER take clean clothes for granted ever again! lol

This exceeded my expectations. It is even something you could bring with you camping if you have a camper that has access to electricity and a water line of some kind. I definitely recommend this item if you need something small for an apartment or your washer takes a crap like ours did.

Hope this helps!

title: I love it! Kind of big
text:
I love it! Kind of big, but does clean a lot of clothing at a time.

I place this directly into my shower and drain into the drain. I do fill this up with a bucket, the piping is garbage. I do about 1 load a week, 2 loads when I need to do towels and other oddities.

The dryer is like a salad spinner, but it works well enough. After spinning, I use a standard laundry rack in my kitchen and typically everything is dry by the next morning.

title: Ideal for our motorhome, highly recommended (with instructions)
text:
We purchased this item a few months ago and have been using it every few days since then. It is remarkably well built and sturdy. We have had only two issues with it, both easily handled. 1. We place it in our shower, and if the shower drain gets blocked and the water level gets above the legs of the washer, it will not operate until the water level is back down. (I assume this is a safety feature related to the electrical wiring). 2. Our dark clothes always come out covered in lint so we end up throwing the darks in the dryer at the campground for a couple bucks to get rid of the lint. Otherwise, this unit is great. It gets our clothes much cleaner than we ever got at a laundromat or even our home washer (when we had one).

The hose that comes with the washer will not fit standard US faucets, but you can easily create an adapter by visiting your local hardware store. We elected to "permanently " install the hose in our shower with a diverter which also gives us an easy way to fill the dog watering containers.

Directions that come with the unit are basically incomprehensible, so here is the gist:

1. Place unit in an area such as a shower that has a drain, plug into outlet (should be a GFI protected outlet).
2. Connect one end of water hose to faucet or whatever you have designed, and the other to the left hand water input nozzle (washing side).
3. Make sure center knob is set to Soft or Normal, not Drain. Turn on the water to the temperature desired.
4. As the water is filling, go ahead and add detergent (liquid is best, not PODS) and your laundry to about 2/3. Do not overstuff.
5. When water is above line of clothing by about 1 inch, turn the wash cycle to the time desired and close lid.
6. When wash cycle is complete, move about half of wet laundry to the right side spinner. Do not overstuff. Put the plastic "cover" on top of laundry and press down. Close both spinner lids and set spinner to desired time.
7. Move the hose to the right side spin/rinse nozzle and turn on cold water for about 1 minute, then turn off. Allow unit to complete spin cycle. You can repeat this step if needed.
8. When spin cycle is complete, remove clothes and hang to dry. Repeat steps 6&7 for remaining laundry.
9. If you have more laundry to do, you can reuse the existing wash water if it isn't extremely dirty or turn the center knob to drain to empty the basin, then start over at step 3.
10. After a couple loads, be sure to remove and clean the lint trap inside the wash basin. When complete and basins are empty, set the center knob back to normal, unplug the unit, disconnect the water hose and store it wherever you desire.

Hope this helps.

title: Satisfy customer

title: It works but not as much as I need it to
text: My boyfriend and I our moving to a new place soon where there is no washer/dryer on-sight. We bought this to try it out to see if we need to change our future living situation. I was excited to give this a try and hoped that it worked as well as a lot of people said it had. I was disappointed. Having to do smaller loads in the first place is inconvenient, and then only being able to put 1/2 of the load in the spin dryer (meaning you have to run the drying cycle twice, then back in the washing side to rinse, than again another two runs of drying). None of the cycles take very long but having to move things around and start new cycles every few minutes just makes it take a while. It probably took me an hour and a half to get set up and just do one load. This was my first time using it so it might be quicker next time, but it's really important to have a set up of hosing the water in and having a place for the water to drain. Bucketing water in and out is very tiring and annoying. My boyfriend works in a restaurant and his work clothes gather quite a stench, and our normal washer would get the smell out just fine. This however, did not. It helped, but I didn't feel it got the clothes quite clean enough, they still smelled slightly. This probably means I would need to do even smaller loads. Which again, leads to the frustration and time of the numerous cycles and putting in/draining water. I was really hoping this would work a bit better and be a bit more convenient. This would be good for just the occasional small load, and is much more convenient than a laundromat, but maybe not the best option for all of your laundry, all the time. It works and does what it advertises, it just wasn't what I was looking for.

title: Worth the money!

title: Worked great, for 2 washes, then broke
text: Worked amazingly for 2 uses. I was so excited to recieve this product. After really looking at it, It's not put together very well, product has glue drips on it, brown marks, stripped screws, dirty fingerprints. The washer part stopped working after literally after only 2 washes. I took off the back panel, and where the agitator is, there's a screw loose and it won't "hug" into the spindle correctly in order to move the belt. I tried to tighten the screw but there's no hole in the spindle for the screw to even go into. The spindle moves, the thing around it will not because they can't connect due to no hole in the spindle.

title: I hate laundry; but it’s my Best Purchase in Years.
text:
So I try to spend a minimal amount money. I tend to be a bit frugal; but it’s by choice and I’m lucky for that. So I saw the price tag and I was “wishy washy” (ha, get it?!) about getting this machine.

We have a laundry mat down the street but it’s SUCH A HASSEL! dragging it in and out and waiting for machines; it takes so long. And it’s a ton of stupid quarters and public people. It’s annoying and a pest to do constantly. But the idea of making a big chore into a mini chore was appealing. I wash in my work form home breaks which I’m done switching and start washing within 3-4 minutes.

So I was skeptical of this machine to be honest. If it’s from Amazon how nice is it really? I saw good reviews and praised; and I took a risk. And I’m SO GLAD I DID!

pros. This machine is lightweight; compact but still pretty nice sized. I was shocked when it came in how big it is. It’s just me and my fiancé and two cats; we have a queen sized bed and don’t do much. So this machine is PERFECT! It can wash towels, sheets, slippers, all work clothes (including his khakis and my thick sweaters)! Big comforters might be able to fit but an occasional blanket washing trip is better than every week!

Pull out of the box and unwrap, and plug in. The easiest setup of my life. I was worried getting a machine online I thought it would be more complicated. But nope. Easy peasy :)

Now you do have to be a little careful loading it; if it’s not fully whirlpooling it won’t clean it right. Also; SOAP. One tide pod was too much so we unfortunately did have to switch to tide liquid. But it just needs a small “bloop” of soap. It can get over soapy easy so just use maybe 1-2 tablespoons. That’s the sweet spot.

The spinner (not dryer) is very fast. It’s actually fun hah! It actually gets clothes like 70-80% dry. At first I was wary: I knew this might be an annoyance. But drying clothes takes maybe 3-4 hours? It’s not long to let it hang and air dry it’s honestly been nice to have our house smell good!

This is the first time I ever have enjoyed doing laundry. Ever. That’s massive for me! It used to be so annoying and my least favorite thing ever but now it’s nice to see my clothes CLEAN! And fresh. :)

We don’t have any hookups (but they are built in on the washer!) so tbh I got 4 cinderblocks and a 5 gallon pail (it’s a gravity drain) to hoist it up; and the 5 gallon pail is ok with my bad shoulder even when full. She isn’t stunningly gorgeous on her cement throne but hey, it works well and it’s sturdy. And it cost under $6.

Cons: this is a spinner so you do have clothes around the house. Be mindful of that. I wish it was a dryer but it’s a super good spinner honestly; doesn’t need to air dry long. Not a con for me but for others maybe.

If you don’t have hookups you will need a shower or bucket for water. I don’t mind this at all (featuring cottagecore lil old me) but I know that can be upsetting to some.

This machine is a little loud when spinning. Even if you balance it right it just whirrs. Now it’s not extremely distracting or bad. But it’s something that’s there.

No full lines on the wash tub. It takes some experimenting but it is a lot better once you figure it out.

And weird instructions. Don’t even read those just chuck em. It barely made sense.

TDLR: best money ever spent. Made me fall in love with doing laundry which I normally hate. Best purchase in a very long time and holds up well. Caught up on all laundry; pros and cons above.

title: I love it

title: I Love This Thing!
text:
The only thing I didn't like about this powerful, small washer is the hose that came with it that is for the water intake. The ends are not big enough and it is too stiff to push onto any shower spout or kitchen sink spout. To fill the washer, I use a 5 gallon bucket with warm, hot or cold water. The specifications do inform you that 110 degrees should be the maximum water temperature used. Those are the only cons I have with this washer.

The washer is powerful. My tips are to put the water in first and use 1/4 of the detergent you would usually use or less. Turn on the washer for a moment to allow the detergent to swirl and soap up, then put the clothes in. I absolutely love it. It fits in a small space. I have it on a table in my bathroom. That helps it drain even better. Again, I love this powerful washer. My whites have never seemed whiter.

title: Just out of box, 3 loads done in about 1.5 hours
text:
I just got this yesterday and set it up this morning with first three loads completed. It took me about 1.5 hours, but expect it will go quicker once I get the correct hose hook ups. As pretty much every other review has said, the inlet hose that comes with this doesn't work out of the box. Since I did my research, I wasn't surprised or disappointed with this. Totally expected it. Before I used it this morning, I did watch quite a few of the video reviews - Kayley had a great one (but she used a whole tide pod which I think is too much soap). Pleasantly surprised that you can rinse your close in the spin side! I was able to wash quite a lot of clothes in each load, including adding a pair of jeans in with a few t-shirts and heavy socks AND a mid weight sweater. The amount of clothes I washed in the three loads this morning is about the same as I would have put in one of the jumbo washers at the laundromat. I did elevate the machine, but didn't have anything to put it on so the machine was completely above the side of the tub for full draining, so after all draining was completed, I put the hose in a bucket that was on the floor for the last bits.
I was astonished at the amount of dirt / stuff that came out of the clothes - even with the very small amount of soap I used.
Things that would have made this machine better: (1) longer inlet hose (2) slightly longer power cord (3)information as to what adapter I could purchase at the same time - even if it didn't come with it, at least I could link to it and purchase it also.
To me, the pros far outweigh any of the cons for this machine. I'm hoping I will get many years work out of this.

Update: Since getting this machine, I have washed everything in it except very large items. Heavy jeans, thick bath size towels, sweaters - even shaggy fur fabric. Surprising how much I could put in each load. For example: heavy winter jeans, thick knit sweater, 2-3 long sleeve t-shirts, few under things all in one load. As reviews and description states - 1/2 wash load fits in spinner at a time. Even the heavy items spun out well - better than any commercial washing machine has done lately. For rinsing, I used about 1 Tablespoon white distilled vinegar in a gallon of water poured into the spin side...AFTER spinning all wash water out of it. Give the clothes a really good shake to remove wrinkles an hang to dry what little moisture is left in them.
UPDATE: I have now been using this machine 1-2 times a week and I am just as happy with it as when I bought it 6 months ago. I wash jeans, jackets, sweaters as well as lighter material with no problems. I do have to say, I have had to remove an item or two because I put too much in occasionally but that is not the machine's issue. If you are looking for a good way to hook the hose up to the sink/shower, I highly recommend the Rinseroo system. (It is sold on Amazon also.)

title: Hose me...
text:
If this Washer had a longer waste water hose, a longer (Add retractable- even better) power cord, and most importantly a more efficient means to hook it to most standard sinks (kitchen and baths) it would be GREAT! I was one of the luck it seems, as I figured how to connect my water hose to the vanity sink in just minutes. I attached WITHOUT any extra hardware or tools. But apparently, most people do not have the same setup. And that is unfortunate. I think most people using this will either wind up emptying the tub manually (due to both the length of the drainage hose and the lack of drainage options due to the gravity drainage system rather than a small pump) or filling the tub(s) manually (due to a lack of connection options) or both.

This is a very good washer overall. But, as I stated above, expect some manual operations (involving dirty and/or clean water- so dress appropriately) or be willing to spend some extra bucks to resolve its short comings.

text:
I’ve never written an Amazon review but this thing is amazing. I live in a cheap apartment with no washer or dryer and the ones at the on site laundry are from the 70s and this was a perfect solution. I no longer have to drag my laundry up and down 2 flights of stairs or pay $5 a load for washing and drying. I did my first load in this and the water was gray because how dirty my clothes were from my apartment laundry I’ve even done clean clothes and it’s still gray and gross. I really recommend this it’s saved me so much time and money.

Here are some tips I have found helpful so far

Get a cart for it it’s not too heavy but is a pain to get in and out of doorways. I purchased a large drying rack from Amazon and took off one of the collapsible racks and added a bungee cord it works perfect for moving it around my apartment. I wouldn’t recommend washing on there though it’s too unstable.
DONT USE PODS please don’t use pods they’re a pain I just had some left over and I don’t wanna waste them.
If you have a detachable shower head try to take the head off and see if the extension fits in the water intake tube. Mine did and I didn’t have to buy any hardware and there’s no leaks. You might wanna super glue the plastic cone in the intake tube in though it comes out sometimes.
Make sure to do your own rinse cycle. I drain my water after a load and then fill it all the way up and do a 3-6 minute cycle then throw my stuff in the dryer.

title: Great for a small apartment!
text: Absolutely love this product - spares so much time and hassle compared to going to our apartment complex's laundry facility. Washing there is expensive, people leave clothes in the machines, and half the machines don't work. Using the compact is a bit more labor intensive, since you have to do smaller loads and do the wash and spin in separate tubs, but overall it's quicker and you don't have to leave the house. A heated hang-dryer works well with this washer - we've liked the "Panda" brand one. Overall, this product is so much easier than going to a laundromat and cheaper than a full-size unit. The key is to do small loads frequently and not let the wash pile up; the tub won't hold nearly as much as a full-size washer so if you wait too long, getting caught up will take some time. For filling the tub, we hooked a garden hose to the washer hookup and for draining we use a 5-gallon bucket, since the drain in the utility closet is too high for the gravity drain to work. Highly recommended!

title: Spin motor failed after 8 loads
text:
The spin motor failed after being used only 8 times. The spin motor hums, but does not have enough starting torque to get the motor started. I opened the unit and started the "YGG-45 Spin Motor" my hand (with the brake disabled) and immediately powered the motor (white it was still spinning) and the motor started working at it's operational speed.

I replaced the 14uf capacitor (usual suspect when AC motors wont start up), but the result was the same. Motor humming and would not start without a nudge in the right direction.

The spin motor is not serviceable due to it being riveted shut. A replacement motor is difficult to source because it is usually sold in lots of 1,000.

Very disappointed in the quality of this product and would not recommend.

title: Love this perfect and reliable washing machine!
text:
This is a perfect and reliable laundry machine. The machine is only for washing and wringing, and it requires manual hanging to dry. These machines usually expect smaller loads so overloading will burn out the agitator. I bought another machine first (rating was 4/5, less than $100) but that unit broke on the 2nd usage due to the agitator stopped working without any obvious overloads. This unit was my 2nd purchase and so far, it's working great. Thus, even user's careful attention, these machines may have hit and miss in QA standard even within the same unit. Here are some important usage tips (from my experience with this unit) and data:

Data (load examples below are only for your baseline, to adjust with your further fine-tuning):
* Usage period - 4 months since the purchase, still working great
* Usage frequency - 2 to 4 loads per week (all loads done in 1 day, not spread over days)
* comfortable load example #1 - 1 flat sheet and 1 fitted sheet (full), 1 bath-towel (thick), plus a few kitchen towels
* comfortable load example #2 - 2 pairs of women's jeans (regular size 2), 3 women's inner long-sleeve shirts (size S, t-shirt or thinner material, not sweatshirts), plus a few undies and socks

Important usage tips (in-parentheses):
1. Put the machine in a bathtub
2. Lay the drain hose down close to the bathtub drain (if you forget to put the hose down from the hanging position, spin will not work. It will spin very slow)
3. Plug it in
4. Set the dial to Soft or Normal (Make sure the dial is NOT SET to "Drain" before step #5)
5. Put 2/3 water in the machine (I use a 3-gallon bucket)
6. Put liquid detergent (recommended)
7. Put the load in the water and adjust the final amount (DO NOT FILL UP. Leave at least 3 to 4 inches from the top)
8. Wash for 15 min (or less if you prefer. DO NOT DRAIN the water yet. The weight of the water helps the machine stabilize for the spin cycle below)
9. Spin the load for 1.5min (to wring out the soapy water)
10. Drain soapy water from the washer and then put clean water for the rinse cycle
11. Put the wrung load back from the spinner to the washer, then adjust water level
12. Rinse 9 min (or less or more if preferred. Again, DO NOT DRAIN the water after this step, to balance/stabilize the machine for the spin cycle below)
13. Spin 3 min and take the load out of the spinner (anytime after this point, drain the water from the washer, make sure water is completely drained from the drain hose, then unplug/put away the machine)
14. Hang the laundry (the machine wrings well so it takes a short time to dry)

title: Overall an excellent alternative to the laundry mat every single week.
text: Love this for my tiny apartment! Currently I just put it in my tub and start using it. It is a gravity drain (hence why it's in the tub), but it drains great. This thing REALLY cleans! I honestly think my clothes come out cleaner than a regular washer. Light weight and easily cleaned. Being a plus sized person i was worried about the amount of clothing it would hold but it holds up great! I can wash 7 or 8 t-shirts in it easily. I even did a couple pairs of jeans! The rinse/spin dry side took a minute to figure out but once I did it was easy. I run water on the "dryer" side during it's first spin, to rinse out extra soap, and then run it a second to spin out excess water. Obviously things don't come out completely dry, but enough that it only takes a couple of hours for it to finish drying by hanging. I will say the instructions were not properly translated, very hard to understand, but I figured it out. The hose for the water intake is short and flimsy, and does not fit my shower head or sink head. And easy fix is on the way with with some coupling heads and tighteners. Nothing too crazy. For now I fill the tank right up from the main lid.

title: Great machine!  Good value and convenience.
text: I've only done 4 loads so far, but I am very impressed. The washing agitation is vigorous, and the spin speed is incredible.  I only put 1/2 sized loads in so far, just enough to fill the spin tub, which is how I measure how much clothes I can wash.  I know it'll wash bigger loads, but this is what I've done so far.  I add a couple oz of detergent, about 4 gallons of water to the wash tub, put the clothes in. I set the timer for  9 to 12 min to wash, depending on what I'm washing, and then drain.  I move the clothes to the spin tub for 3 min. to completely drain the soapy water out of the clothes, and then I move the clothes back to the wash tub with another 4 gal of water to rinse for about 6 min.  Drain, then back to the spin tub for 5 or 6 min.  The clothes come out clean and nearly dry!  I use a small folding drying rack, which easily holds two of the  1/2-sized loads.  For $105 delivered to Missouri, I'm very happy.  I don't think I'll ever wash anything bigger than towels in it, but for day to day laundry it's fantastic.  I'll take blankets and heavier stuff like that to the coin-op place.

title: There are a few caveats and knowing about all of them prior to purchase kept me from being disappointed; Definitely read the rev
text:
This unit is ultra simple and does exactly what it needs to. It's only bedding that it doesn't necessarily have the capacity to wash. There are a few caveats and knowing about all of them prior to purchase kept me from being disappointed; Definitely read the reviews!!

The faucet connectivity is still something of an issue. One on hand, the tube ending is shaped to fit something not American. On the other, the nozel on my faucet is incredibly short. I did see a picture of the turkey baster solution.. if I can find one short enough I might give that a shot.

Drainage was the other hang up. I went to a lumber yard, had a piece of scrap 3/4in plywood cut down to 27x15in, drilled a hole in it for the tube and super glued a yoga mat around it for traction. This foamy platform rests on the toilet with the washing machine on top of it. Re-purposing that old yoga mat was super gratifying..

Lastly, a nasty sort of burning electric Chinese factory odor is emitted from the wash cycle. It's not extreme so I just put my HEPA filter in the bathroom with it and shut the door.

title: Aggressive washer! Use a pillowcase for spin dry cycle
text: I'm editing my original review as we have had this machine for about a month now and have had a little more experience with washings. This is a powerful/aggressive little washer!  It definitely has gotten our clothes clean, but it has also damaged the fibers in clothing. The damage appears to be from the spin dry tub (the drainage holes are a little sharp on the edges). My solution was to put wet clothes inside a pillowcase. Worked like a charm and the clothes come out with less or much "softer" wrinkles.  Before the pillowcase fix,  it took the rear label patch off of a pair of men's Levi jeans and created pulls in the fabric of a dress shirt that was otherwise in like new condition. The lint filter does a fairly lousy job of catching all of the lint as I still get a considerable amount on clothing after it comes out of the spin cycle.  I add a cup of vinegar to the wash cycle because we have hard water and to help cut the suds. About half the time I need to drain and fill the wash tub again to rinse all of the soap out, adding a touch of Downy fabric softener.  I also pour water into the spin cycle via funnel to help rinse further.

title: Does what it’s supposed to do.
text:
[[VIDEOID:b669cd683727f7181ef3bc53e7d435c0]] This washer is great! It does what it’s supposed to do. It’s small compared to regular washers but this is easy to set up and you can get straight to tackling your laundry load. I tried washing by hand and it’s a no for me. I used to walk to the laundry mat across the street but it was way too tedious. Unfortunately my apartment’s laundry room is not reliable so this was the best option for me.

Pros: It’s easy to set up even if the hose doesn’t fit, you can always fill it manually so that’s not going to stop you from washing.

Good for apartments (small spaces) where your not allowed to hook up a machine.

Great for washing every day clothing. Shirts, shorts, pajamas, underwear, socks, towels, small rugs and bath towels.

It washes everything really well. I noticed it washed better than at my local laundry mat (not sure why).

Spinner dries clothes about 60-70%, you don’t need to struggle wringing anything out.

It doesn’t take long to wash 15 minutes max to wash and to dry another 5 or less. Longest wash and spin under 20 minutes.

You will save so much money not only on soap because you only need a tiny amount but also from going to a laundromat.

Cons: You can’t wash big heavy items like blankets, heavy coats/jackets.

You have to set it up in a way that it won’t shake/vibrate too hard. When it spins specifically in the beginning it spins hard then it gets the motion shaking stops. When ending the spin cycle shakes again.

Can’t fill the tank with too many clothing items. You’ll will be washing few articles at a time. For example 2-3 shirts, a pair of pants/shorts, and few underwear/socks per wash. (5-8 items with 2 heavy the rest light).

You need to be careful not to load it or it can damage the machine. I’m always checking how it spins before I leave it to wash. If it doesn’t spin it’s overloaded so you need to take some clothes out so it can wash well.

Overall the pros outweigh the cons for me. It’s made a big difference. To be able to wash at home without a hassle so worth it. It’s a good investment only $200 dollars! Totally worth it, I enjoy using my machine for the past 2 weeks since it arrived. I thought about it so long and I’m glad I finally bought it. I will update in a couple months to see how it’s holding up.

title: Great solution to apt living. Takes more work thatn a regular machine.
text:
My original Review was when this machine was working. Ive used the machine a hand full of times since I bought it in March. It is now august and It doesnt work anymore. Neither the wash basin or the spinner work. I took great care not to over load and the motor already burnt out. It seems like a great solution but... its not. Its a short term one.

I have used this washing machine for about 2 months now and for the size and money it does a great job. If you are looking for a easy time doing laundry this is not for you. It takes more work than a regular washing machine. This is my process. You need to add the clothes, fill with either a bucket or a detachable shower head. The hose that comes with it is useless so just throw it away. I have been using my detachable shower head and that works just fine. I add detergent to the line that says 1 on the cap. I set the timer for 15 min. Let it do its thing. Then I drain it in to the tub. Make sure your machine is up higher than the tub. I use 2 chairs in the bathroom to prop it up so i get good drainage. It works on gravity alone. There is no pump. I recommend getting a lint trap to attach to the hose or you are going to be cleaning your tub a lot. The lint trap in the machine doesn't work very well. Once I drain, I fill the basin again and run for like 10 min with regular clean water. Drain that and this part is optional but I like to fill it again and add fabric softer to the last rinse and run it for like 5 min and then drain it. To use the spinner the less clothes the better. If you over load it it will not spin right. So if you are spinning jeans then do one pant at a time. The spinner does a great at getting the water out of the clothes. I find that at most, 3 min spin time is good to get water out of heavier clothes and for shirts or leggings one min is plenty. In one load I'm able to wash about 7 medium shirts. Id say you could wash 3 pairs of jeans in one load. If they are of average size. Larger clothes take more room obv. The heavier the clothes the harder the machines works to move the clothes around. The first few washes the machine emits a mechanical grease type smell. The more you use the machine the more the smell dissipates. It does not affect your clothes what so ever. Make sure to always reset the drain dial to wash mode or else you will get water in to the spin compartment while the clothes wash... its not a big deal. Once you drain, the water will drain out of there too. Id recommend being gentile with this machine because the hose used to drain is kind of flimsy. Hence the 4 stars instead of 5 star rating. I'm scared that it will rip at some point and get water everywhere. I want to replace it with a sturdier hose at some point. The machine isn't perfect. It leaves a bit of lint on clothes. Especially black clothes and if you have cats or dogs... you are going to want to either use a lint roller after the clothes has dried or just don't use this at all. I line dry all my clothes. It will be dry with in 2 hrs if i put a fan in the bathroom. Over all. I'm pretty content with this machine for what its worth. The time I can spend at home is worth more to me than lugging 2 weeks worth of clothes to the laundromat and spending 3 hrs there with whiny kids with no entertainment. Now I only have to go once a month to the laundromat for my linens only. Although I do use this to wash my towels.
I live in an apt with spotty laundry access so to me this machine was the answer to my problems.

title: Lots of potential in a little machine
text:
My wife is absolutely pleased with her tiny washer. She washes, sometimes, twice a week with no problem except for the issues of either carrying water to the machine or constantly going back and forth to the kitchen sink to turn the water on and off and monitoring the water level or the hose dangling inside the machine making sure it hasn’t slipped out onto the floor. This is for the wash, rinse, and spin cycles. Other than that, we don’t have any problems with leaks or anything else. I thought about making this machine capable to semi-automatically fill itself. I’m pretty resourceful, I made life a lot better for both of us, and now, she’s even happier. Check out the picture and see how I did it. If this setup is too much or complicated, the easier way is to just run a simple single hose to the machine and put one valve on it, then add another piece of hose to hang inside the machine. Once you have the hose hanging inside the machine, you can use a simple clamp, like the one shown or similar, and clamp it to the rim of the tub. You can also slip the hose onto the nipples, one at a time, on top of the machine.

Hose specs: Hose from sink should be ½” ID ⅝” OD
This hose type can be used for most of the plumbing project. Even for the valves.

Hose specs: Hose going to the inlet nipples on top of the machine should be ⅝” ID ¾” OD. This piece can be about 8” in length.

ID is inner diameter
OD is outer diameter

Any associate at any hardware store can help you with these parts.

Once you have all the hoses and valves connected, you can just slip the hose from the sink inside the hose attached to the top of the machine. Make sure to push the hose in far enough so the pressure will not push them apart. I do suggest you use hose clamps to attach the hose to the nipples on the machine, since they will be staying in place and because of the possible pressure.

The valves can be any valves of your choice. The can be either brass or plastic.

This setup will give you the freedom, peace, and ease to fill your machine constantly and turn your water off right there whenever you don’t need it.

We have ours in our bedroom near the door, not just for storage, but full time. We just hang the hose out the door to drain, since it just “gray” water. Check with your local ordinances and “tattle talers” to make sure it’s ok.

I hope this helps.

Swish swish

title: My best investment.
text:
I have had this washer for a little over a month i use it maybe 3-4 times a week. It is amazing. It is lightweight. It’s very easy to use. I read other reviews for instructions the ones that come with the washer are pretty useless. The small hose it comes with also pretty useless. We live in an apartment.

1) This machine drains with gravity. I put it on top of some milk crates next to bathtub. Its perfect.

2) I have it in the restroom right next to bathtub and I use a detachable shower head to fill it up. Its way easier than adding all these hoses or using buckets.

3) very little soap goes a long way. Yes it really does. The loads are small. No just like 3 things more like 4 pairs of tights 2 shirts and a pair of shorts. Works perfect!

4) Do not fill up washer too much with the movements it will spill from top.

5) The spinning cycle is not a dryer! But it leaves clothes completely water free. They will air dry in about an hr or 2 max! Just make sure to put in half of the wash load. Load it correctly and it should do its magic.

6) I attached some plastic snares (2) on the drain hose just to catch lint and other things. So they wont go down the drain and clog up my bathtub. I bought a 14 pack for about 5$..

7) After each use I rinse everything with hot water both washer and spinner. Clean out lint trap. And leave the tops open so it wont smell.

8) Its not super loud it has a slight humming when it washes but other than that its perfect!

Bottom line is yes purchase it. You wont regret it. I love it. I enjoy doing laundry at home. Takes a few extra steps but I have no regrets.

title: Gets the job done!
text:
Like: This baby fits right in the bathrub and gravity drains. I fill it up with buckets- was unable to rig the hose, but honestly it's not a huge deal. The agitator is strong. Don't expect this to be comparable to an industrial machine- I still sprayed spots with laundry spray that I know a regular washer would get out. Our laundromat shut down due to Covid and we were in a bind. This little baby has handled about 10-15 loads so far and is still twerkin. The spin compartment is plenty powerful. Expect to hang dry everything, so choose how much you'll do at once based on the amount of drying space you have. We use a laundry rack, our radiators, and hang some pieces up around the apartment on hangers. We have limited space and this guy fits in our entryway. You could also store things inside when you are not using it.

Dislike: The lint situation can be a bit overwhelming... make sure you clean the trap as much as possible. Make sure you do some rinse cycles and properly rinse the clothing.

Not something to dislike but of note: The spin dry can't handle the entire load so you'll have to experiment and see what it can handle and do it in stages. It's usually gotten all the juice out in 3 minutes, so there's not much lag time if you're hang drying anyway.

Bonus: When doing bras, do a small separate load and put each bra in a laundry bag. Then put the laundry bags in the spin cycle instead of hanging to dry immediately. This will get out excess water and make your bras dry quickly.

All in all: This isn't sturdy construction and a lifelong machine most likely. It's made of cheap materials, but it gets the job done if you're in a bind. It's also great for delicates. Watch some youtube videos before using. Those really helped me.

I had it on an indoor window ledge while filling it with a bucket manually let it drain through a hose out the window. I swapped the white hose with a black longer one. Just be cautious of your filling it manually. I ruined the spin dry part by spilling water on the knobs area while pouring in the water. The washer part worked still. Also be careful of moving the back panel. Doing that caused me to have to use zip ties to keep tension on the knob that drains the water from the washer side.

title: Well, dang! It works perfectly
text: Okay, I am not prone to long winded blather. However, this device is one of the most practical small washer devices I have ever seen. For the hundred or so bucks what you have is a simple, washing and spin extractor system that leaves your garments rrady to hang on a line ( or shove in a dryer) with minimal fuss. The water inlets are on both sides of the top panel, the drain is on the bottom and is controlled at the panel as well. We are off grid and needed a system that was easy to adapt. This was it. The washer side is built with a bottom plate agitator to spin the washables, alternating clockwise for 20 or so seconds then Counter clockwise. Both washer duration and extractor duration is set with mechanical timers on the front panel. So is drain. With the small motor it is still adequate to run about 12 lbs of clothes, and about half that in the extractor which needs to be loaded carefully so as not to become off balances. We run it from a small generator and manually load water, dumping into a couple of buckets for reuse processing. This device is a godsend for folks like us. Especially with small footprint of 24” wide by 14” deep. Easy to move, as it is all plastic, but what the heck. Only gripe is that the user manual is about the size of a post card with 4 pages all micro typed and faint ink, with the stupidest wording ever seen, even from chine. Still would buy again.

title: I'm glad I bought it
text:
I ordered this 5 months into the pandemic when I was tired of hand washing my clothes, sheets and towels and wasn't comfortable going to a public laundromat. This machine is like the missing link between hand washing and a regular full sized washer. I have it up on two plastic crates, next to my bath so it can drain into the tub. I was lucky that my shower sprayer reaches the washer to fill it and I don't have to hook and unhook the hose to the shower spigot. I did have to buy an extension cord rated for washers to reach my outlet. It's more hands-on than a regular washer, you need to switch the laundry from washer side to spin side, then back to washer to rinse, then back to spin side to semi dry it. So I've just taken to doing one function every time I pass the bathroom. It fits a surprising amount of sheets, towels, clothes. I have washed a cotton bedspread with no problem. The only things that don't fit are large comforters and pillows. It has a vigorous wash cycle and the spin cycle gets items almost dry. The tiny filter inside doesn't catch all the lint, so I attached a foot cut from a stocking to the drain hose with a rubber band to catch the rest. This was a great purchase and after a year and a half it's still going strong
EDIT- At just a couple weeks short of 2 years of owning this machine I was washing a couple of loads of laundry when I smelled a horrible burning smell. There was gray smoke coming from the top of the machine and the machine no longer works so I guess the motor burned out. I was starting the 3rd load in a row which I have done plenty of times before, so I'm not sure what went wrong. I'm not sure I'll repurchase this because the price has gone up and I regretted not paying a little more originally for a machine where you don't have to switch the laundry back and forth from compartment to compartment

If you're a female like I am that can cause a serious pH balance problems with your lady parts, enough to see the doctor. title: Wonderful but some small things
text:
First I just want to say that this really is a good machine. It works wonderfully for washing clothes (albeit in small loads which is fine) and for spinning out the water. My main complaint is the condition (and one small misleading description) which I will get to .

I love that this machine is small and easy to move around. The sound I would say is no different than a medium noise level dishwasher however the spin cycle will be loud at first.
Looking at this machine at first glance it seems relatively easy to handle and use but watching another person's video on how they use this greatly helps just make it easier to jump in and use.

Now to what complaint.
I got this machine yesterday and was super excited!
However when I opened the box (which machine was upsidedown) I instantly noticed how gross the feet were. I kept unboxing though and noticed that the main part being the washing and spinning bins hadn't looked used. Wrapping was on the lids for protection, warning of moving parts sticker was still on the spin cycle lid...So today I decided to use it anyways cause ya know.....laundry. but whenever I moved the machine to drain the water—don't have anything to set this on yet for gravity drain so I moved it to the tub to drain. Works well—it would leave marks on my floor.
I the. Decided to take pictures of it for this review and noticed the tube which was yellow as if water had been stiing there a long time.

I guess my complaint would be that I was under the impression I was getting a new machine....and instead either got a refurbished one or a used one.

As far as the misleading description, I believe they listed this item as having a spin dry. It doesn't really dry your clothes, it merely spins the water out for easy hang dry.

In summation, great machine, great usability, just disappointed in description and seller for the condition I received it in.

title: Great little machine to help you stay home!!!
text:
This little machine is a lifesaver during the corono virus so I do not have to leave the house. A great buy. There is certainly a learning curve in how to use it. As far as noise level. It is a little noisy when spin cycle first starts. If you are in an apartment I suggest putting a rubber mat under it to absorb noise.

I just put it near my shower stall and fill it up from the hose showerhead and let it drain after the wash cycle into the bottom of the shower. I put mine on a wheeled cart. Cost 77 bucks but well worth it as it is very sturdy and easily wheels the washer to closet for storage when I am done.

Some advice:

1. If you fill it too much you will notice machine struggles to swish clothes around.
Makes a chug chug sound. Next time don't fill so much.

2. Only little bit of soap. If you put too much on it will be filled with soap suds after draining.

3. I fill machine again with water after initial washing for a rince cycle. If you put too much soap in you will have to do two rinses.

4. I struggled with how much water to fill up for a wash. I fill it up to the top of the vertical lines that are on the inside wall. Don't worry about putting to much water in as you will notice it will start draining out. Also, if you put the shower head in washer to fill it up and walk away to do something else and forget about it , it will not overflow onto the floor, instead it will drain into the shower.

The cart it is on: Magna Cart platform 300 lb capacity. The washer fits on it nice but I put some sponge material under each corner to prevent it from moving around during spin cycle.

The only complaint I have is that the piece you put on top of clothes in the spinner is clear and I often don't realize it remains on the bottom of the spinner after last use. I then have to remove the clothes to retrieve it. It would help immensely if the piece of plastic was colored so it could be seen more easily. For this reason I give the machine 4 stars.

I am 77 years old and this is the longest review I have ever done but I wanted to help someone else out during this very difficult time of Coronivirus. Stay home. Please don't take any chances. Your life is very, very precious!!!

title: Compact and easy to use but mine arrived damaged.

This doesn't have a dryer but the spinner portion of the machine gets them pretty dry. Clothes are slightly damp but I like air drying my stuff so that's no problem!

title: Great machine
text:
I've had this for about two months now and it has been great to have. I have used shared laundry in apartments for the past 5 years so it is so nice to have my own machine that I can use whenever and that does not need quarters! The load size is pretty big. I can wash two large bath towels, a twin bed sheet, and a small bathroom mat in one load.

I drain water out into my tub and keep the machine on a table I have in my bathroom. The table is not the sturdiest so the machine does shake it for heavier loads but it is off the ground which makes it easier for draining water once a load is done.

The spinner gets rid of most of the excess water although I do hang my clothes to dry the rest of the way. I usually have them hang overnight and they are completely dry the next morning. The spinner does wrinkle clothes a bit but overall I am very happy with this machine.

title: Freedom! No more hand washing.
text: Light wieght and easily moveable. The wash motor is powerful. I r manually run a rinse. The high speed dryer removes water well. A second spin cycle removes about a 1/2 cup of water. One load is approximately one person's clothes for 5-7 days. Quality is sufficient. The wash bin doubles as the dirty clothes hamper and the extension cord is stored in the spin dryer. Filled by a line from adding a in-line shower head diverter valve bought at Menards with a 4 ft hose. The fill line stays connected upstream of the shower head. The machine drains into the tube drain. Another fill option is to search for "rv shower faucet" for a faucet with a built in diverted water line. The burning smell is from the drive belt because the motor is torcquey. The lowest cost option to free yourself from the slavery of hand washing. The user manual is a comically useless translation into english. The picture is of the valve that was in-line with the shower head.

title: Very minor issues easily rectified!
text:
Love this little machine. Exceptional cleaning with proper water levels. Quiet!
Issue 1. At floor level, it's difficult to drain. I built a small, wheeled cart about 20 inches high so I can access the tubs easier and so I can drain right into the toilet, eliminating any worries about lint in my drains.
Issue 2. People look at the fill tube and assume that it's supposed to fit OVER the faucet aerator. It's not. If you trim the flange from the faucet end of the hose.
If you live in the U.S. it's an easy, EASY hookup. And no leaks even under some pretty good water pressure.
First, you have to trim the wide flange from the part of the hose that attaches to the faucet.
Then unscrew the aerator from the faucet and pop yhe screen out.
Slide the hose down through the aerator ring until it won't go farther.
Now, screw the aerator/hose assembly back onto the faucet and connect the other end to the left hand inlet.
Done.

All in all, it's a 9.75 out of 10.
