title: Improved My Quality of Life - Extremely Satisfied
text:
This review is for the skeptics - because I was one. I went back and forth about buying this machine for MONTHS, all while dragging my clothes to a laundromat. I worried that I would be wasting my money on this machine and that the reviews were too good to be true. I was worried that it would would flood my floor and downstairs neighbor. I was worried that it would be heavy and hard to use.

Well, fellow skeptics - I am here to admit I was wrong. I LOVE THIS MACHINE.

Within 2 weeks I feel that I’ve already gotten my money’s worth. I have been able to wash towels, sheets, a queen duvet cover, tons of clothing, delicate work shirts, and more. And let me tell you, they have come out SO CLEAN.

And while the machine doesn’t have a dryer, the spinner is far more powerful than I expected. The items come out barely damp and only need to hang dry for a little while before I can fold and put them away.

My tips:
I use the machine in the shower / bathtub. I fill it up with my detachable shower head until it’s at a good level (see inside for H/M/L aka High, Medium, Low) to know where to fill to. I then add a small amount of detergent, add the clothes, and walk away! After wash one, I drain, sometimes spin the clothes, refill, wash again and spin.

Some things you should know:
1) do NOT use too much soap. A little goes a long way. Just a splash of liquid detergent does the trick

2) the customer service is excellent. I will not lie, I had an issue with the first machine I ordered (it leaked). I emailed customer service and they sent me a new machine insanely fast. I felt like I was in good hands.

Still thinking about getting the machine? This is your sign! I rarely write reviews but this one deserve 5 stars.

title: Some workarounds for a good product!
text:
[[ASIN:B01ALBMIEI Giantex Portable Mini Compact Twin Tub 11lb Washing Machine Washer Spin Dryer]]

I've been using my Giantex portable washing machine for two weeks and I have a couple of thoughts for people who are considering purchase of this machine.

1) I gave this product 4 stars for the following reasons:

* The input hose could not be attached to my bathroom faucet (as others have noted).
* Water leaked out of the top seam of the washer tub when using the normal setting with a large load.

2) Draining the machine.

I did not buy a machine with a built in pump because I thought that would be one more thing that could break. However, if a siphon will not work for you, it is worth the money to buy a slightly more expensive machine that has a built in pump that will allow you to drain into a sink.

Some people solved the drainage problem by putting the machine on a platform or in a shower/tub. I had concerns about that because when the spinner is not balanced, it moves the machine around (which could cause the machine to fall off a platform) and because I felt nervous about having an electrical connection where water may puddle. I decided to place my washing machine on the floor of my bathroom. It is about 3 feet from one bathroom sink and about 3 feet from my tub.

I looked into buying an electric powered pump to drain the water (as another customer had noted). However, since that customer did not name the pump he bought, I spent time time researching pumps before deciding that most of them were either too expensive or didn't fit the configuration of pulling water from inside the washing machine's drainage hose as I wanted to do.

Because the drainage hose is about 2 inches about the floor, I thought that a siphon might work for me. For a test, I bought some cheap aquarium tubing and the siphon action worked. So, I bought a Plumber's Siphon Pro (on Amazon) for $13.49, and it works great. With the drain hose hooked vertically on the machine, I drop the weighted end of the siphon down to the bottom of the drain hose, pump the siphon bulb until the hose if full, and drop the end of the siphon hose into the tub drain, and the water starts draining.

3) Water input.

I considered replacing my shower head with a three way shower diverter, but decided against it because I do not need a hand held shower head. I also had some doubts about having to modify a shower head to allow a stronger water flow.

My solution was to connect a garden hose to one of my bathroom faucets. This is what I bought:
* Home Depot - "15/16 in.-27M / 5/64 in.-27F x 3/4 in. GHTM or 55/64 in.-27M Chrome Multi Thread Garden Hose Aerator Adapter" ($5.02 - shipped to store for pickup)
* Amazon - "American Specialty UT-10 10' Multi-Purpose Utility Hose" ($12.12).

I connect the utility hose to my sink faucet when I want to wash. It takes a few minutes to fill the wash tub. I put the end of the hose in my tub between wash and rinse cycles, and disconnect it when I am done washing. Also, don't leave the room when the wash tub is filling as the hose may fall out of the wash tub, and then yikes!!! what a mess.

4) Solution for water leaks on the top seam - Set the setting to "Soft" and fill no higher than the medium setting.

5) Solution for clothes tangling - Use laundry mesh bags to separate shirts and dainties in the wash tub (but take the clothes out of the bags when spin drying).

6) Solutions for out of balance spinner - Fold shirts, pants before putting them in the spinner tub. Don't overload the spinner tub.

Overall, I am very happy with this portable washing machine. I don't have to spend $10-$15 each week at the laundry mat. It's just me and my husband, so I can do small loads whenever I want. And my clothes get just as clean as at the laundry mat.

07-05-2016 Someone asked for pictures of my siphon setup. The first picture shows how far down the weighted end of the siphon hose will go inside the drainage hose (down to where the water exits the machine). The second picture shows the weighted end of the siphon hose inside the drainage hose. The third picture shows the water draining into the tub's drain. (Note the small strainer I bought at Walmart to catch any lint.) The fourth picture shows how the siphon hose snakes up the side of the tub and over into the tub. Once the water starts flowing, the suction is strong enough to pull water until there is no more water at the weighted siphon end. (Note the black siphon pump should be removed from the hose after the hose is filled with water.)

title: Skip the Laundromat! Also Great for Small Spaces.
text:
When I lived in a small studio temporarily I didn't want to continue to make trips to and from the laundromat. It just seemed like a waste of time, and quarters by the end of it. I was spot on when I purchased this item. It's absolutely fantastic.

As long as you have regular power, a water source, and a place to drain water, you can do laundry! It did take me a few minutes to figure out the "order of operations" which is pretty simple after the first time. (Add Water and Soap, Add Clothes, Let it Spin, Drain It, Add Clean Water, Let it Spin, Drain It, Move Clothes to Spin Dryer, Spin Them, Done!)

The only "con" I found with these is washing very delicate items. Think of very thin shirts or very easily stretched material. It's best to hand wash these items or just skip the spin dryer altogether and let them air dry. Just be cautious with any very special clothing items. For how functional this product is, it was well worth the investment and time to use it. Highly recommended.

title: SO FAR SO GREAT!
text:
Update 11/2018: still loving my portable washer after a year!! Tips: I've learned to wash once, drain water. Fill with clean water, then rinse once. Transfer clothes to spin dryer. Use water for the entire 5 minutes. Turn off faucet. Drain the soapy water into a bucket then pour in the washer (if you have another load to wash). Spin for a second time with no water. Your clothes should be practically dry. Don't over load the washer as it will not spin effectively. The water level should cover the clothes completely. Also wash towels for last as the lint gets on clothes. Finally hang dry on the shower curtain rod and you're done. And you CAN wash and spin at the same time to speed up the entire wash day. Great buy!!

Shipping was great. My washer arrived on time despite the delays with Hurricane Irma. I have already washed two "loads" one of which being my bathroom rug which took up the entire space in the washing tub. I decided to use my washer in the kitchen as opposed to the tub in the bathroom. It is not heavy but I imagined it can get tiresome moving it from the tub to the closet/wall. It is important to find an economical and functional space for it BEFORE you buy. As others have stated the paper directions that come with it are HILARIOUS so ignore those. A simple YouTube video on how it works is all you need. Another thing you will want to do is raise the washer off the ground. It is a gravity draining washer so you need to elevate it in order to drain completely. After looking for something to buy in store to no avail, I went to the hardware store and got materials to build this 9" tall wooden stand. (tip: ask the associate to show you to the scrap wood area. You may get a deep discount and/or even free wood like I did). I used a large dish pan to catch the water. Don't worry. You'll only have to empty it to two times max. I thought about getting a small cooler on wheels that I can put down there to have the water drain into, then when full just roll it out to the backyard and water the grass...But for now this will do. The spinner is AMAZING! I set it on 5 minutes and my bathroom rug (which I squeezed down in there and set for only 3 mins.) was completely dry. Clothes are 85%-90% dry. My only gripe (thus the 4 star rating) is the water inlet tube is too short to reach my kitchen faucet so I'm in the process of looking for a longer one. I DO NOT want to have to move the washer directly in front of the kitchen sink!to wash. Overall I am satsistfied so far. I will try my best to update this post every 3 months.

Recommendations:
1. If you notice leaks check your water level. Don't fill the water to high. I use the Medium line
2. Use just 1/4 cup of liquid soap or you will be rinsing for hours. And i do rinse at least one time. Drain the dirty water, fill tub with clean water and let wash for about 6 minutes. Less is truly more and your clothes will still be clean.
3. Use a fabric softener as well so your clothes won't have that rough, stiff feeling afterwards.
4. You will notice a burning rubber smell upon first use. Totally normally just like any electrical device when you first use it.
5. Don't overload the washer. It begins to shake when it's off balance. I washed 2 shirts, 3 pair of undies, one jean pant, 2 wash rags, 1 pair of socks sign I problem.
6. Leave both lids open after using so tubs can dry
7. Unplug unit when not in use.

title: Functional and Portable
text:
If you live in apartment or dorm this little machine is very handy and economical. The instruction booklet is trash, but the build quality is sufficient and the machine is capable. When used properly, clothes come out of the machine clean and mostly dry.

If you have a hand shower installed and set this up near or in your tub that makes it a lot easier. You'll have do relatively small loads and manually fill/drain the water - which is a bit of a hassle but such is the price you pay for not needing a dedicated hookup. Also, the spin dry and hang method can leave your clothes wrinkled, so make sure you have an iron if you want to wash dress clothes.

title: True Companion to the College Experience
text:
I'm a college student taking fifteen science credits and working part-time as a tutor. My days generally go from 8am to 8pm. My weekends have become homework/studying marathons. I often sit down at the start of each week and schedule my showers. Livin' the dream. So as a result, I hadn't done laundry in nearly three months. The clothes were piling up. So many clothes. So many. I've only had this guy for 48 hours, but he's changed my life. The clothes are clean and hanging in my closet where they belong. He's probably an angel. I have named him Wally.

Things to consider (but not things major enough to detract from my appreciation for Wally):
- As other reviewers have noted, the inlet tube nozzle does not attach well to very many water sources. Buckets are your friends.
- This boy needs gravity to drain, so the draining tube has to rest at a point that's lower than or equal to where the unit is sitting. The tube is also quite short, measuring out to be just under two feet.
- You'd might as well throw out the instructions as soon as you open the box.

It's super simple, but since the instructions are rubbish and, hey, new machines can be intimidating, here's how to use this boy:
1. Ensure the dial is set to "soft" or "normal." There are only three options; as long as it's not on "drain"!
2. Slap yer detergent in!
3. Slap some clothes in--my best advice is to just use your best judgment. If it's a helpful reference, I just ran a load of four pairs of jeans, three T-shirts, and some miscellaneous socks and whatnot and still kicked myself for not throwing in a few more shirts.
4. Dump that water in, friend!
5. Set the timer to fifteen minutes. Or less, I won't tell you how to live your life.
6. Is he done? Good! Set the dial to "drain" and, leaving your clean and vaguely soapy clothing inside, refill the tub; this is going to be our makeshift rinse cycle. Set the timer to your desired quantity of minutes, wait patiently, and pat yourself on the back for getting your laundry done on time.
7. Is he done again? Even better! Now you have clean and not-soapy clothing. Excellent! Shove as much as you can sensibly fit into the spin chamber, ensuring the dial is still set to "drain." You may need to separate the load, as his drying capacity isn't quite as great as his washing capacity. (I love him anyway.)
8. Close both spin lids--it's very important that the first one is closed all the way!--set the time, and let him rip! He will only spin for up to five minutes, but this is often more than enough.
9. He's done! Remove your things, hang them somewhere to dry, and thank him for a job well done.

Disclaimer: There is a rubbery plate with holes in it that comes with the unit. You are probably supposed to use it. I have no idea where to put this or what it does, but Wally runs perfectly in spite its absence.

Additional tips:
- Instead of fiddling with the inlet hose, good old-fashioned buckets are always an option! For me personally, the size of the unit and set-up of my apartment wouldn't allow me to attach it to a water source AND keep it within range a drain, so a 10-quart bucket has suited me fine. It's not as inconvenient as it sounds, promise!
- Kie, how much water goes in?! The instructions say to use 30-45 liters of water (depending on the size of the load), but I find that anything over about 38 liters (40 quarts) is too much once clothes are added.
- Kie, how much detergent do I use?! I find that filling my detergent cap to the lowest line (usually marked with "1" or similar) is suitable for medium- to heavy-sized loads.
- Kie, my boy keeps starting and stopping during the wash cycle! Is he okay? Yes! Starting and stopping every few seconds is normal; he's just changing directions and is still more than happy to clean your things.
- Kie, my boy is making scary sounds while he spins! Is he okay? Kind of! He's okay, but your things are very heavy and he may be asking you to take some out. He will also scream if things are sticking too far out of the chamber and getting close to the lid, so you may need to stop the spin cycle and gently readjust if this occurs. For me, this happened one time, and only because I was careless when loading things in--Wally is blameless.

So in short, this guy is great. He may or may not require a little finagling in the set-up department, but if you are kind to him, he will wash your things with no complaints. He probably saved my life. He's perfect.

title: Awesome powerful little portable washer for a great value!
text: I rarely write reviews but this product is just so wonderful that I feel I must!  I bought this to use on our boat about a year ago and it's been the best purchase.  It not only saves me time by not having to go home to do our laundry, or the hassel of going to the laundromat, but also money that I would have spent at the laundromat for "not-so-clean" clothes!  I have spent about the same amount of $ to purchase this washer as what I normally spend going to the laundromat in just 3 or 4 weeks time!  This machine is a workhorse, too.  I can wash 2-3 bath towels along with several sets of our clothes at the same time.  I've also washed a couple of extra large beach towels without any issue.  It cleans as good as my $2000 set that I use at home! Everything has a manual setting so I can choose how long things need to be washed and dried.  I love that it's also lightweight so I can easily slide it from the outside water source/sink over to the side of the boat to drain.  I can even reuse the water, if need be, with a bucket!  It uses a minimal amount of laundry soap and I can use my favorite bleach and fabric softeners.  I also love the "dryer", which is basically just a spin cycle, but it works great!  Our clothes are just slightly damp after washing and spin drying and dry very fast on my clothes line.  I have told all of our dock neighbors and I'm now the envy of all who have witnessed the power of this little guy!  I've also recommended to family who spend winters in AZ in a park model home and also have a small living space like we do. They are loving this just as much as I do!  It's also great for apartments, campers and college dorm rooms.  Don't waste your money, buy this one now!

title: Great invention for convenience
text:
It was delivered in great condition and I'm very happy with it. I'm disabled & I live in a studio apartment. I got tired of having to always get quarters every month. Krogers has stopped letting people exchange dollars for quarters, so now it's harder to get them. Which is a pain.
This is really nice, but being disabled it's a job. It reminds me of washing on a wringer washer.
And I use to love washing clothes like that, but I was younger & had more strength.
This takes a lot of effort, but it's convenient, gets the clothes very clean and all I do is hang dry the clothes and next day I have a few loads clean. My aide couldn't get stains out and I pay alot for my clothes, so this way I can take care of my clothes & make sure the stains get removed.
It'll wash half a load of a top loader, so that's not bad, but then you have to cut that in half when you spin dry. It's a job doing this. But it's good for me, cause I needed the exercise. I get very little sitting in all day, every day. I have Fibromyalgia & Sciatica and I'm in pain every day without EVER being given pain pills for the last 29 yrs. If you get pain pills thank God. I pray Sessions is humbled because he has no compassion for those of us who are in pain.
I can do this and that's good for me.
This is not for a big family. It's for one or two people. Whatever you think you need try it. It doesn't cost much and it's convenient. I love that about it. I'm glad it was invented.

title: Great for RV/Travel trailer
text:
We bought this for our travel trailer. We needed something for a small space, and didn’t want to use up a half day at the laundry mat.

Upon receiving, you can see from one of the photos a screw in the back was missing. We contacted the manufacturer who advised us to try and if the missing screw didn’t affect the performance, they’d give us some of our money back. It did work and they upheld their end as stated.

After using the first time our clothing was covered in lint. A quick google search led us to try 1/3 c white vinegar and 1/4 c baking soda added to each new water load. (That amount is for a full water load.) That breaks down and helps keep the majority of the lint from clinging to the fabric and works amazing! Of course that is added in addition to the typical detergent.

Also the amount of lint that leaves the machine through the drain pipe is quite a bit. Being in a travel trailer we didn’t want to put too much of that through the pipes. So, we tried a strainer in the drain which works amazing and catches all that extra lint.

We use it in the shower, but as seen in one of the photos, something needs to be placed under the machines legs, as it will vibrate-although very little, it will scratch the shower/tub surface.

The spinner simply spins out excess water. It does spin out a lot of water and some pieces of clothing will dry within a couple of hours; others take the normal amount of hanging to dry as it would coming from a normal full size washer in a typical residential home. (This time is from hanging them on racks inside our trailer).

All in all we Love this machine! It cleans well, and works great for a small space, it’s not really heavy and is easy to maneuver.

title: Great for small spaces
text:
I purchased the Giantex washer because I live in a small condo and it is expensive and inconvenient to use the laundromat. I am also newly single and no longer accumulate large amounts of laundry to separate dark from light colors and would have to waste money doing small loads or, worse, mixed loads, in larger commercial machines.

The Giantex washer allows me to wash smaller loads economically.. I put it in my bathtub and use the hand-held shower head to fill it, and just allow the drain hose to lie in the tub. I also used the styrofoam packing material as a stand to put it on so it reduces any noise or vibration (which is minimal).

The spinner removes so much of the water that the clothes dry very quickly.

I am fully satisfied with this purchase. I had scrutinized this product for a while before purchasing it and have not been disappointed. As long as you remember that it is not a fully automatic machine and you have to tend to the filling, draining, and spinning I am sure you would like it, too.

text: Works great! 5 stars for performance, convince, durability, price and  compact.However comparing to an automatic washer more manual labor and takes a little more time to wash because of it's size. It does look like a toddler play set because of it's size. But it's overall amazing. I also purchased the 5 year warranty and a drying rack. 1 load consists of 2 size 38 blue jeans, 2 large shirts and 2 boxers, basically 2 days worth of clothes. The drying spinner takes no less than 5 minutes however you need to hang your clothes to dry. Takes about 6 to 8 hours at room temperature 75 degrees. Sheets queen size takes about 4 hours to hang dry. I use a turkey baster to add water, as suggested on one of the reviews. Noise level I would not use at 4am because it is a little noisy but during the day not loud at all. Small socks can be a problem on the spinner and may land in the draining compartment. title: I LOVE THIS MACHINE! This thing really works!
text:
First off let me start by saying I love my little washing machine. My husband who is 6’4” and myself who is 6’2”, are able to wash a good amount of clothes in this washer with spinner. We both wear 4X-6X tee shirts, shirts, blouses, and I wear 24-26 in jeans, shorts, dresses, and skirts and my husband wears (I think a 52 in bottoms). So our clothes are big, which made me hesitant to purchase this item. We both have different techniques for how we wash, rinse, and spin when we wash clothes, so find a technique that works for you. I waited a good while after purchasing this product to do a review because I wanted to give a true tried and trustworthy review the reflects months of usage. The only complaint I have about this product is how useless the connection hose is for it and being it was so useless we fill the machine up by hand with a storage bin and we empty it the same way. IT DOES NOT TAKE A LOT OF DETERGENT TO CLEAN YOUR CLOTHES! Let me repeat this again it doesn’t take even a half of cap full of detergent to clean your clothes. We use Percil liquid detergent, OxyClean powder, Clorox bleach when needed, and quaternary disinfectant in each load. We’ve been using the same bottle of Percil and tub of OxyClean for about 6 months I think but anyways. It doesn’t take much detergent and the reason for this is because the washer unit is very strong inside the washing tub. If you have lightly soil clothes it does not take a full 15 minutes to wash them. Put the timer on 3 or 6 minutes and you have fresh clean clothing. The longest I put my clothes to spin is 3-6 minutes max. Why? Because this baby doesn’t need more time then that to spin the water out of garments. If items are heavily soil soak them first. Just fill the tub with dirty clothes and fill to water line or at least don’t fill over filter line add detergent, turn timer to 3 minutes and then let the clothes soak for about 30 minutes to an hour. Do not soak clothes in chlorine bleach for over 10 minutes. If you do, you run the chance of destroying your clothes. When I do a load of jeans I usually only put 2 pair max, 3 pairs of leggings, and maybe 3-4 pairs of workout shorts in a load and I turn the timer to 9 minutes with jeans. When it comes to shirts I can put at least 5-7 in one load; and for sheets I can do both flat and fitted but I do just one sheet at a time because they get cleaned better that way.
After the first initial wash cycle completes I empty the tub. Then I refill it with clean water and do a short 3 minute cycle. Then I remove the clothes from the wash tub and put half in the spinner for 3 minutes. As the water is flowing from the hose to my storage bin I look to see how clean or dirty it is and that let’s me know if and how much longer I need to rinse the clothes. So I take the first half of the load out the spinner and put them in the bath tub and run warm water over them and rinse them as the second half of the load spins. Take the first load out the tub and put back in the spinner and then hang them to dry. Yes, it seems a little much but I love to wash clothes by hand so it doesn’t bother me. But if you can find a hose long enough to fit on the washing machine and a floor drain then you can eliminate a lot of the steps I go through on wash day. This baby is powerful and will rock if you have it placed off the floor. I took the styrofoam insert that came with it and tape cardboard around it and placed our washer on top of that. It was a very good set up until the cardboard got wet. I should have wrapped it in a trash bag after putting the cardboard on it, lol. Well hindsight is 50/50 and because it rocks I try not leave it while it is washing, because honestly who wants to clean up all that water? Not me! If you have any question just reach and I will try my very best to respond in a timely manner, toddles!

title: Love it. Practical, efficient, great size!
text: I love this. I just got it today with the 3 year warranty. It is amazing! I’ve been washing all afternoon lol the instructions however were confusing and made things harder for me. It’s actually really simple though. Make sure it’s sitting on a stool or something so the cord doesn’t get wet and the machine can drain. Plug it in. First dial is for wash/rinse. Second dial is for draining (slow or fast. Fast isn’t crazy like I thought so I use that setting) and the third dial is for the spin/dry cycle. Left compartment is for wash/rinse. Second is for wringing it out. You add water via the hose but I will use my shower hose once it arrives. I used a bucket to fill for now. So you have to add water in left compartment twice, one for wash other for rinse. Not a lot of soap is needed. Anyway this is a life saver if you live in an apartment. Space wise it is not bad at all either.

title: I've learned to make it work.
text:
I needed better instructions as to how to use the two tubs. There's a learning curve/ trail and error. I've made it work, although it might not be as designed.

I had to buy a fitting to use it with my kitchen sink faucet. I've learned the hard way not to stray far when filling up the tub. It will spill over!

I cannot use it after 10pm because I don't want to disturb my downstairs neighbors. It's loud and vibrates a lot. It can even "jump", if I don't watch it closely.

I'm thankful to have a washer in my apt! I just have to set aside time to be very attentive.

title: Great washer, dryer does not dry.
text: Overall it does the job on the washing side, but it does not dry all the way. The dryer side is very small and the clothes come out damp. It isn’t too bad, I am able to hang dry shirts but pants are the issue lol. The drain is awkward too bc it doesn’t reach anything I have that can hold water, so I bring the tube to a bucket and dump the used water in my sink. Also, I figured this but do not over stuff the dryer. It may hold what you shove in there but the machine can break. Regardless of the flaws, I really do like it. however, I would look around more and find a portable w/ a bigger dryer + one that gets hot enough.

title: Spinner does a great job. I use mine for shop towels
text: This washing machine works very very well.  I am actually impressed.  It washes vigorously.  Can't tell much of a difference between Normal and Soft setting.  I have read reviews on here about people not using the water on the spinner side but what I do is wash a load, drain, then put half of load in spinner, turn water on in spinner and spin for 4 minuntes total....with water for 2 minutes, then turn water off and spin only for 2 minutes.  That's how I rinse my loads.  Saves time and water too.  Spinner does a great job.  I use mine for shop towels, red rags, and pet bedding.  Lint filter seems to work well.  Very cool washing machine and does a great job!!

title: Love it !!!!!
text: I love this machine and I would have given it five stars but there is a hole in the drain hose which leaks a little bit of water each time I use it and for that reason I'm giving it four stars… When used properly this is a fabulous machine… I do my wash then I take the items out and spin dry them while I'm draining the washbasin .... This removes the dirt and suds from the clothing most efficiently before I return them to the wash side and add fresh water for the rinse cycle… After that I spin dry them again and they are so super fresh and clean and I don't need fabric softener because They don't need softening… All  The detergent is completely gone and my cotton clothes smell like cotton and my wool clothing… (Yes I have washed wool sweaters and socks in there no problem )and they come out smelling like fresh wool ...  it's a great little machine if you want to be more conscientious about the water you use it takes me about 10 gallons to do a load of clothing and then I saved that water and dump it down my toilet to flush the toilet  .. this way not only in my conserving water by using less to wash my clothing but I am also using it to flush my toilet and saving water there also 😊😊😊😊  I was using the washing machine originally in my bathtub and lifting it in and out but now I have it sitting in my hallway on top of a wooden chest and I just carried the water back-and-forth to and from the bathroom and it's all very portable and very easy to do .. oh, and another thing… When I know I'm completely done using it I pour about a gallon of water back into the wash basin and turn it on for a couple of swishes to rinse it and then I drain it completely and dry the machine down with a microfiber cloths and leave the doors open to air it out… This way when it's not an use it is fresh clean  clean and dry .....  I would definitely give this machine thumbs up 😊👍😊👍

It does take some rigging on the input/output tubes, but it's not too difficult. I also built a cart for mine to sit on top of, since this is a gravity drain it needs to be higher than the drain.

title: I have a studio apartment and wanted to be able ...

Also the rinse hose is crucial to really wash/rise the clothes so be prepared to hook it up. I read about this machine and watch videos about how others eventually connected. Luckily, i realized my kitchen faucet extends far enough that I'm able to use. I have to stand and hold it but it works!

title: I'm so glad I bought this instead of dragging myself to the ...
text: I'm so glad I bought this instead of dragging myself to the laundry every two days at my complex. It is small enough to fit in my patio storage closet so I converted the closet to a mini wash room. I can wash a small load in about 20-30 minutes and then spin dry them when i'm in a time crunch to dry everything. It can be tedious but I love the freedom of not having to go to a laundry facility or pay some company to hold my laundry money on a card that deducts $1.00 for every $5.00 I put on the card. If you are single this is perfect and I even when I move to a place with washer dryer hookups I think I will just rely on this. Not only is is a fraction of the cost of a typical washer and dryer system it suits my needs. As long as I remember to do my laundry 1-2 days before I need clean underwear, I am good. Yeah it does require you to put water in it for which I have been using a mop bucket and I take advantage of the slight foundation sagging in my storage closet open the door and let the hose run the water out onto the patio/ grass area. I just make sure to use eco friendly detergent to keep it from poisoning my green space.  Also take note if you dont have enough clothes in the machine and turn it on high it will shake and sometimes it stabilizes itself. I put a foam mat beneath it.

title: One year on and still running!

Just don't overload it and your clothes will come out perfectly clean.

You just have to see how fast it spins to determine if its overfull or not.

Hanging clothes seems to wear them out faster than having a dryer, which is a sad thing. I am not sure if its the washing machine itself but my clothes have been deteriorating over the past 2 years or so since I was using it. Not like, crazy like bleach does, but just thinner material, easier to rip/etc. Maybe it was using too much detergent. Maybe the machine is hard on clothes. I am not too sure. But either way its a nice machine.

title: Great machine, needs some diy to make it work for you
text:
I love this machine and use it to wash everything in my home. Six months in and it is still working perfectly. The only item I can’t wash in it is the bed comforter as it is too large. We live in a five floor walk up and going up and down to the laundry room that works half the time has gotten too tedious over the years. This machine allows me the freedom to do laundry whenever I feel without exhausting myself.

For a household of two, I keep things controlled with about 2 loads per week. I store the machine in our pantry, where I can easily slide it in and out. I used the top of a cheap turkey baster to attach the hose to the kitchen sink, as it wont connect on its own. As the machine drains from the bottom using only gravity, I lift it up using bed risers and drain the water into a five gallon bucket that I dump in the sink. I personally fill, run, and drain the wash cycle three times per load. This always cleans the clothes perfectly. The spin dryer wrings the clothes very well, but they still need to dry for at least 12 hours on a drying rack. Some lint is left on the clothes after each wash, but this is remedied with a lint roller. Our electric bill remains relatively low. I definitely feel I’ve gotten my money’s worth out of this machine and will never go back to a public laundromat.

title: Came dirty, but works as intended. Good, bad, and a couple tips!
text:
Good: It came in like 3 days! The box is not too heavy to get into your home on your own. It washes clothes fine and the spin dry works well. Your clothes will be dry and ready-to-wear the next day. I do not regret buying this thing (but will update this review if I have any problems).

Bad: The washer side was dirty upon delivery. There were also a few water droplets! It smelled like fresh plastic but didn't look like it. I saw how difficult it was for other buyers to contact the seller so I just made sure it worked (it did) and cleaned it out with a gentle cleaner and paper towels, followed by filling it with water and a little vinegar and letting it run and drain. The machine is actually kind of hefty/awkward to move but not too bad. A little bigger than expected.

Advice: (1) You do NOT need to attach the 'water inlet' hose to this thing. I just use a bucket of water and pour it into the machine. Probably faster this way anyway.

(2) If you're like me and have a small/tiny bathroom and nothing to put this thing on, you can get away with draining MOST of the water into a bucket on the ground next to the machine (no machine elevation needed). Once most of the water is out, it will be light enough to manually raise up onto the side of the tub to finish draining... a little extra but it works if you don't have anything to put this thing on. If anyone has any good and simple ideas to help me out here PLEASE share :)

title: Hose will leak after few weeks
text: This guy is really small and portable. Fits in my tub. However, hose is made of really cheap material, it's like candy wrapper. Drain hose size is 1 1/4" fyi. Most of the designs @amazon and Home Depot doesn't fit under the machine because it's small.

title: How to use the washer
text:
If you did not get a defected product like I did It is fantastic :) ( I had two since one was for my sisters house one for mine.)
Shortcomming... The hose is too small both to connect it to the sink and the draining hose. you need to either have it where it can drain outside or you need to buy something stable where it raises higher than the kitchen sink or bath tub.
you need to set the timer for everything
Benefits
Easy to carry not heavy at all.
It fits a pretty good size amount of clothing
The draining system is simple to understand
It allows you to choose how much time each item will have.

How to use:
I know my mom almost ruined mine for not knowing how to use the washer:

1st put clothing inside of the washing tub
2nd fill up the tub so that all of the clothing is covered (usually its about 3 1/2 bucket fulls)
(Add soap to a small amount of water to delude then poor to prevent clogging)
(make sure that the middle knob is not in draining.)
(Also make sure that the water is at least a fist full higher than the clothing it washes better)
3rd set the timer
4th after time ends move the middle knob to drain
(make sure the hose is in sink before you make the switch since water will drain instantly)
open the spinner side
5th inside the spinner side there is a white circle take that out
6th push clothing in to the bottom of the spinner side make sure you do not over fill
(sometimes you have multiple spins per wash since wash side fits more clothing)
7th after filling spin side put the white circle back in and push down
8th put timer on spin side and wait.
(while you wait and after the washer is done draining you can refill the water in the washing side)
Wash the clothing again and spin again before hanging the clothing.
For the best results you have to wash the clothing at least twice in order to remove all of the soap from the clothing.

title: Such a clever little machine!!!
text: I absolutely adore this nifty little guy! It was the perfect solution for living in a small space and wanting to avoid using a small community laundromat because people tend to hog the machines. Definitely not for the absent-minded; just be smart about not overloading it, have enough water to cover the clothes, do NOT use too much detergent, and if you don't have a place to drain the water and plan to use a 5 gallon bucket like I do--just be mindful. A "full" wash load generally doesn't need more than 5 minutes in my opinion. I was surprised at how powerful this machine is, it's impressive! Not a machine you can walk away from, at least not for me. I usually have to hold onto it to keep it steady for a full load, probably an unnecessary precaution on my part, but that's how strong it is. I do have it on a raised surface to drain. Other reviews say that's not necessary, you'll have to find that out for yourself. The spinner part is awesome too, doesn't usually need any more than 2 minutes. Clothes come out slightly damp so underwear/t-shirts air dry in about an hour, which is pretty quick compared to air drying clothes coming out of a regular washer. Only thing this machine doesn't do is get fur out of your clothes like a dryer does, but hey, that's what a lint roller is for!

title: I'd buy this again in a heartbeat!
text:
I have this portable washing machine! My husband and I live on the third floor, so getting the laundry done is a Pain.

We have it on wooden board on the back of the tub - the wooden board has non-slip grips on it, and we weigh it down with some 5 pound hand weights to help with the vibrations. If there was somewhere I could place it on the ground that I could still drain it from I'd do that, but this works pretty well.

Tips, tricks, and other important things from someone who's had this for a year plus:

1) You NEED a mesh lint trap and some cut pantyhose over that, attached to the drain hose. A lot of lint comes out of the machine.

2) You also NEED those floating lint catch things for agitater-less washing machines. The built in one catches next to nothing. (You still need the mesh and pantyhose combination too.)

3) You can wash the equivalent of 8 L/XL men's shirts at a time. Personally, I do one 15 minute round with hot soapy water, then one or two 15 minute rounds of cool plain water. You can salad-spin dry 4 L/XL men's shirts at a time.

(You can't have the washer washing and the spinner spinning at a time, FYI. As I'm filling the tub is when I'm spinning the clothes.)

4) Soap. A tablespoon or so of laundry detergent is good, or one detergent pod broken down into two cups of hot water. That's the perfect amount for us.

Overall, this is a good price for a portable washing machine. Is it as good as a proper washing machine and heated dryer? No. Does it work for smaller spaces, as long as you don't mind the washing and drying times? Absolutely.

title: Almost speechless. PERFECT for a primary OR secondary washing machine, dorm rooms and cloth diapering.
text:
I am SUPER greedy with my 5 star reviews but I'd give this one a 10 star if I could. I bought this to use while my full size washer was being repaired. It came in and I ALMOST returned it because my full sized was fixed. THEN there was an issue with the drain pipe from my full sized washer. SO, I opened this one. I was reallyyyy skeptical because its so light and small..I mean, my first thoughts were, "Can this REALLY possibly wash clothes and get them CLEAN?!" Uhh YES.

Setting up:
I have a second bathroom so I just placed the whole set up by the tub. (This can EASILY be set in and out of the tub if you wanted to do it that way) The plug in cord, water line and drain hose are all relatively short. The diameter of the water line is about nickle sized, the drain hose is about golf ball sized. (my awful measurement descriptions, sorry, lol) Its pretty cut and dry. Don't expect that water line to fit pretty much any standard faucet or water outlet. Be prepared to manually fill it with a bucket until you figure out what to connect the line to. I actually went to a hardware store and got a rubber hose and tension clamp.

First use:
I plug it in and put 4 full sized towels, 3 tshirts and a handful of socks in, a teeny amt of laundry soap and washed for 12 minutes. The guide says to wash fora bout 6 minutes. I went longer because i thought it wasn't going to work for just 6. Wrong again, for that load, i could have easily went for 6 minutes...10 minutes if I wanted to drag it out. To drain the water, you turn the dial from Normal to Drain. Its a gravity drain but works well. After draining the water, I rinsed them and eyeballed the spin dryer.

Rinsing:
There are really two ways to do this. (1) is to hook the water line to the right side of the machine and as it spins, turn the water on for about 5 seconds and then turn it off and let it spin another 15 seconds. (2) is to drain the wash, add clean water and let it run another 3 minutes then drain and spin. (IF you want to use fabric softener: drain, fill, add softener, 3min cycle, drain and rinse)

The spin dryer:
I dropped a towel in (soaking wet) closed the lid and turned the dial. WHOA. 15 seconds of spin and i cut it off. Opened it up and pulled a "damp" towel out. By damp, I mean, if you shower, get out and dry your hair and body off with a towel kind of damp. I was super impressed. When you spin dry, only put in 3-4 things and make sure to drop them straight into the middle so it can balance it as it starts to spin.It only takes 15-20 seconds to spin the hell out of anything you put in there. Why this timer goes up so high is beyond me. You should NEVER need to spin anything that long in this machine...unless you're using it to churn a gallon of butter.
ONE LOAD: 1 min to fill, 6 min to wash, 3 min to rinse with spinner (4-5 to rinse with washer tub) TEN- TWELVE minutes for ONE load of laundry. You can NOT beat that.

Overall:
I am shocked. Highly impressed and I am SO glad I kept this. I have 3 daughters (ages 10-15) who LOVE changing clothes 11 times a day. This is now THEIR washing machine. 9pm and you realize you don't have your favorite skirt clean? Go wash it in YOUR machine. For my teenager, one load will hold 3 pair of uniform pants, three tops, 2 skirts, a tshirt or two and underclothes. This could be a serious game changer for dorm rooms, extended vacations and guest houses. I can't tell you how underestimated this thing is. This machine makes it ok to just wash a shirt and a pair of pants. You control the amount of water, time and soap so you aren't wasting anything. If you're on the fence about it, rest assured that this little sucker will surprise you.

As a side note, those who use cloth diapers, reusable menstrual underwear or cloth feminine products, this is the PERFECT laundry machine. Its almost like it was made for it. We cloth diaper and I can easily soak, wash and strip a days worth of diapers in no time. AND it spins out the water so well that it takes MINIMAL drying time.

text: I bought this washer dryer, as a mere peon. It was supposed to take a week to arrive, and it arrived TWO DAYS LATER. All I had to do was plug it in, and instantly my life turned into a fairytale. I was rich. RICH rich. My clothes were being expertly and aggressively washed IN MY OWN HOME. Spin dry you say? HAH like that does anything. I said the same. The clothes come out of a 5 min spin DRY. LIKE ACTUALLY DRY.  My net worth sky rocketed. My quality of living improved one million percent, instantly. Men want to marry me, and women want to be me. All because of this $169 washer dryer. A life before this, was not worth living. I see that now. But hindsight is 20/20. Welcome to your new life, friend.

Now I’m enjoying my old routine having a few beers while doing laundry and it gets my clothes a lot cleaner than any he machine since it actually fills with water and thrash’s my clothes in vortex of water and detergent and a serious spin that extracts  instead of being  slopped around in a shallow puddle of H.E BS that takes over a hour to barley do anything that reflects a good wash. Yea it’s not a fully automatic machine BUT IT DOES ITS JOB AND DOES IT WELL and that makes it worth the extra effort any day of the week. If you live in a apartment with no washing machines I would highly recommend. If you have a nice big house and are in the market for big new machines SPEND THE EXTRA MONEY ON COMMERCIAL SPEED QUEEN MACHINES THAT ARE BUILT TO LAST A LIFETIME AND WILL CLEAN BETTER THAN ANY H.E MACHINE AT BEST BUY.

title: Way Better than hand washing underwear in the sink!
text:
I bought this unit about three months ago, and it came damaged so upon calling the company I was given a replacement immediately. The customer service department is wonderful! I do laundry 3 days a week and this works nicely.

I hooked this up in my basement to the utility tub and put the drain tube in the drain hole. I used my old washing machine hoses to connect to the unit and sink just cutting the hose to size with a kitchen knife so no real issues there.

The unit itself is deceivingly small upon appearance but I can fit a whole bunch of clothes in there. As long as I divide them up in the spinner, I can fit in one load:

10 T-Shirts- Ranging from size 5/6 (kids) to Adult XL
3 hoodies- Sizes Small-Xl
10 pairs of yoga pants/kids sized pants
3 pairs of jeans/sweatpants Adult sizes
A massive amount of socks/underwear/bras
4 full sized towels.
3 queen sized sheets
4 single sheets
smaller blankets/NO QUILTS

For drying, I bought garment racks for $10 each and put them over heater vents in my apartment. I just hang up the clothes, and they dry in a few hours. Towels I line dry in my basement, and for socks/underwear bras etc I use a laundry bag and place it on the heater vent and shake it up whenever I remember. I do plan on buying a dryer eventually but for now this works for my family of 6.

The cons are you do have to fill, drain and spin. It is not automatic, so if you are the type that needs/wants a machine that does it all for you this is not it. On the other hand, if you are happy just having clean clothes, and don't mind a little extra work, it is well worth the price.

title: Works good, just noisy.
text:
So I've had this washing machine a couple of months now and personally I think it works great. It saves me a lot of money and a lot of time. I live by myself so I don't have a lot of clothes to wash in the first place. I use it once per week and I mainly just put it in my tub on a couple of old storage containers I've had lying around.
So a couple of downside are: it's noisy, doesn't have a hose for the fill spouts, and gravity drain.
1. It doesn't come a with a hose for the fill spouts. Honestly not a big deal I just use my showerhead to fill the machine. However if you want the hose you got to buy it separately.
2. It's noisy. This sucker is noisy as hell. You want a quiet machine, this is definitely not it. It's not as noisy as a regular washing machine but you definitely know it's running.
3. Gravity drain. Basically you got to put it at higher elevation to make it drain properly.
Otherwise great machine for someone living alone. Works good, just noisy.

text: This is the 3rd portable washer I’ve had in 6 years. They were all the same. After about two weeks of use, I found that there would be a little bit of water sitting in the bottom of the spinner at times when I was using it. And when this would happen it wouldn’t spin at normal speed so I couldn’t spin out the water in the clothes. And if I tried to spin it with nothing in it, the same thing happened. After letting it sit idle for some time, it would eventually spin at full speed and spin the sitting water out. Even when I tried to soak up the sitting water, nothing changed. I’ve never had this with any other washer. This is very frustrating as I’m stuck in the middle of doing laundry and it causes a huge delay.

title: Don’t even hesitate!!! ADD TO CART!!!
text: My washer arrived yesterday and I’ve already washed 3 loads of laundry! I live in a small duplex, and have been hauling clothes to the local laundry mat for the last 2 years! Finally decided to make this purchase, and oh my gosh, I’m so glad I did. There was a very helpful video, a girl uploaded in the reviews, so I didn’t even have to read the instruction booklet. I love how light weight this machine is, how quick the cycles are, how clean my clothes come out, and how great the spin dry side is. I’M IN LOVE WITH MY NEW WASHER! I do have back steps that I decided to set it out on. This made it super easy to just drain it right off the side of my steps. My first two loads, I had it in my shower, so I could easily fill it from the shower head. But it didn’t drain as good considering it was on a flat surface. Definitely easier if your washer is higher than the drain hose. No matter what, this machine is awesome! The picture I uploaded hopefully gives an idea of how tall it is. (It’s in front of my bathroom sink) It’s a lot smaller and lighter than I expected which is just a plus!! I’d buy it all over again, if I could. Love it!

title: - Great customer service
text:
Pros:

- Great customer service!
- Cleans very well. I also love how our clothes smell so fresh after using this! I've been using automatic washer for 6 yrs and never had such a fresh smelling clothes before.
- Takes a lot of clothes for a portable washer! took around 6 items of my husbands pants and shirts. And almost all of my 4 yrs daughter's laundry.
- Arrived quickly and in great shape.
- Spin dryer is good enough.

Cons:

- you will probably need an adapter to attach the provided tube to your faucet.
- it has a gravity based drainage system. Which means you can't put it on the floor and empty the water in a sink! I had to empty the drainage water in a container and then carry it to the sink. You also need to put the washer on an elevated surface to empty all the drainage water.

I ended up preferring paying double the price for an automatic portable washer!

text: So far so good. My only problem is the weight which is something I knew in advance.  What I do wish is that there was an adapter for the fill hose. It most certainly doesn't fit any faucet. Have to fill the washer with a bucket. I am 71 years old and lifting buckets of water is hard on my back. I put the washer in my tub since it is gravity drain. I would suggest to anyone who buys this to keep the bottom of the box. I use this to slide it across the floor. I  have to keep this hidden in my closet because I live in an apartment complex that pays the water bill. If caught......  Other than that I love the washer. Now my neighbor next door bought the same thing about a month or so before I did and she has already tore hers up. I hand wring the clothes out before I spin them. That way the load does not go off balance. DON'T I repeat don't overload the spinner. Two or three items is plenty enough. If you are doing jeans only spin one pair at a time.  If some of your clothes, like mine, are cotton then yes you will have to maybe iron. Best money I have spent in a long time.

title: No more nasty laundromats! Yay!
text:
I purchased one of these little washers for my daughter and son-in-law who live in their 5th wheel. Their RV is plumbed for a combo washer/dryer, but they don't have an extra $1200 laying around right now to purchase one.They recently had a baby and are cloth diapering, and trying to find laundromats on the road can be problematic when needing to do laundry very frequently, not to mention the cost. They've had the Giantex mini for a month and love it! I also live in my RV and travel full time and just purchased a second unit for myself.
Yes, it's made in China, something I try to avoid. Yes, it's all plastic, again something I try to avoid. Yes, if you wash a large load you will have to spin it in two separate loads. No, the hose doesn't fit on any faucet known to modern man, but in an RV they work fantastically just placing the washer in the tub or shower, using the handheld shower head to fill it. No, it doesn't have a drain pump and relies on gravity but again it works fine in an RV just laying the drain hose in the bottom of the shower so the waste water goes right down the drain. Weight is always a major consideration in an RV, and at only 25 pounds or so it's lightweight enough to easily move it when you need the tub/shower.
This little machine is amazing. It holds a surprisingly large amount of clothes. A typical load for me consists of a pair of jeans, a t-shirt, a tank top, a pair of underwear, a pair of socks, maybe a dish towel or sweatshirt. The jeans do twist up a bit, but nothing major. Everything comes out clean, and the lint trap in the washer seems to work pretty well. The loads only take a teaspoon or two of laundry soap, another cost saving.
The spin dryer works extremely well, removing an amazing amount of moisture, and items hung indoors dry within a hour or so, jeans or heavy sweatshirts of course taking a bit longer. If I hang things outside they dry even faster. The machine is also very quiet both washing and spinning. The spinner is a little loud when it first starts, but once it gets up to speed and has jettisoned most of the water it's very quiet.
I can wash any of my clothing, towels or queen size sheets with no problem. Obviously a spin dryer won't remove lint as well as a conventional dryer does so I wash bath towels separately. If I washed delicates I would probably put them in a mesh bag to protect them. The only thing I will still have to take to the laudromat occasionally is a thick comforter due to it's size.
For the purchase price of $85, this is the bomb. If it only lasts 3 or 4 months it will have more than paid for itself, and I would just order a new one instead of going back to hauling things to the laudromat.

title: Just what I needed
text: After much thought, I purchased this washing machine in Jan 1923. Held off on review until I used it for a while. 3 months later, it is still working like a champ! I run around 3 loads a week. Yes, you can wash queen sheets. I do 1 pillowcase and sheet as a load. Check out YouTube videos for tips. Ty to whoever suggested leaving water in tub while using spin side, it really does cut down on vibrations. I use mine in walk in shower using extended shower head to fill it up. I like to think of it as an “ interactive” washer….you’ll get the hand of it. Thank you for making this quality product.

title: Good buy. Works well.
text:
Works great, wish it auto drained after a cycle though! Can't tell you how many times I've started and forgotten it! I might think about modifying it if anything breaks. If it lasts two more years I'll give a 5 star rating!
Tip: Don't wash towels with anything else. Lint gets everywhere!
Tip: Use Fabric softener!!! Didn't use any the first time and my clothes where like cardboard.
Tip: Buy a cheap clothes rack. The spin cycle will by no means dry your clothes. They will still be damp. Hang em up!
Tip: Sometimes there's dirt left in the wash bin after a cycle, so rinse it out before doing another load.
Tip: Others usually run a rinse cycle as well as the wash cycle, I just run a wash cycle and my clothes come out okay. User-preference.

Overall it was fairly cheap and saved me from going to the terrible laundromat or driving an hour to my dad's. As long as you do a load as it comes you'll never have to do a ton of loads at once. It's also a plus since utilities are paid in my apartment so this is a huge cost saver.

When you get it, rinse it out. They test them in what appears to be a dirt covered area. The feet where dirty and there was a little dirt inside.

My setup:
I have this setup next to my shower, which I put on one of those shower heads with the detachable head and I use that to fill it. I run the drain pipe into the shower. I use the water tube it came with as a bumper to reduce the vibrations by connecting each end to both inlets and then letting it hang behind it. I then scoot it against the wall.

Instructions (since the ones with it are in broken English.
Wash:
Before running a wash cycle make sure the center knob isn't on drain.
1. Load laundry, not too much.
2. Fill to just under the top two holes by the lint catcher.
3. Push your clothes down and if you can fit a few more add them now.
4. Add about a half cup of detergent, and about a quarter cup of softener.
5. Turn the Wash timer knob to the full 15 minutes.
6. When it's done turn the center knob to drain.
After it has drained move your clothes to the spin drum.
'Drying':
Before 'Drying' make sure the center knob is on drain.
1. Add clothes, no more than the inner ring of the spin drum.
2. Put the little round plastic piece on top of your clothes and push them down as much as you can keeping it level.
3. Close the lid and turn the 'De-watering' knob to the full five minutes.
It'll start to vibrate and sound like its coming apart but it will soon stabilize and the noise will go down a bit.
Once done hang them.

It is fairly loud if you are by it, but I close the door to my shower (its in its own little room here, weird right?) and I can't really here it much. My neighbors share the wall its up against and they said they can't hear it so don't freak out too much.

title: Perfect solution for our summer cottage!
text:
We've contemplated how to fit a stackable washer/dryer into our cottage for years. I suddenly thought of looking up this type of machine. I bought it based on other reviews and that Fakespot gave the reviews an A. Lots of help and advice for setting this up and how to use because the enclosed instructions aren't great.

The hose attachment is the hardest part to figure out. We put this in our small shower. It fits perfectly. We used the rubber glove method to hook up the hose to the machine. Make sure the glove part is securely over the shower head. Have a good amount of the glove outside of the rubber bands on the shower head itself. This will keep it from leaking.

We used it all summer for four of us. No laundromat needed, which was a relief in the times of the pandemic. We hope to get lots of use out of it during our summer stays. We'd buy it again.

title: Pass on this one - Do more research to buy a better quality machine!
text:
The spin cycle broke on my portable Costway washer. I had a technician from Puls come and look at it, but he said it would cost more to repair it. At least I can still use the washer part, but I have to wring the excess water out of my clothes by hand and go to the laundry room to dry them. Unfortunately my studio has no washer and dryer in the unit. I bought a portable washer to avoid paying for the laundry room, but I have no choice at this point till I can buy a better quality machine. It was only $100.00 on Wish, but it's not under warranty anymore with Costway. The machine is made in China and there is no service center in the United States. Basically my money went down the drain. 😣

It is fairly easy to move around, though. A little heavy, but I can lift it on my own to put in the shower with no problems. A little noisy, but not bad. The water inlet hose provided was too small to fit onto my faucet, so I bought a special hose from Home Depot to fill the washer with. The instructions that came with the washer are useless, so I watched several YouTube videos to learn how to operate it.

If you're thinking about getting a portable washer, whatever you do, DON'T buy this washer! Do your research and get something better!

title: It’s okay

title: It works well.
text:
I am a graduate student living in an apartment with no private washer/drier. This is the only thing that I use to wash my clothes. It works well. The only thing that I don't like is the hose lengths/ diameters. That being said with a little bit of ingenuity it is easy to figure out. Also, the instructions do not make sense but it is self explanatory. Here are the steps that I take (others might do it differently).

1)Move washer into the bathtub, connect the hose to a water supply somehow (I use the showerhead and a glove), and insert the other side of the hose into the washer input (there is a washer and a spin cycle input, the washer one is the leftmost one). Connect to the power supply.
2) Fill with clothes but be careful not to overfill. If you overfill you will notice that once you start the engine will struggle quite a bit. If this happens just take some of the clothes out.
3) Start to fill up with warm water and add washing detergent. Use a lot less detergent than you normally would.
4) Wash for 13 min. Once the cycle is over drain (if you have more clothes that you need to wash I take the clean clothes out and add the dirty clothes in with the same water). Drain once done.
5)Move some of the clothes to the spinner. Make sure that it is balanced and not overfilled (I do it about halfway). Add the security lid.
6) Connect hose to the rinse input on the left side and start rinsing the clothes in the spinner with cold water. Spin for 30 secs and rinse again. After you are happy with the rinse spin for 2 and a half minutes.
7)Repeat as necessary (about two spin cycles per washing load) and airdry all your clothes once you are finished.

title: Missing pieces and burning motor belt.
text:
After reading reviews I was excited to get this. However, it arrived today, and when I tried to use it the motor for the washer was not working. I had to take the back off and found that the motor belt was not attached. That wouldn’t be the biggest deal in the world, but then I saw that one of the bolts that holds the washer motor secure was straight up missing. Not in the box, and nowhere to be found. Due to it not being there, the motor rocks like crazy and has been slowly leaning towards the washer. It has also been making an awful burning smell due to the belt burning (I can only assume due to the leaning motor caused by the missing pieces).

I’d go out and get some replacement pieces for the motor, but in order to install them I’d have to take apart the entire inside and then reassemble it. At this point I really wish I hadn’t bought it, though due to the high reviews otherwise I’m thinking mine may have been a fluke.

Also, the instructions are absolutely worthless. Obviously not translated by someone who knew what they were doing (probably Google Translate, honestly), and their only real use is for a brief laugh. For an example of the gems in the instruction manual, I quote “Even evenly puts in the clothing escapes in the bucket” and “Put drain horse in wrong direction?”.

title: Amazing appliance, never going to the laundromat ever again.
text:
This unit is amazing. Cleans clothes very well and doesnt make too much noise. Like another reviewer mentioned, I installed mine in the bathtub. I've done multiple loads and the machine cleans just as well as the big commercial machines at my local laundromat.

-Throw away user manual, read reviews for information on how to operate
-Throw away water hose, its not necessary
-Fits in bathtub, light enough to easily carry in and out of the tub (~30 lbs)

Instructions on how I use it:
-Plug power cord into an outlet
-Make sure cycle dial is set to "Normal" or "Soft"
-Add soap to left compartment (this is the washing side)
-Add water to left compartment - I use handheld showerhead but you can use a bucket or pot
-Add clothes to left compartment, fill approx. halfway
-Set wash timer to 15 mins
-Once wash timer has completed, set cycle dial on "Drain"
-Drain soapy dirty water to prepare for rinse
-Once water has drained, change cycle from "Drain" back to "Normal" or "Soft"
-Fill up left side with water for rinse cycle
-Set wash timer to 6 mins
-Once rinse cycle has completed, set cycle back to "Drain"
-Drain dirty water
-Move wet clothes from left compartment to right compartment (spin compartment)
-Press wet clothes down and put in plastic dish
-Set spin cycle to max

title: Solid, RELIABLE washer even after 3 years since purchase!
text:
Well guys, you’re all probably wondering ‘Is this thing going to stand up over the long-term? Is it worth the money? Is it going to break down after 3 months then I’m screwed? I am here to tell you that after 3 years of having my washer, ITS STILL RUNNING LIKE A PRO!

Pointers I would recommend: If the hoses don’t directly fit, then just put your shower head (hose) into the tub directly and fill it that way. And as long as you can get the washer high enough so that the drain tube can make it over the side of the tub to drain into the tub, then you’re good to go!

I ended up buying a flat dolly (kind of like a little pallet on wheels) from a hardware store then added some small planks of wood on top of that to raise it even higher then put the washer on top. It works like a charm!

I would recommend the following in this order:

- Wash a load for like 10 mins; drain the water and begin refilling with clean water

- Put that load in the spinner for the full 5 minutes (the dial maxes out at 5 mins)

- Once the tub is refilled, take the load out of the spinner and into the tub to rinse. Give it a solid 8 minutes.

-Finally put in the spinner for 5 minutes and they are good to dry!

I hope you found this helpful because let’s face it: this is all new to you. You don’t want to waste your time on crap product and you also have no clue how the hell it works in the real world. I hope I answered all those questions for you.

Make the purchase. You won’t regret it.

title: Cleans clothes, waiting for the next problem.
text:
Had it for 3 weeks, about 8 loads. It started to make a slight knocking noise, but it was working ok. When I went to move it, there was a nut laying under the machine. Thinking it was just left loose during manufacture I just put it back on. But when tightening it up is just spun on the bolt before it got tight. Turns out the nut was poorly manufactured and did not fit the bolt. I went to the hardware store and bought the proper nut and washer and problem solved for now. Waiting for the next problem. Also, you have to keep the original box to return it. I have it, but who keeps a box for the entire warranty period?
I think it gets my clothes cleaner than using a larger laundrymat washer. I recommend filling the water to the highest level and not over loading it. The high water level lets the clothes float more and tangle less. Socks stretch in the spin tub just as much as they do in the washer so keep stretchables in the laundry bag during the spin too.

text:
Absolutely love this item!!!

title: Very good as long as you know it's limitations
text:
[[VIDEOID:8089a25eb7c0eb1b9eb048eb45484d]] I bought this washer after Hurricane Harvey destroyed my home in 2017. I made this video after a few months use and still to this day in October 2021, use it. In fact, since my Whirlpool broke and I was waiting for replacement parts, I used it the other day to wash 3 loads so I, and my sons could have clean clothes.

First thing you should know is to NOT overload it. 2-3 pairs of jeans MAX. You can wash a light twin/full fleece blanket but only 1 at a time. Normally you would put in enough clothes to fill it no more than 2/3rd full, half full would be better. As for water, do not fill it higher than the top of the filter in the back corner. The 2 water inlets have a diameter of 1/2 inch, so I use clear vinyl tubing on them. DO NOT use a hose clamp to tighten on any hose, the plastic can crack.

In my video, you'll notice I wash, drain, spin, rinse, spin. I do it this way because I have allergies and I need to get as much soap out as I can. As for soap, use very little. Liquid soap I use a 20 oz bottle capful, powdered soap I use 2 capfuls. Any more than that and you will be rewashing your clothes 2-3 times to get all the soap out.

When using the spinner, be sure to use the included flexible cover and push down firmly on the clothes to force out as much water before closing the lid and running the spin cycle. That will lessen the possibility of out of balance vibration which could damage the motor and it's bearings.

I have rinsed clothes while they were being spun, however that doesn't seem to get all the detergent out and as I said, I have allergies and need it all out. So I rinse my clothes through a second wash cycle with fresh water.

The plastic top of mine has yellowed, but that doesn't affect the washer at all, and when I washed clothes the other day out on the porch since the weather was nice and I could reuse the water to water my garden, I just sat on the porch and read while the clothes washed. The sun light seemed to have faded the yellowing plastic back towards white.

All in all, this was a good purchase for my family. Just as long as you are aware of it's limitations, you should have no issues.

title: Best $100 I've ever spent.
text: I've been using the washer for over a month and so far this thing is the best and I love it. I bought it not really expecting much but I still can't believe how great it works. I live in an apt where having a washer and dryer isnt an option. I can use the ones in the basement but they suck and cost more then the laundromat. But I hate the laundromat even more.  I was hoping to be able to do a few shirts and a pair of jeans during the week just to get by til I had to no choice but go do laundry. I haven't had to go since I got this washer. I can do Jean's, heavy sweaters, and sweat shirts. You just have to take it easy when loading it. I can do two pairs of Jean's and a few shirts with no problem. Just keep in mind this isnt a full size and is somewhat small. But if you dont over load it your clothes will come out very clean.  I get filthy at work. My work clothes are usally covered in grease and dirt. Most of which are heavily stained.  I've had a few pairs of jeans and shirts that look brand new after I washed them.  And the spinner rings out the clothes so good they come out almost dry. I just wish the spinner was bigger.  I have to split up a load but its not worth complaining about. I decided to just get a cheap drying rack to dry everything and with in a few hours everything is usally dry because of how well this thing rings out your clothes. Even if it broke today I would buy another one with out hesitation. It's already paid for itself by not having to go to the laundromat but not having to deal with the creepy weirdos or listen to a couple with 10 kids that run around like animals as they yell at them in some foreign language is priceless. The last time I went to the laundromat one of these disgusting animals threw one of their kid's dirty diapers in a washing machine full of crap which is what caused me to take a chance and purchase this. Thank god I did. Its freaking awesome.

After reading reviews I chose to attach the turkey baster to the hose and cut a x in the top it stays on the faucet and works well. I'd suggest for anyone to different hosing for the water inlets. Everyone loves this washer in my house. Even the cat! It's definitely a science to figure out your own load sizes and soap amounts but I truly recommend this.  Make sure you do a rinsing load with soap before washing any laundry the first time to make sure it's cleaned from any chemicals or dirt.

title: Best Purchase Ever!!!!!
text: This is probably the best purchase I have ever made on Amazon. This little washer packs a mean punch. I love it. I have 2 small children so laundry builds up fast. Yes, the hose doesn't fit on any faucet in my apartment.. Lol. But is an easy fix with a quick trip to your local hardware store. I seen someones review on here where they used a turkey baster as a water hose adapter.... That works as well.. Lol. It is well worth the money.. I received the machine clean and in perfect shape. I've done well over 10 loads in one day, with no issues. Only a little soap is needed... and for draining convenience, I suggest you put the machine in the bathtub, if possible.  I will be purchasing a mini/portable dryer, so no more laundromat for me (unless I'm washing blankets)... title: It worked well until it started draining constantly.
text:
The machine worked wonderfully for about seven months. It got my clothes clean, the spin dryer is remarkably effective at getting the clothes *almost* dry, and it holds a surprisingly large amount of clothing.

And then... something went wrong, and now the wash side drains constantly-- even filling the machine to the brim it's difficult to finish a load before too much water drains off, and raising the hose just makes it drain into the spin side. I don't have the mechanical aptitude to take it apart and see what went wrong, unfortunately.

It's a disappointingly short life for such a good product.

title: It is so much more than I expected but is also exactly what I expected...
text: This washer is great! It fits in my closet and bathtub easily. It's not completely noiseless but compaired to a regular washer it's silent! I am sensitive to noises ( toilet filling up in the next room sounds like a water fall...) . I'm so happy about the sound level and if placed on a level surface the vibration is next to none...( Spin cycle, start and finish, will vibrate a bit ). the power of the agitator is super impressive!! The spinner will stop if lid is opened but, The agitator in washer will not stop if you open the lid and that can be dangerous for little kids. the instructions clearly states no child should run it....although, Instructions seem to be translated using a child's google translate...must read to believe!!! Then google an instruction video to cover washer operation, it's much less of a head ache!! But it was a funny read!!! I'm not sure how long it will last it seams made mostly of plastic and the intake hose that comes with it is a joke....but you can put water in it anyway you need to(cup,bucket,hose,inlet spot, dog bowl, cooler, anything to get the water in to it) so that's also handy!!! The spinner also almost dries the cloths(IT IS NOT A DRIER!!!!) but hella good spin out function!!!!! All in all I'm completely in love with this tiny washer!!!

title: So much fun and cleans well
text: This combo is so much fun. My friend n I , both 57 years old, have played with this combo so much. We can’t wait to have enough dirty laundry to be able to us it.  Everything is included that u need to run it. I bought an extension cord because I live in a very very small 22 foot camper.  I carry combo to tub which tub is not big enough to be the in, and I put combo in tub, plug it in, add water to the combo tub, which is very large n holds a lot of clothes, put detergent in and turn it on. 10 min later I turn it to drain . After 2 min of draining, I turn knob back to timer n add water to combo tub and Downey and turn to 6 mins and it Rivne’s clothes n softens them. I then turn to drain and put clothes into spinner side, after I squeeze a little more water out of them shake them n turn spinner on.  I then hang my clothes on hangers in bathroom n porch since it washes so many clothes.  There’s no lint filter to check or clean. Unit does have a strong motor. I am having so much fun with this machine that I actually look forward to washing clothes in it.
